PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Benefits : X-Rays
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable Senators and members assembled in Parliament:-
The petition of certain residents of Western Sydney draws the attention of the Parliament to the proposed legislation which may prevent X-Ray services being available at medical centres.

Your petitioners therefore request the Parliament to allow qualifying medical centres to continue to attract Medicare Benefits for X-Rays performed at those centres, so that this worthwhile service to the community will be able to continue.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Michael Baume (from 700 citizens), Bishop (from 350 citizens) and McKiernan (from 300 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Austudy: Family Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain electors of Queensland points out to the Senate that the 1990-91 Federal Budget stipulates that from January next year Family Allowance payments will be subject to an assets test. Family Allowance will be withdrawn if net assets excluding the family home and debt exceed $300,000. Furthermore the parental assets test threshold for Family Allowance Supplement, Austudy and Assistance for Isolated Children has been severely slashed in the 1990-91 Federal Budget.

Considering the economic crisis facing rural communities in Australia, assets tests of such a nature are not viable because the assets are incapable of generating enough income to sustain families and send children away for schooling.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to exempt the family farm from the assets test for Austudy, Family Allowance and Family Allowance Supplement.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Farm Exemption
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and Senators in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned shows:

That the Government is planning to introduce an assets test on Family Allowance at a level of $500,000. It will maintain the current assets tests on Family Allowance Supplement (FAS), Austudy and Isolated Children's Allowance which are discriminating against farming families particularly during the present rural crisis.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Australian Government to exempt the family farm of registered primary producers who are living and working on their own farm from inclusion in the assets tests for Austudy, Family Allowance, Isolated Children's Allowance and Family Allowance Supplement.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Air Landing Fee: New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed air landing fee for regional and commuter airlines landing at Sydney Mascot Airport during peak times discriminates severely against people in rural Australia and will force many airlines to either revise their schedules, cancel flights or increase passenger fares to cover this additional financial impost of the Federal Labor Government. This will result in less accessibility for country businessmen and travellers alike, will increase the costs of business for rural people and threatens the viability of many smaller airlines who provide valuable services to rural towns. We therefore call on the Federal Government to abolish all plans for the introduction of this discriminatory fee and allow commuter airlines to continue to provide their full range of services to towns throughout New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme: Erythropoietin
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Chronic renal failure patients must already endure exhaustive dialysis to just survive. Anaemia, or lack of oxygen-carrying red blood cells that leaves one weak and lethargic, is another symptom some renal patients must also endure. The inability of the kidneys to produce a hormone known as erythropoietin makes transfusions the only viable option for these patients and the transfusion destroys all chances of a transplant due to the increased levels of antibodies.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled require the Government to make available through an Authority Listing with the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme the recombinant human erythropoietin to those chronic renal failure patients suffering from anaemia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Five-Dollar Note
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

There is widespread concern in the Australian community about the proposal by the Reserve Bank of Australia to produce a new plastic $5 note that will feature the Queen, and that the present $5 note featuring Caroline Chisholm will be removed from circulation.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, urge the Reserve Bank to adopt a design for the new note that will promote and identify the unique character of Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I was making it clear last night that one of the great concerns we have in this whole debate is that, once again, the Government is locked in a time warp. While the rest of the world acknowledges the benefits of foreign ownership, certainly at relatively modest levels and below absolute control, there are very significant advantages that derive from access to foreign capital, foreign technology and foreign expertise. With the shrinking global village, there is clearly evidence that every other country in the world is taking advantage of these opportunities, yet this Government, for its own cynical, political reasons, seems to think that a 20 per cent limit on foreign ownership in both holding and licensee companies will somehow protect Australian culture. Quite clearly, that is a nonsense. It is hypocrisy in many respects. It is failed economic nationalism under the guise of wrapping oneself in the flag-which quite often, of course, is the last resort of a political scoundrel.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a tragedy that what we have here is vividly portrayed in the Australian Financial Review this morning as a clear case of advantage receiver in the world of the media. The article points out that restrictions placed on foreign parties taking equity in Australian print media could make the task of selling the Fairfax organisation a difficult one. A separate article goes on to say that a softer line is emerging on foreign ownership. It is quite extraordinary to look at the contortions within the Australian Labor Party and to understand that in almost every instance they have virtually nothing to do with principle. They are all matters of judgment on individuals. In other words, does Mr Keating like Maxwell? No, he does not. He probably resents him because he is a former Labor member of parliament who actually jumped and made a quid in the real world. Mr Keating cannot decide whether he ought to jump or not-once again leading from behind, of course.

TALK.START.PARA: —He would have been pushed, I think.

—He will probably go there in due course, but I would not back him to have anything like the degree of success that Mr Maxwell has had, nor would anyone expect that to happen. But, of course, what we do have is Keating deciding that he does not like Maxwell--
—Order! The honourable senator will use proper forms of address: `Mr Keating', please.

—Mr Deputy President, I acknowledge what you say. Mr Keating has said that he does not like Mr Maxwell; therefore he will not let him in. The Labor Party has made a great play of not liking Rupert Murdoch but, then again, of course it is stuck with him having very high levels of foreign ownership in the print media. According to the article, it is now saying, in an extraordinary contortion, that foreign ownership may not be that bad-after all, it is better than having Packer or Murdoch running the show. It is a convenient argument. It has nothing to do with principle. Foreign ownership becomes the lesser of two evils in Labor's demonology. But it certainly has nothing to do with the advantages that might derive from limited levels of foreign ownership.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had in this country from 1981 until these amendments were put forward a regime that had worked pretty well. No-one had really complained about the level of foreign ownership in Channel 10 and, indeed, no-one had ever suggested that there was a need to cut back on that. All that we had had was an awareness in the media and, indeed, through the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, that it was perfectly possible to have levels of foreign ownership of up to 50 per cent in a holding company not causing any difficulty.
Perhaps the best article that demonstrated the hypocrisy of the Government's manoeuvres in this area was one by Tom Burton on 13 January this year in the Sydney Morning Herald, where he said:
. . . Ralph Willis, was meant to be relaxing on a well-earned holiday . . .
Mr Willis then put out a press release which could only be construed as disingenuous in the extreme. Tom Burton continued:

The best that can be said of these statements is that whoever wrote the press release obviously was trying to sneak one through while no-one was watching. The whole statement appeared designed to suggest unequivocally that the Government suddenly had become aware of a loophole and was moving to close it. This was just plain nonsense.
The Government knew that the Ten network already had a similar arrangement in place for more than 18 months whereby nearly 30 per cent of Northern Star Holdings, the company which controls-
then-

the Ten licensee companies, was controlled by foreign investors, mostly UK media groups. It knew because the Broadcasting Tribunal in February last year had spent hours and hours and written pages and pages examining whether the foreign investors' interests in the holding company meant Ten was in breach of the Act.

The tribunal concluded in the negative, as it did when it considered similar arrangements for the Newcastle station NBN3. It concluded in the negative because, contrary to what Willis's press release said, the up to 50 per cent foreign ownership via a holding company arrangement had been clearly intended when the provision was introduced in 1981 as part of the notorious `Murdoch amendments', designed to allow the US resident Rupert Murdoch to continue operating the Ten network which he then owned.
The clause allowing the arrangement was explicitly referred to in the second reading speech of the then Communication's Minister, Ian Sinclair, and was opposed by several ALP members and senators.

Those who opposed the clause included Senator Button and Mr Dawkins on the then Opposition side and Senator Puplick on the then Government side. It was quite clear that all of the political participants knew precisely what the intention was. Yet that regime lay dormant, uncriticised and uncontroversial until, for politically opportunistic reasons in the lead-up to the last election, Mr Willis thought it was about time he pandered to the left wing of the Australian Labor Party.

That is really where the whole thing has gone completely off the rails because we then had Mr Willis backtracking on a decision to close the loophole. He then said a few days later that the whole thing was still under consideration, that discussions would be held with the Department and that he would not be seeking to impose anything on the industry without consultation.

He then said that he had been fully aware of the Northern Star case. He actually wrote a letter to the Sydney Morning Herald pointing out that he had been aware but he made no mention of that in his press release, of course. Then, a couple of days later, he refused to stand by the general 20 per cent ceiling on foreign ownership, despite having given a positive commitment to it in the 4 January press release.
Then we had Mr Hawke hinting that the level might be increased, and on 27 January the Sydney Morning Herald said:
The Federal Government is set to double the maximum level of foreign ownership of commercial television networks from 20 to 40 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's what Alan Bond thought.

—Of course; they all did. This was originally a decision of Mr Willis's to pull the plug on what he thought were delicate negotiations being undertaken by the receiver of Channel 7 to bring in some foreign involvement in that network. We know that CBS and Paramount had been negotiating for some time to take a stake in one of the networks.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet what we had by 27 January was the Government being so contortionist as to propose that the 20 per cent limit in the licensee company-where it is much more sensitive and where there are good, valid policy reasons for wanting to keep strict control over the degree of influence that might be exercised at that very close level-be raised from 20 per cent to 40 per cent. We quite rightly opposed that as unnecessary, as simply an hysterical attempt to try to curry favour with television owners.

Mr Hawke allowed that sort of position to run for several days. Finally, Mr Keating raised the spectre of foreign owners holding up to 100 per cent, clearly saying that because he was pandering to those in the Labor Party who did not like any levels of foreign ownership. He was showing the sort of leadership from behind that we have seen in recent days. Eventually it became quite clear that the Government had no position and was determined not to have a position prior to the last election. Margo Kingston said:

Labor is now set to do nothing and hope the issue gets lost in an election campaign . . . After weeks of dithering, Mr Willis now says his submission is still `not ready'. The policy paralysis of Labor on the issue, the chaos this has caused in the industry, and the anger of its backbench and union supporters have combined to make doing nothing attractive, in the hope that an election will wash away the problem.

By late February it was clear that the Government had had five different policy positions, prior to having no position at all going into the election, and Mr Willis had the cheek to suggest that the Government was even prepared to backdate legislation if necessary.

When Mr Beazley ascended to the job, what did he do? He dithered for quite some time but then took the extraordinary decision to reduce the level to 20 per cent across the board. That is the legislation with which we are stuck at present and which I think has been well described in the media as simply a very cynical and opportunistic attempt to curry favour with the Australian Labor Party. However, it is a decision which goes completely against the national interest and the interests of media proprietors and ultimately the beneficiaries of the media, the general public.

I think we all understand that what will drive product in this country is quality, not these artificial barriers. People will continue to make programs like Neighbours and to have them as international successes if they can determine what is likely to be a winner here and overseas. That has nothing to do with whether there is an artificial restriction or requirement on how much one is entitled to own in terms of any particular arm of the media. It is all to do with decision making and judgment, and that is something exercised by the industry and not by the Government.

I think we would all agree that foreign ownership of the media can have potentially deleterious consequences if one is talking about the media being run by foreigners-in other words, more than 50 per cent foreign ownership-in a situation where they make the real decisions. While it is easy to identify the potential for harm when it comes to editorial influence in the print media, it is very much more difficult to do that in the electronic media. Yet that is what this Bill is about-radio and television.

Can anyone suggest seriously that Laurie Oakes would be replaced by a foreign agent of influence? Yet Oakes and his ilk are about the only examples of editorial content that one gets in the electronic media. By and large the electronic media are about ratings and trying to turn a dollar. Irrespective of their political allegiances, the media are interested in the bottom line. Foreign ownership can do nothing to boost that bottom line. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal retains the power at all times to make judgments about control. It can intervene whenever it sees a need to do so; it does not need to be constrained by artificial ceilings or floors. It can scrutinise the issues at any stage. Yet what we have, and continue to have, is this pathetic attempt to pander to those who somehow think that foreign ownership at any level above 20 per cent is inimical to the national interest. That is a tragedy for the Australian media, which almost in bulk is in receivership at the present time, when so many more useful and creative things ought to be done.

The great putative leader, Mr Keating, who now has had to engage in abject and slavish capitulation and apology and who claims that leadership is so important in this area, has not at any time stood up for what others have regarded as very important in this area, that is, a much more deregulatory Broadcasting Act. We are told that at some stage in the future we will get a rewrite of the Act; it has been on the drawing board for years and nothing has emerged to date. If Mr Keating wanted to get out up front on this issue, he would be calling for that. It is supposed to be consistent with his wonderful dream for freeing up Australia and making it a world competitor, and yet we have had absolute silence from him on this critical issue.

If one looks at what the Government is presiding over domestically-for example, in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC)-one finds that the ABC announced staff cuts of 350 in July last year and a budget shortfall of $32.5m for 1990-91, with most of those cuts to be made in program production, operations and ancillary departments. The ABC is now making commercials in its own studios, even to the extent, as Channel 9's Sunday program pointed out recently, that it is producing commercials at a cheaper rate than the established industry, sometimes as much as 50 per cent cheaper. When it came to the crunch, it put a Daihatsu commercial ahead of ABC television sport. That is a tragedy and a squandering of resources.

The ABC has no right at all to be in the business of trying to compete, undercut and cross-subsidise commercial activities. It ought to be out there promoting excellence in Australian sport and trying to ensure that it at least is some sort of cultural leader and is not simply pandering to the lowest common denominator. The ABC is rapidly heading down the track of being yet another clone of the commercial stations. It is very likely to be an example of one media arm that costs almost 10 times as much as the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) and yet delivers very little more in terms of quality.

Those are the sorts of problems the Government ought to address. We know that the ABC is looking at backdoor sponsorship. The Home Show is sponsored by the Housing Industry Association to the tune of about $320,000. While the ABC is undertaking all these high risk activities, it is also very keen on pay television, in marked contradistinction to this Government, which has run a million miles from pay television. It wants to see a cocooned media industry and wants to keep the present restrictions on the number of players, which puts pay television in the never-never category and which denies freedom of choice to consumers and access to quality programming.

While all that is happening, the Government has stood by and watched as the ABC has got something like $150m to $200m in debt, with something in excess of $50m being invested offshore in Japanese loans. It now wants to get into the potentially higher risk area of pay television. The ABC is profligate in the extreme in terms of its real estate policies. It has asked the Government for something like $200m to complete the South Bank project. It is estimated that Ultimo has already cost around $150m, and yet in the face of all these sorts of problems Mr Beazley has been absolutely silent and has wasted his time on these sorts of mickey mouse initiatives.

The Opposition takes the view that this proposal to artificially lower the level of foreign ownership in Australia is completely contrary to the national interest and will do nothing to encourage diversity, promote excellence, or entice to these shores the sorts of capital, technology and expertise which are desperately needed at present. This is all about turning one's back on technology and international developments and somehow pretending that the rest of the world ought to go away and that we can go on fostering a national media industry that is artificially restricted and does not have to compete with the rest of the world. I would have thought that that was a recipe for disaster.

The Opposition, therefore, takes the view that the media industry will go from bad to worse. The shuffling of the pack going on at the moment in terms of ownership bids is a product of the Government's neglect in this area. An overhaul of the Broadcasting Act is desperately needed so that we can get some genuine competition back into the area and can have incentives in place to encourage the industry to stimulate the production of local products.

Local content is clearly what is demanded by many consumers, for natural enough reasons. One does not have to be too smart to recognise that and play to it accordingly. One does not need artificial restrictions; it does not follow that any restriction on foreign ownership will involve a limit on local content or a requirement for an increased level of local content. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal can control that at any time; any foreign owner or equity holder clearly must comply with local content restrictions. To confuse the two in the way the Government seems to be doing is simply once again to ignore the real problem.

It is a great shame that this cultural cringe and xenophobic reaction that manifests itself in this Bill is being put forward at the expense of all those other desperately needed initiatives that the Government is acutely aware of but, once again, not prepared to do anything about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: -Today we are discussing the Broadcasting (Foreign Ownership) Amendment Bill, which will enforce a 20 per cent aggregate limit on the level of foreign ownership of Australian broadcasting companies. This is a Bill which we believe should have been discussed seven years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: All of us will be aware-and in fact we have all been reminded-that it was the infamous Murdoch amendments, introduced by the Fraser Government in 1981, which opened up the loophole allowing foreign companies to hold well over the 20 per cent limit of our media companies through holding companies; in fact, foreign investors are now able to purchase up to 50 per cent of a holding company, which has 100 per cent control of a television subsidiary. Through this, foreign companies are effectively able to control Australian television broadcasting companies.

At the time the Murdoch amendments were introduced, the Australian Labor Party opposed them. Despite this, however, three successive Labor Ministers have failed to act on this in the whole time the Australian Labor Party has been in government. It was not until all three of our financially strapped networks began to look overseas for their capital that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) finally decided to bite the bullet, so to speak.

Increased foreign investment, I believe, is not the solution to the sorry financial state of Australia's media. It is not the place of government to cover for poor commercial decisions made by those who purchased the stations for greatly inflated prices and then paid exorbitant prices for programs.

Legislation in this area should always be in the public interest and not in the interests of a number of media barons or failed entrepreneurs. I fully support Mr Beazley's comment on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) program Lateline that if licensees find that they are unable to provide an adequate and comprehensive service they should hand in their licences, as others certainly can provide this service.

I noted with interest, too, the comments of Senator Chris Schacht in the Sydney Morning Herald of 22 November and again today in the Australian Financial Review that if it were to come to a choice between cross-ownership and foreign investment he would prefer increased foreign investment. I would have thought that these were equally undesirable and, more importantly, both avoidable.

This Bill reaffirms that aggregate foreign investment in our broadcast licences is strictly limited to the 20 per cent limit that was the original intention of the legislation. Further, the Bill provides that the proportion of foreign directors in a licensee company will be limited to 20 per cent of the total number of directors. Licensee companies which are in breach of the aggregate ownership limit will be given three years to come into line with the provisions of this Bill. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will be given the discretion to extend this time if it believes an extension is appropriate.

Recently, a rally involving some of Australia's leading journalists and writers was held at the Sydney Opera House. The rally showed the level of concern within the industry itself at the ownership of Australia's media. This concern is only going to grow and, as public awareness of the current state of media ownership in this country grows, the movement will gain momentum. When people in the industry itself are concerned enough to organise such a meeting, then I think we as political representatives have a responsibility to examine the outcomes of that meeting.

Firstly, the rally passed a motion calling on the Federal Government to prevent any further concentration in ownership of Australia's media. The Australian Democrats would go further than this and suggest that we should be looking at ways to reduce the already high levels of foreign media ownership in Australia. We would do this through placing a 43 per cent audience reach limit on our commercial television networks and through measures to create greater diversity of ownership in our print media.

Secondly, the rally called on the Government to establish an independent inquiry to look at the present state of the broadcast industry and what needs to be done to rectify this. The Democrats believe that this is essential. The problems in this industry are many and complex and will need to be considered in conjunction. Finally, the rally passed a motion calling for the Trade Practices Commission to be given increased powers to enable it to adequately oversee the industry. These are all issues which the Democrats support and have pushed for in the past, and I believe that they all need to be addressed by this Government to ensure Australia's broadcast industry returns to a healthy and viable condition.

At that rally, Mr Neil Brown presented the coalition's proposal to deal with the current state of the industry. The solution, as the Opposition sees it, is to open the media up to an even greater level of foreign ownership and to lift the current embargo on pay television; in other words, even more of what Labor governments have dished up to the media over the past eight years.

I am yet to meet anyone in the industry who believes that introducing pay television is going to cure the television or radio industries of their financial woes. With two television stations in receivership, radio stations facing their toughest period for four years and advertising dollars becoming increasingly scarce, the introduction of pay television would be a recipe for even greater trauma for the industry. I do not agree with Senator Alston. There is never any guarantee that pay television, by its mere existence, will provide greater quality; in fact, I would argue that it would probably militate against a higher level of Australian content.

With respect to the Bills before us, Mr Brown has stated in the other place that the Opposition will not be supporting them for a number of reasons. I think that is what Senator Alston said, although he did not say it quite as clearly. Firstly, the Opposition believes that foreign ownership of Australia's media outlets is not an important issue. I think that Opposition members, together with a number of the Murdoch editors, must be the only people in this country who are not concerned at the prospect of our broadcasters falling into foreign hands.

Senator Alston said that it was impossible to show that editorial influence existed in the electronic media. I do not agree with that; I do not accept that. Editorial influence and interference can begin in the newsroom with the very selectivity of what items are broadcast as part of the news.

Secondly, the Opposition believes that this legislation is a heavy-handed solution. Quite obviously, given the elaborate means that have been used in the past to circumvent this legislation, a fairly heavy-handed approach needs to be taken. Finally, the Opposition believes that since it removed the tracing requirements back in 1981 these requirements should not be reintroduced. It is now history that the Opposition's 1981 Murdoch amendments are perhaps the most notorious changes ever made to this legislation. I think it is outrageous that they have not been rectified before now.
Quentin Dempster, presenter of the ABC's 7.30 Report, said at the broadcasting rally:
In its eight years of being in power, the ALP has done nothing but sell out Australian journalism.

I agree with him and point out that the Opposition is quite prepared to continue, and even encourage, this abysmal sell out. Labor governments of this decade have allowed an American citizen to gain control of around 70 per cent of our print media. This is clearly the next issue this Government must address if it is to regain credibility in the area of broadcasting.

It is not often that I would agree with sentiments expressed by Bond Media Ltd Chairman, Mr Warren Jones, but, when he accused the Government of hypocrisy for allowing an American citizen to own 70 per cent of our print media while it tightened up the foreign ownership of other media outlets, I think he was fairly close to the truth.

Looking at media regulation in overseas countries, honourable senators might be surprised to know that most have very strict controls on the level of foreign ownership of their media. In the United States, commercial broadcasting licences are not available to corporations which have foreign directors or which have more than 20 per cent of capital stock or votes controlled by foreigners.

In Canada, corporations eligible to hold broadcasting licences must be incorporated in Canada, must have Canadian directors and must be at least 80 per cent Canadian owned. Section 3 of the Canadian Broadcasting Act states that these measures are designed to, `safeguard, enrich and strengthen the cultural, political, social and economic fabric of Canada'.

It is important that we ensure national security and we should always seek to enhance our society. I have always said, and I believe, that broadcasting outlets, including television, provide their owners with enormous social, commercial and political power and it is vital that this power not be given over to foreign interests. I do not believe that the ultimate answer is simply to encourage capital technology and expertise from overseas. We can look at what foreign ownership of land in this country is doing. We cannot assume that technology transfer will take place. It is too high a price to pay.

Broadcasting is an industry in which we must guarantee Australian ownership, control and content. As such, the Democrats fully support a 20 per cent limit on foreign investment. We do not support the 50 per cent limit that the Opposition appears to be advocating. As such, the Democrats support this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to speak until just a few moments ago, and I will keep my remarks very brief. I start off by saying that the Broadcasting (Foreign Ownership) Amendment Bill is in keeping with the Government's contemptuous attitude towards the Parliament-that is, government by press release. I think it was on 22 May last year that the Government unilaterally announced the limits on ownership at 20 per cent. While we have a Government that has the contempt for the systems and processes of parliament which this Government has, we will have a less than satisfactory system in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: In due course this contempt for the Parliament will manifest itself in a way which will cause this Government to be dumped ignominiously at the next election. I was struck by Mr Keating's comments last Friday-not so much because they were criticisms of the Prime Minister but because of his intellectual arrogance in saying that this country has never had a great Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has this got to do with it?

—If Senator Kernot holds her breath, I will get to it. What took my breath away was the Treasurer's intellectual arrogance that this country has not had a George Washington or a Lincoln. But right on the edge we have a Federal Treasurer about to fill the shoes and take on the mantle of greatness which, as he recited, has been bestowed on four Presidents of the United States. I was struck not by Mr Keating's comparison of himself with George Washington, but rather the arrogance that is manifesting itself in this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: When are we going to find out about a crucial matter such as television ownership in this country? The matter is not brought into the Parliament; it is not a parliamentary statement; it is a press statement. If Senator Kernot wants to know what I am arriving at, the legislation is a press statement, lacking in detail or finesse-simply a one-pager telling us how the course of broadcasting in this country is going to change.

If I might now go past that to the crux of this debate, nobody has offered a philosophic argument in favour of 20 per cent ownership. We have this jingoistic objection to foreign ownership, as if all foreign ownership is evil, wrong, treacherous and dangerous; we are such intellectual pygmies that we are terrified of foreign ownership. Nobody is prepared to articulate what is philosophically wrong--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask Queenslanders how they felt about the sell-out of the Gold Coast and Cairns.

—I make no general comment about Queens- landers, but I make some specific comment about their bigotry, bias and racist attitude towards foreign ownership-brought about by personal subjective fear, not by objective analysis of what is right and wrong about foreign investment in this country. I have not heard the Democrats--
—You are confusing investment with ownership.

—No. What is the difference? We are saying that it is fine and all right to lend money to Australians and have them hock themselves to the eyeballs, which tears apart the economy, but do not anyone dare to have any title, any ownership. We have this absolute obsession and fear of competition, of the unknown.
—It is a takeover; there is no question of competition.

—It is not a question of takeover. I repeat that I await an explanation from the Australian Democrats in philosophic terms as to what is fundamentally wrong with foreign ownership in the media which draws a clear and articulated distinction between that and owning a hotel on the Gold Coast. I have my own views, but I wait for the Democrats and the Government to put a proposition to me. In fact, I wait for the Government to tell me why 20 per cent is better than 15 per cent, 25 per cent or 40 per cent. There is no cogent, logical and articulated argument; it is simply an arbitrary figure.

SPEECH.PARA: Putting aside a figure, what is the fundamental objection that the Government has to ownership of the media as distinct from something else? It saddens me in some respects, if I can be altruistic for a moment, that we have this debate about foreign ownership or ownership generally in the media in this country and nobody has the intellectual capacity to seek to persuade anybody else in the community of the rights and wrongs of ownership, except for this jingoistic obsession and this fear we have about ownership.-If the Democrats are saying that the Japanese cannot be trusted with our television stations, why do they not say so? The Democrats are sufficiently coy to stick their nose outside the cave, battle and jump back in again.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has nothing to do with race; it is a principle.

—That is right: nothing to do with race; it is just a principle. In other words, it is the principle of race. I was not only referring to the Democrats. I do not know why they always run the Australian Labor Party's arguments for them. I was talking about the Labor Party's legislation. It is its proposition, its legislation, that I am debating.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collins is sitting over there, looking quite relaxed with his feet up on the table, and allowing the Democrats to do his arguing for him. I am interested in the Democrats telling me whether foreign ownership or a concentration of power of media ownership by two or three heavies who happen to have Australian citizenship is the greatest evil. Which is the worst, and why is one worse than the other? Again, there is a deafening silence when it comes to logical arguments.

One of the tragedies in this country is that we have the monopoly that exists at present. Nobody has put a cogent argument for having limits on television ownership and licences for television and radio that do not apply to the print media. Do we take it that foreign ownership or concentration of power in the print media is not bad but that it is in the electronic media? No cogent argument is put by the Government. We have here a situation where a foreigner, in the form of Rupert Murdoch, controls-Senator Kernot said 70 per cent; I thought it was 60 per cent-an inordinate amount of control of the print media. By any measure, that is undue influence on community opinion.

Upon reflection, if I had my way I would not allow anyone to have more than one television or radio station. Everything else has been tried and has failed. But no argument has been put which draws a distinction between the print media and the electronic media. I now turn to the matter that concerns me most, and that is that, in my view, this 20 per cent limit is really all about Kerry Packer and Alan Bond. I will tell Senator Kernot the story if she does not know it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do know it.

—In that case, the honourable senator would know that before the last election Alan Bond and Warren Jones were both promised by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), with a shake of the hand, that foreign ownership would be allowed at 40 per cent.
—Who told you that?
—Senator Walsh has asked who told me that. One of Senator Walsh's then ministerial Cabinet colleagues told me that.
—Who?

—I can keep a confidence. I do not burble away every secret that is whispered in my ear by the conspirators on the other side who are tearing each other apart and trying to destroy themselves. So Mr Bond, Mr Jones and the Channel 9 executives went to America and stitched up a package with the major players over there which was going to save Channel 9 from falling into the hands of Mr Packer, because of course Mr Packer was owed $200m by Channel 9. At that time, prior to and during the election, it was very helpful to have Channel 9 on side. This was an election that the Government was never going to win-it was like the recession that we were never going to have. This process ran prior to and during the election, and after the election Channel 9 was in what one might describe as a fair amount of financial trouble-and not the least of the people in that situation was its principal shareholder, Mr Alan Bond. Then in strode Kerry on the back of his polo pony. He of course had the money; he was going to make sure that Channel 9 survived. So Mr Packer did a deal with the Government and it reduced ownership to 20 per cent. What was the net result of that? The net result was that the deal with Bond and Jones collapsed, and so did any prospect of Bond Corporation--
—He was double- crossed.
— Of course, but he was dispensable; he had done his job and was no longer relevant. He was not going to survive anyway after the election, and Mr Packer was.
—Didn't he fix them up in WA Inc.?

— Yes, that is right. So Mr Packer ended up with Channel 9 because nobody else in this country could afford to take on the debts of Channel 9 and maintain its viability. That is what the 20 per cent limit was all about-nothing else. That is what saddens me. There is nothing philosophically pure about this; this is not a question of policy. This is fundamentally legislation to suit one man. It might suit others and it might suit other people's views about media ownership, but it was essentially driven by an arrangement between the Prime Minister and the now proprietor of Channel 9. That is what I object to-having to come into this chamber and vote on legislation for the convenience of one person. When we in this country get to the point of legislating for the convenience of one citizen and not for all citizens equally, we have really arrived at the depth of corruption and decay.
—Go back to the seventies.
—Leave him alone and he might go away.
—I have only 17 minutes left in which to speak, unless Senator Collins gives me leave to speak for another 30 minutes. I was actually going to speak for only about 30 seconds, until I was provoked.
—You said a couple of minutes.

— I did say that, too. I simply wait-I will not wait for the Australian Democrats, because I am sick of disappointments-for Senator Collins to present a philosophical argument in favour of 20 per cent and against 25 per cent and 15 per cent, and a philosophical argument that draws a distinction between foreign ownership in the electronic media and the print media. I wait for him to explain to me what makes Rupert Murdoch so special, so distinct, so separate.

SPEECH.PARA: What one can be certain about in this day and age is that Rupert Murdoch will appear on Channel 9 before every election and say, `Bob Hawke is the man you have to vote for'. Then he will say, `But I do not influence my editors in my news- papers.' They will all be watching, and we can just see them running a contrary line the next day. Seriously, I find the whole debate about media ownership in this country very sad. It has a sorry, sad, and in some parts sordid history. I am not suggesting for a moment that when we were in government we made all of the right decisions; I would have to say that they were all altruistic, but not necessarily right. But now we have plunged into the depths of legislation for one citizen and not for all citizens. Any legislation that provides a unique and special benefit for one person is bad legislation and does not deserve to be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —If that were in fact the case, perhaps I would agree with Senator Crichton-Browne, but of course it is not the case-and demonstrably not the case. Senator Kernot in her contribution gave just one specific example of the levels of foreign ownership permitted in this very sensitive area of broadcasting around the world, and that was Canada. Is Senator Crichton-Browne suggesting that the proprietor of Channel 9 in fact engineered the foreign ownership levels in Canada, or in the United States of America or in Great Britain, or indeed in any other comparable developed country around the world where the levels that are being struck by this legislation are of the same order? In fact, upon investigating broadcasting practice around the world I am informed that the only country which has the kind of policy Senator Alston would like to advocate is Saudi Arabia. I am not suggesting for a minute that the Government is prepared to go along that road. The fact is, as Senator Kernot quite correctly said, that this is not a question of sensitivity and controversy that is unique to this country. In fact, it exists in every comparable country around the world where the levels of ownership are set at roughly the same levels.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of what Senator Crichton-Browne said in that part of his speech which related to the legislation, his desire to see a situation where one television channel would be owned by one individual operator is one that we would all like to see in the perfect world. The difficulty is that it is a utopian dream that is never likely to be realised for the simple reason that, like so many other things in this country, where natural monopolies do exist despite the best efforts of legislators, it is an expensive business to start and run newspapers and to start and run national broadcasting channels. For example, what would Senator Crichton-Browne suggest that the proprietor of a little television channel run for the benefit of the viewers in his area?

TALK.START.PARA: —Leave it up to them.
— In response to that interjection, all they would be able to run would be home movies.
—So? What has that got to do with you.

— In terms of being out of touch with the real world, I think that interjection just said it all. `So?', the honourable senator says. That is con- firmation of the financial reality that Senator Crichton-Browne is painting-that the resources available to that individual, in as desirable a situation as we might find, would be so limited that the quality of the programming would be appalling. Frankly, I cannot understand the argument. On the one hand, Senator Alston is saying that we should have open gates on foreign ownership--
—No, 50 per cent.

—Fifty per cent; it is not a question of any great controversy. With respect, I disagree with him. I think it is a matter of great sensitivity in the electorate. Presumably, we should allow this unlimited access to this sort of money to improve programming. But a situation in which one owner of a television channel, tapping the same advertising market that pays for all this, is not able to put on sufficient quality programming, is a matter of no moment to Senator Alston. He said, `So what? Let that be the situ- ation'. That is just not living in the real world. This is an expensive business to get into these days and it is becoming increasingly more expensive in terms of the access that these television channels must have to the final product that they broadcast. Of course, it is the quality of that product that finally determines how financially successful these organisations will be and whether they remain financially viable.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think there would be too much argument that what has recently happened in the Australian television industry has not happened because of the actions of the Government, the marketplace, the advertising sector, the quality of the programs, or anything else; they have not contributed largely to that. Without question, the Gordon Gekko philosophy of good business practice in recent years has infected not only broadcasting, to my great regret and to the regret of most ordinary Australians like me, but almost every other area of high flying corporate finance-the print media, corporations--

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you getting stuck into Keating too?

— I am not getting stuck into anyone; I am simply stating it as a matter of fact. The media over the last two weeks and the transcripts of some recent court proceedings over the last month or two would provide more than ample evidence of that disease that has affected our country over the last couple of years. Hopefully--
—Keating induced.

— That is nonsense. The Treasurer of this country does not induce corporate greed in people. It is a natural failing that has probably been with us since the Garden of Eden-if one believes in the Garden of Eden. Again, it is not unique to this country. But because of the high profile that has been given to it in recent days I hope that it will give pause for thought for future decision making at the corporate level. Without argument, that has been the major contributor to the current sorry state of financing of Australian television broadcasting.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of debating philosophically the difference between 20 per cent and 25 per cent, legislation that provides limits to anything has to provide benchmarks. Precisely the same argument can be applied to the benchmarks that we set here on a routine basis with everything else-social security legislation, for example. It may be argued that a person is on the right side of qualifying for a particular grant or benefit but on the wrong side when he or she is on the other side of the benchmark. The fact is that at the end of the day it is a matter for judgment.

The fundamental philosophy in this country is that which is shared by every other developed country in the world; that is, that both the ownership and control of Australian broadcasting should be substantially in the hands of Australians. That is a fundamental desire which, as I say, only brief reference to the literature will reveal is constant and common in developed countries around the world. Whatever decision any government takes on this issue, it will be loudly and strongly declared to be wrong by someone on either side of the debate. It has been demonstrated in this short debate here this morning that that is the case. It would not matter what benchmark was set, whether it was restricted, open slather or any point in between; somebody would determine that it would be the wrong figure. We could canvass that debate for hours this morning. Indeed, it is a debate--

TALK.START.PARA: —Give us your high moral principles of changing it over the nine years.

— It is not a question of high moral principle at all; it is simply a question for the judgment of the government of the day as to the appro- priate level to set. As Senator Alston and everyone else knows, this issue has been canvassed ad nauseam in this chamber on many previous occasions. Particularly in light of a very long and protracted debate on the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill last night in the Senate, I do not intend to prolong the agony of this debate by simply going over the same ground that has been gone over this morning by previous speakers. It is a philosophical debate in regard to which two views have been expressed this morning by both the Australian Democrats and the Opposition, both disagreeing fundamentally with the level of ownership that the Government has struck. That will always be a problem, no matter what level is struck.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by saying that this level is comparable to the levels imposed by other governments of comparable nations around the world. I thank all honourable senators for their contributions to the debate.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Senator Collins)-by leave-agreed to:

That the Broadcasting (Foreign Ownership) Amendment Bill 1990 and the Bills listed as Government Business order of the day no. 2 (Broadcasting Amendment Bill 1990 and Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990) may be taken together for their remaining stages.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the Government amendments and new clauses to be moved to this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 1 agreed to.
Clause 2.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 2, page 1, subclause (1), line 8, omit ``paragraph 11 (a)'', substitute ``paragraphs 11 (aa), (a) and (d)''.
Clause 2, page 1, subclause (1), line 10, after ``sections'' insert ``28A,''.

These amendments will enable the consequential amendments-Government amendments Nos 5 and 6 relating to the definition of control and the new directions power inserted by amendment No. 14-to commence at the same time as the authorised lenders exemption; that is, upon royal assent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support these two technical amendments. I would like to reserve my comments on the substantive issue until later.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator POWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 2, page 1, after subclause (1), add the following subclause:
``(1a) Section 29a commences on 1 January 1992.''.
After clause 29, page 27, insert the following clause:
Special provisions relating to advertisements
``29a. Section 100 of the Principal Act is amended:
(a) by omitting subsection (5a) and inserting the following subsection:
`(5a) A licensee shall not broadcast:
(a) an advertisement, or any matter containing an advertisement for the smoking of cigarettes, tobacco or any tobacco product; or
(b) any proscribed matter.';
(b) by omitting `(5a) or' from subsection (10);
(c) by adding the following subsections after subsection (10):
`(11) A reference in subsection (5a) to the broadcasting of proscribed matter is to be read as not including:
(a) a reference to the accidental broadcasting of any matter; or
(b) a reference to the incidental broadcasting of any proscribed matter in the broadcasting of events that occurred overseas.
`(12) For the purposes of this section:
`proscribed matter' means any matter which includes any trade mark, brand name or logo associated with any cigarettes, tobacco or tobacco products;
`smoking' means inhaling or puffing the smoke of cigarettes or cigars of any composition or tobacco in any form;
`tobacco products' means cigarettes or cigars of any tobacco composition or tobacco in any form, and includes snuff, cigarette paper, cigarettes, rollers and pipes.'.''.

These amendments were circulated in the chamber some weeks ago and have been foreshadowed for many months. They deal with the aspects of the Broadcasting Act relating to tobacco advertising. In the 1970s, the Broadcasting Act was amended to eliminate the advertising of tobacco products in the electronic media. However, at that time an exception was made for what was termed `incidental advertising'; that is, advertising which was not taken out directly with the broadcasting company but which was seen in the case of television, or heard in the case of radio, as a result of indirect sponsorship largely through sponsorship of sporting and cultural events.

Since 1976, when the final implementation of the so-called electronic ban came into place, this loophole has been used to provide the tobacco industry with almost saturation advertising. Senators have had information from the Australian Medical Association (AMA) which has shown that during the Adelaide Grand Prix the Marlboro name or logo appeared on the television screen for up to 35.7 per cent of the time of the screening of that particular event. This is common throughout major sporting events in this country- there is available a proportion of advertising time which would not be available under normal advertising circumstances and which the Broadcasting Act purports to have eliminated by its amendments in the 1970s.

I argued for these amendments during the second reading debate some weeks ago. In regard to these amendments here today, other people will argue for me. I will begin in fact with the Sydney Federal Electorate Council of the Australian Labor Party (ALP), which wrote to Ms Mary Crawford, MP, Secretary of the Federal Labor Caucus, in these terms:

This Federal Electorate Council calls on the federal parliamentary caucus to support amendments, to be moved by Democrat Senator Janet Powell, to broadcasting bills currently before Parliament, which will prevent the televising of incidental tobacco advertisements and promotional material during the broadcasting of sporting and other events.
I will also quote from a press release issued yesterday by a Government Minister:
Mr Peter Staples, Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, called on all Australians-and especially parents-to help push tobacco sponsorship out of sport.

These amendments that I am moving call on the Government, whose responsibility it clearly is under this Act, to do just what Minister Staples is asking parents to do, to help push tobacco sponsorship out of sport. The press release goes on to say:
Mr Staples said sporting organisations should resist the tobacco industry's strategies to promote its products through sport.
And a direct quote:
Tobacco sponsorship has helped some sports directly with funds and, indirectly, by increasing exposure of sports,
But up to 75 per cent of the funding that is allocated to a sporting organisation by a tobacco company is for tobacco promotion.
And that leads to an increase in the uptake of smoking by young people.

That is a direct quote from the Minister for the Aged, Family and Health Services, Mr Staples, who was announcing a sponsorship deal yesterday under the national campaign against drug abuse in association with the Victorian Health Promotion Foundation, who joined the national buy-out of tobacco sponsorship of Australian soccer.

To be able to quote an ALP electorate council and a Government Minister gives considerable weight to these amendments that I am putting before the Committee today. If that does not give sufficient weight, I will go on to the Australian Medical Association, which supports moves by the Australian Democrats to reduce the incidence of smoking in our community and thereby to make a major economic and social advance in this country-economic to the extent of over $2 billion per year, which is the cost to our economy of smoking related absenteeism, illness, disease and death. The AMA wrote in these terms to all parliamentarians in October:

The amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act to ban the incidental advertising of tobacco products proposed by the Leader of the Australian Democrats . . . were unanimously endorsed by the Federal Executive of the Australian Medical Association in Canberra on October 5/6, 1990.
The AMA went on to urge members of parliament to support these amendments. Its letter goes on to say:

The scientific literature and the daily evidence in our surgeries and consulting rooms is testimony to the harmful effects of smoking. Tobacco kills more than 19,000 Australians yearly and adds many millions of dollars to health costs. Tobacco companies support sport to forge a spurious link between the use of tobacco and the health, youth and vigour associated with sport. Thousands of young Australians are beguiled by the false glamour so created to become addicted to a fatal drug. Sporting activities now funded by tobacco companies are worthy of support but that can be provided in better ways than through sponsorship by companies selling products causing death.

The AMA, as I said, has written to all members of parliament. In this particular instance it was written by Bruce Shepherd, its new Federal President, and I want to acknowledge the support of Bryce Phillips, the former President, on these issues as well. The letter to parliamentarians concluded:
Hence the need for Senator Powell's amendments to restore the integrity of the legislation and to enforce the original purpose of Parliament.
The purpose, I remind the Committee, is to ban the electronic advertising of tobacco products, which is all that these amendments are attempting to do.

The Anti-Cancer Council of Victoria, which has been a strong advocate of my previous legislation banning the print advertising of tobacco products and of closing this loophole, has also written in strong terms to parliamentarians and to Minister Beazley, who, in response to an earlier letter in May from Dr Nigel Gray, the Director of the Anti-Cancer Council, said:

Any proposal to remove the accidental or incidental exemption would require, among other things, a prior evaluation of its likely effect on sport and cultural activities currently sponsored by tobacco companies, and seek to identify possible alternative sources of funding for those activities.

Dr Gray responded to Minister Beazley with a range of helpful suggestions, and indeed countered some of his arguments or some of the thoughts in his letter about the difficulties of the process. It is clearly within the province of the Federal Government, as has occurred in States, to provide the opportunity for alternative sponsorship.

I am pleased to report to those members of the Committee who are not aware that the Western Australia Parliament, which seems to have trouble passing some legislation at the moment, has in fact passed the relevant legislation in that State to establish a health promotion foundation equivalent, following the example of Victoria and South Australia. Legislation is in the Tasmanian Parliament and the issue is also on the agenda of the Queensland Government.

What we will see, in the event of this Government refusing these amendments, is the Hawke Government isolating itself, along with the Greiner Government- although, to his credit, not Mr Greiner's Minister of Health, Mr Collins-taking the same attitude as the former Bjelke-Petersen Government in Queensland and refusing to act on behalf of the health of its citizens and, indeed, in the economic interests of the country. Nigel Gray's letter to the Minister concludes in this way:

I would conclude by emphasising that there is really no excuse for the Government to prevaricate any longer, and thereby to facilitate the quite disgraceful advertising of tobacco through sporting events-basically centred in New South Wales-which ought to be entirely unacceptable in the year 1990.

Other organisations in the health area, of course, are also in strong support. The Public Health Association of Australia Inc. wrote to me to let me know of a recent policy resolution at the 1990 annual general meeting of the Public Health Association. That resolution runs through some of the aspects of the issue: the addictive nature of the product; its hazard to human health; its cause of an estimated three million deaths world-wide each year and more than 20,000 deaths each year in this country; the cost to the economy, which I have already outlined; and its concern about the loophole, which we are attempting to close by these amendments. It calls on the Federal Government to review the operation of the Act and notes that these amendments moved today would achieve the intention of the earlier legislation to ban all television advertising of tobacco.

The Queensland Cancer Fund, whose representative I met recently in Queensland, has also been a strong advocate for this, as have cancer and asthma organisations and a full range of medical organisations all around the country. I think the question for the Government at this point is: if not, why not? It is a question which the Government really needs to address very seriously.

These are not a set of amendments which have been dropped on the table at the last minute as so many often are at this time of the year. These amendments have been foreshadowed for more than a year. It is 12 months almost to the day since the Government supported my private member's initiative, which has resulted in the implementation of a ban on tobacco advertising in the print media and which comes into effect at the beginning of next year.

It would be inconsistent for the Government, and for the Opposition, which also supported that initiative in the dying days of the last Parliament, not to support this initiative. We could be forgiven for being cynical in believing-and last December we were, quite clearly, coming up to a Federal election-that the exhortations of major health organisations, such as the AMA and the wide range of groups in the community, meant more then than they do now. Both the Government and the Opposition believe that there is more time for them to hope that the community will forget if they wimp out on this occasion and fail to act in the best interests of the Australian community, particularly young people.

We have a Bill coming before us some time in the next 1 1/2 weeks remaining before Christmas which deals with drugs in sport. We have had hours of debate on the question of drugs in sport in this particular sitting period. Tobacco is a drug which could not be more closely associated with sport; it is a drug which is deliberately using sport. As Minister Staples, the President of the AMA and many other authoritative voices have said, these purveyors of a drug are using sport for their own purposes to hook new smokers onto a new habit-and it is working. Minister Staples has demonstrated the way it works in today's Age.

In South Australia the most popular brand of cigarettes among young smokers is Escort, the sponsor of the State's football competition; in New South Wales it is Winfield, the sponsor of the Rugby League competition.

This is a drug for which there is no safe dose whatsoever. It is being given up more and more by adults in the community. Through this sporting link, via the loophole which these amendments strive to close, it is hooking more and more young people so that the tobacco industry is able to continue to sell its product of death in the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I dare say that Senator Peter Baume probably wishes, not unreasonably, to hear what the Government's response to this is before he speaks on this matter, because I know he has a close interest in it.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of the Australian Democrats' amendments would be that they would give all parties concerned about a year in which to prepare for the removal of the incidental exemption. It is the view of the Government that it is not sufficient simply to provide time alone, because time alone would not address the need for the full consideration of the implication that removal of the incidental exemption would have on sponsored sport or the arts, nor would time alone necessarily result in new arrangements for alternative sponsorship and funding.

The matter has been gone over in the Committee before. This all relates to the history of how incidental advertising became so dominant and influential. The proscription of direct advertising for tobacco products has also arisen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you scared of them?

—No, I am not. I have said this in debate before and am happy to say it again in response to that interjection that I find the connection-not surprisingly in what is, I hope, an ever increasingly unpopular product with sporting bodies-to be something that does not sit comfortably with me either. I also recognise, rightly or wrongly-the people affected in the various areas will put their views far more strenuously than I will-that the reality is, to use an expression much favoured by Andrew Peacock, that very substantial sponsorship is currently provided by tobacco companies. It will leave organisations very much in the lurch if it is removed without proper consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: These are matters the Government is considering. Until they have been considered in full, the Government is not in a position at this time to support the amendments. As a matter of fact, I understand that meetings are taking place today with representatives of sporting groups who have very serious concerns about the imminent removal of substantial funding for their organisations which will, in effect, render those organisations largely defunct in terms of their financial base. No doubt those consultations and discussions will continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is precisely what the tobacco companies wanted. That is why they entered into the sponsorships.

—That is absolutely correct. As I said, it is hardly surprising that tobacco companies would seek to associate their products-I would have thought that they have nothing to do with the pursuit of good health-with sporting pursuits. That is simply acknowledging the reality of the situation. They moved very heavily towards this area in, I think, 1976 when the proscriptions were first introduced to prevent them from direct advertising of these products.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said before, the Government is supportive of the intent of these amendments. However, the Government will not take a piecemeal approach to the issue of tobacco sponsorship of either sport or the arts. The Government believes that should incidental tobacco advertising be banned, the question of alternative sponsorship has to be addressed at the same time. Furthermore, certain provisions in the existing contracts between sporting bodies and tobacco companies are understood to contain let out clauses upon any regulatory or legislative change occurring. Again, that is hardly surprising.

If these amendments were implemented now, in some cases sporting bodies would suffer the removal of this sponsorship in the short term rather than in the long term. The Government is approaching this issue as a package so that alternative sponsorship is identified at the same time as any consideration for the legislative change that is being proposed by the Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that although the Opposition's position, as I understand it, would not be a unanimous one, we take the view that it would be very helpful to have the benefits of the Government's current assessment of the position. That will certainly play a part in any future deliberations on this issue. We also make it clear that we do share the view, as does the overwhelming proportion of the community, that cigarette smoking is intrinsically unhealthy and undesirable and, therefore, ought not to be encouraged. As the party which introduced the partial ban on the advertising of tobacco products-it has operated in this country since 1976 by virtue of section 100, which the Democrats now want to amend further-we have substantially succeeded in eliminating advertising of cigarette products on television.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the ongoing conundrum about cause and effect needs to be raised in this debate, and I know that arouses passionate voices, particularly from those in the medical profession. There can be no doubt that cigarette smoking not only is harmful to health but, in many instances, can terminate life. I do not think anyone these days, other than perhaps the vested interests, would try to gainsay that proposition. The much more difficult question and the one that needs to be seriously addressed by those who are not just in the business of grandstanding and chasing symbols--

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been on the agenda for years.

—Just a moment. I am not addressing that issue. I am saying that if we are serious about wanting to reduce the incidence of smoking in the community, particularly amongst young people, as far as I can tell from the literature, the jury is still out. I quote from the report of the Surgeon-General of the United States released last year--
—Oh!

—The honourable senator might want to put it down, and I would be interested in her response. The report stated that there is no scientifically rigorous study available to the public that provides a definitive answer to the basic question of whether advertising and promotion increase the level of tobacco consumption.
—Of course it doesn't work! The tobacco companies just give millions to the media outlets out of the goodness of their hearts!

—If the honourable senator wants to suggest that the Surgeon-General and those who drive the medical profession are captured, and that somehow this is the voice of the tobacco lobby, then she can go ahead and say that. It strikes me as an affront to commonsense to run that argument when one does not at the same time adduce the evidence, apart from wonderful intrinsic a priori statements. It is necessary to come up with evidence to demonstrate the link between cause and effect.

SPEECH.PARA: It is one thing to argue-and I concede the argument-that cigarette smoking has a whole range of highly harmful consequences to the health of society, but it is another thing to say that that comes about because of incidental or accidental advertising. There is a world of difference, for example, between promoting nubile young maidens in idyllic circumstances smoking Alpine and simply pointing to the name of a tobacco product in a sporting arena. It might be a brand reminder and might be something that prompts people to buy that product rather than another, but it does not persuade me, as a matter of logic, that that is what induces people to take up smoking.

People take up smoking for a variety of reasons. I suspect that advertising plays a very small part in their decision. It is really saying that someone was not intending to smoke until that person saw the name of a cigarette product at a sporting event. That is drawing a very long bow, I would have thought. The reasons why people smoke have been documented by the medical profession. They include peer group pressure; some feelings of insecurity; wanting to boost one's self-image; and generally feeling that smoking will contribute to one's sense of purpose. To suggest that, somehow, the mention of a name of a product is what is actually going to induce a person to take up the product strikes me as something that certainly has not been established on the evidence.

The one case that I have always found interesting, and I have not heard refuted by the experts in the field, is that of Norway which banned all forms of cigarette advertising in 1975. Yet the fact is that the decrease in teenage smoking has been dramatically greater in New South Wales-and I suspect most other Australian States-than it has been in Norway. Over the last decade in Norway tobacco consumption has dropped by about 7 per cent, whereas over the last decade in Australia we have seen a massive decrease of some 24 per cent.

In other words, we can have a total ban on all forms of cigarette advertising, yet there will still be mugs who smoke. They are obviously not smoking because of advertising; they are smoking for other reasons. Those other reasons might have a lot to do with poor self-image, peer group pressure, parental influences and a whole range of things. One has to say that it has nothing to do with advertising. If the greatest incidence of the uptake of cigarette smoking is amongst the young, then those people, by and large, were not even born when cigarette advertising was banned in that country. So I regard it as a simplistic link to suggest that advertising induces people to smoke.

I accept the right of the passionate advocates to say that anything that might conceivably contribute to the reduction of incentives to smoke ought to be embraced by the legislators. That is a separate argument and I am sure we will hear it shortly. But I would also like to hear some evidence rather than simple emotion on the subject. Anyone can get up and argue that smoking is bad and that we ought to discourage it. One of the most effective methods of reducing the incentive to smoke that has been devised in recent years is the highly effective negative advertising campaigns that have been run, in some instances by State governments. That is the way to go about doing it. Also, making people aware of the virtues of a healthy lifestyle has, in many respects, been remarkably successful.

The issue has very little to do, I would have thought, with whether Benson and Hedges sponsor cricket. At the end of the day, we will probably reach the stage where Benson and Hedges will not sponsor cricket and alternative arguments can be made. Hopefully, we will hear from the Government in the not too distant future about what those alternative arrangements might be.

Let us address what will bring about a positive incentive to reduce smoking. Many other ways will achieve that other than what I think in many ways is symbolism. If we can have evidence from eminent people such as the Surgeon-General saying that the jury is still out, then I would like to know what establishes this very important cause and effect relationship. That is the crux of the debate and that is what is missing at the present time. I understand the Democrats' desire to move this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are your alternatives?
—I have just spelt them out. It is obvious that you have not been listening, as usual. I have just told you--
—Please address your remarks through the Chair.

—If the honourable senator listens for a moment, I have been arguing that we will discourage people from smoking through parents setting a good example. Does it not matter to the honourable senator whether parents set a good example?
—It matters a lot, but it does not absolve you from taking some action.
—Let us not be hypocritical about this.
—What do you propose?

—The honourable senator asked me what I am proposing to do about it. I do not think it is going to make very much difference. It might make a difference in symbolic terms, but if we are talking about cause and effect--
—Millions of dollars worth of symbolism is going into sports promotion.

—Do not give us that rubbish. We are talking about what will have a practical effect on reducing the incidence of the uptake of cigarette smoking in this country and discouraging those who are still hooked on the habit. I think these amendments are very low down the list. The things that will make a difference are parents setting an example and those in the community like Senator Spindler-who obviously will not let his ideological blinkers drop for a moment-setting an example in terms of healthy lifestyle. He would be much better off going for a run or going to the gym than he would sitting there fulminating about how his symbolism is going to prove the big point.
—I take your advice every morning.

—I am delighted to hear Senator Kernot say that, and once again I am sure it is not cause and effect.
