Senator Kernot does not go to the gym because I suggest it; she goes out of enlightened self-interest and because she knows it is good for her. Those are the sorts of things that ought to be encouraged in the community, which I think the Victorian Health Promotion Foundation has spent quite a bit of time doing.
—It replaces tobacco sponsorship as well.

—Be honest enough to admit that those are the practical things that ought to be done. Senator Powell did not mention any of those things. All she did was get up and pretend that, somehow, this is the big solution. It may be ultimately desirable to look at these amendments down the track, but do not pretend for a moment that that is what is going to discourage people from smoking. I want to hear evidence from other countries on this cause and effect conundrum. I am confident that we will find a whole range of other factors that will make a positive difference. The more they are embraced, the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue before the Committee is not the issue as stated by Senator Alston. It is not a question of whether advertising recruits people to smoking. That issue was determined in this Parliament in 1976 when tobacco advertising was banned. It was confirmed in 1989-with the support of the Opposition, I point out to Senator Alston-when that ban was extended to the print media. So he cannot ask us to reopen and reargue that matter; that is not the argument at all, and to put it in those terms is to misstate the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue before the Parliament is whether or not we are willing to take some action to save some people from dying. That really is what it is about. It is a measure directed solely to the recruitment of new smokers. It is not directed to established smokers. People have a right to smoke; it is a legal activity for people over a certain age. It is recruitment that we find objectionable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there a legal limit on the age of smoking or of selling?
—It is illegal to sell cigarettes to certain people.
—But anybody can smoke.

—It is the sale of the cigarettes. We are faced with the situation where certain commercial interests have undertaken extensive sponsorship activity. The Minister, Senator Collins, already this morning has acknowledged that that sponsorship activity is going to be quite difficult to overcome, and measures are going to have to be undertaken to compensate for the losses. But we are talking about the opportunity of saving some lives.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember recently in the Senate when we were considering the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) and related Bills that Senator Watson, speaking for the Opposition, asked a rhetorical question: `What price do you put on a life?' That comment from Senator Watson can be found in the Hansard, and that is really the question being asked today. What price will we put on a life? Given that we cannot establish a new principle-through you, Mr Chairman, I say to my colleague Senator Alston-if we can make the principle which we together established in 1976 and 1989 more effective, we should do so. That is really the issue and to argue it back in terms of what it is not does not help the Committee.

Why do the commercial interests-the tobacco retailers, these bad corporate citizens, as bad as anyone in Australia, these people guilty of disgraceful commercial behaviour whenever they try to recruit new smokers, and that is what they are-promote actions which they know will kill people? They are no different in quality to the purveyors of illegal drugs in that sense, except that what they do is legal. Why do they spend so much money on sponsorship? I think Senator Powell has already said that they do not do it out of the goodness of their hearts; they do it because they see some commercial benefit in doing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —They like cricket.

—Senator Crichton-Browne says they like cricket. They are responsible for their corporate profits; that is where their duty lies. They have made a judgment on many occasions that undertaking sponsorship activity is commercially advantageous. That is why they do it, and I am not questioning that. They put up billboards because they think billboards are commercially advantageous. But the evaluations which are made by tobacco companies do not include, and have never included, the public interest, whereas our duty in this chamber should include and does include the public interest-even if it cannot be factored into the equation for profit. Even if it is not a cost factored in, it is proper to look at where the public interest lies. It is our duty especially to do this where public or commercial matters come into conflict.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a duty, I believe, to act on this matter in accordance once with the principles established in 1976. I would say to those who might wish to bring up that old argument that if it is legal to sell, it is legal to advertise--

TALK.START.PARA: —Just because it is an old argument doesn't make it valid.

—I would remind the honourable senator that long before she came to this place that matter was decided here. We voted for a ban on cigarette advertising in the electronic media, and that ban was introduced by Mr Eric Robinson from the Liberal Party of Australia, in the House of Representatives on 20 May 1976. It was then introduced in this place on 24 August 1976 by Senator Sir John Carrick, then Senator Carrick, and it passed through this Parliament with our support.

SPEECH.PARA: The principle was established in 1976. Then in 1989-when I believe Senator Bishop was here-we voted to extend that ban to the print media and I do not remember any Liberals voting against that. The principle has been established, but not only that, it is illegal to sell cigarettes to people under the age of 16 in many States. It is therefore illegal to advertise to those people, or to direct advertising to those people. One cannot argue that selling cigarettes is legal; it is partly legal. It is legal to sell to some people but illegal to sell to the young. Those that put up the simple argument-legal to sell, legal to advertise-conveniently forget that fact.

Debate on this matter is not new. I was concerned with a Senate social welfare committee which reported in 1977. I am one of only two senators still here who were on that committee. I can recall some of the recommendations of that committee in relation to tobacco. Recommendation 45 stated:
That State Governments and local government authorities be encouraged to ban the advertising of tobacco products.
That had support from all members of the committee-Liberal, National Party and Labor. Recommendation 46 then stated:
That the Federal Minister for Environment, Housing and Community Development-
as he then was-

and the State Ministers responsible for youth, sport and recreation, appeal to sportsmen and sportswomen throughout Australia not to lend their names and prestige to the promotion of tobacco products.
Then recommendation 47 read:

That the Commonwealth Government make any grants to sporting and cultural bodies conditional on their not accepting money from manufacturers and retailers of tobacco products, and investigate the possibility of indemnifying such bodies for loss of revenue, at least in the short term.
I will come back to recommendation 47, because in the Minister's response he says that is what the Government is going to think about doing. Recommendation 48 stated:
That the Commonwealth Government consider refusing tax deductibility for expenses incurred in the promotion of tobacco products

As chairman of that committee, I supported those recommendations then and I support them now. I supported the 1976 decision of this Parliament to ban the advertising of tobacco products in the electronic media; I support it now. I supported the decision of this Parliament to extend that ban to the print media in 1989 and I continue to support that. What this amendment to section 100 is seeking to do, as Senator Alston has said, is to close a loophole in that ban. We know that the tobacco companies are continuing to advertise their corporate names, and the very large amounts spent were set out by Senator Powell, showing the extent of the advertising. We know that even that incidental advertising has a big effect on sales.

For example, and I think someone has already mentioned this, let us look at the three major winter sports in Australia. In New South Wales, the major sport is rugby league, which is sponsored by Winfield-and the major brand smoked by 12- to 14-year-olds is, of course, Winfield. That is also the case in Queensland, where the Winfield company also supports the rugby league. In Victoria, where the Australian Football League is supported by Peter Jackson, the preferred brand smoked by 12- to 14-year-olds-to whom it is illegal to sell cigarettes, by the way-is Peter Jackson. In South Australia, where the South Australian Football League is sponsored by Escort, that is the brand most chosen by 12- to 14-year-olds.

We know that even the incidental advertising is reflected in the choice of young smokers. We know also that in up to 40 other countries advertising, and incidental advertising, is totally forbidden. We know that sport continues to flourish in those countries; we know that there are other sponsors besides tobacco companies. I can remember the Cornhill cricket tests in England; that is not a tobacco company. Also, there was the Gillette Cup, and Gillette is not a tobacco company. Of course there are other sponsors around.

The cigarette companies, in a very cynical move, have purchased the support of culture and sport in this country and are now threatening to withdraw that money and leave the sports high and dry. I suppose it is worth saying a couple of words about someone who is not of my political persuasion, Mr David Hill, the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. He is also president of the football club I support. There are not many North Sydney supporters around--

TALK.START.PARA: —True.

—Even if they live in the area. Mr Hill has actually condemned the New South Wales Rugby League for its willingness to continue to accept sponsorship from the Winfield company and has said it is immoral and improper. The Rugby League has had the effrontery to threaten to take his team out of the competition, or something like that. Those who read the Sun-Herald last Sunday would have seen a very distasteful article with a couple of quite inappropriate comments, one of them by the President of the Cronulla Sutherland Rugby League Club. Mr Hill is right in what he says. He is expressing a responsible community point of view.

SPEECH.PARA: In the minute or two remaining to me I wish to respond to some of the things Senator Collins said on behalf of the Government. I am pleased that the Government is considering a package to try to close this loophole. I put it to the Minister that his response does not hold much water. I do not think the existence of sponsorship on its own is sufficient to justify inaction by the Government or to justify resistance by the Opposition. To support the amendments now would in no way prevent action later on if one wished to take different action to make that package more coherent and consistent. To agree to these amendments now would put the tobacco companies on notice. What is more, they expect this battle to be lost. All that is in doubt is the timing.

If the commencement date proposed by Senator Powell is a problem, just tell us and we will propose an amendment now, on the floor of the Committee, that is suitable for the Government. I have it drafted and ready, if that is the problem. However, to refuse to take action now is to prevent or to delay the taking of effective action at any time. This amendment establishes no new principle whatsoever. The principle in question has been confirmed by the Senate twice. All that Senator Powell is trying to do is to close a notorious loophole in the legislation. She is quite right to propose the amendment she has moved. It will be my pleasure to support it and to continue to support the cause on which it is based for as long as I can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like honourable senators to cast their minds back eight years ago, to 1982. In that year a new disease was discovered in Australia. Since that new disease was discovered, 2,300 people have died as a result of it. About 300 people die each year of that disease.

SPEECH.PARA: Recognition of that disease created hysteria in the community. The fact that today 88 per cent of those it affects are male homosexuals, 4 per cent are drug addicts and another 8 per cent comprise haemophiliacs and people who have contracted the disease from other causes, and the fact that it is a disease called AIDS, resulted in the Government spending $100m a year trying to prevent it. The other interesting thing about the disease is that there is a long lag period between the development of the infection and death. What do we get in regard to that disease? We get television advertisements advising males to wear condoms. That advertising has occurred and permeates our community. One cannot watch television on any night without seeing it. Fifty years ago another disease was recognised as being due to cigarette smoking. In the last eight years, 152,000 people have died as a result of that disease.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a compelling comparison.

—It is quite interesting. What has been the effect in the community? If one looks at our taxation Bills, one finds that we actually devote money to the development of the tobacco industry in Australia. Taxation money is allocated to assist research and development in the tobacco industry. This disease kills 19,000 people a year in Australia and affects both sexes equally. However, females in the past were a little backward in taking up cigarette smoking to the same degree, so that their death rate lagged about 20 years behind that of males. The fascinating thing is that this year-1990-the death rate in Australia from lung cancer in young females is exceeding the death rate from breast cancer. That has never before occurred in the history of Australia, and it is also occurring in the rest of the Western world. What are we doing? We are spending money on mammography units to detect breast cancer.

SPEECH.PARA: The tobacco companies spend about $100m a year on advertising. It is spurious to say they are doing that for the good of the community. To quote the American Surgeon-General's report is merely to quote the fact that there is insufficient scientific evidence to draw the conclusion. One does not have to be a scientist; one needs only to have a bit of common sense. The tobacco companies are not giving away that $100m just to be pleasant to the community; they are spending $40 for every dollar spent on the communication of the health problems caused by smoking.

Tobacco smoking is an addiction. It is a toxic and ultimately a lethal substance. More importantly, passive smoking affects non-smokers; 17 per cent of lung cancers in non-smokers are attributable to passive smoking. It is thought to cause about 150 such deaths each year. The interesting aspect of that is that compensation actions for lung cancer due to asbestosis have been successful. Lawyers are increasingly confident of success in seeking compensation for illnesses caused by passive smoking in the workplace.

Of the 132 children who start smoking in Australia every day, 32 will die from tobacco caused disease. What would Senator Collins say to the parents of those children about the delay in dealing with the matter? Does he say, `Let's wait a year; let's wait a bit longer'? Action is needed now; the time has passed. This disease has been recognised for 50 years. We can correct it, or attempt to correct it now, put it in the too hard basket, or put it off because there are significant forces acting against it.

One of the most serious aspects of the disease is that one-third-and if I can influence anybody here today, I will do so by citing this statistic-of people diagnosed with lung cancer die within three months of that diagnosis. We do not have the time, nor do we have the luxury that time might allow, to help those people.

Smoking causes not only cancer of the lung, but also cancers of the pharynx and of the larynx. When my hospital surveyed 240 people with cancer of the back of the pharynx and back of the larynx-a dreadful cancer which is almost impossible to cure-it found that there were no non-smokers in the group; they were all cigarette smokers.
Of course, there are many other diseases as well: arterial disease, coronary artery disease, cerebro-vascular disease and peripheral artery disease.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you get cancer of the bladder also through smoking?

—Yes, and many other diseases. Cancer of the bladder is related, as is cancer of the kidney. I do not want to bore the Senate with the medical aspects of this. Instead of asking men to put condoms on, the Government should be asking us to put gas masks on. It would be more effective in that regard because passive smoking, as I have mentioned, is a problem.
—Keep talking; you might convince me in a minute.

— I might convince Senator Collins, if nobody else. There are other matters that are of concern in the community. We all get worried about global warming and the greenhouse effect. These matters have received a lot of attention and there are conferences on them. Yet tobacco smoking is the largest killer in the world today.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bishop mentioned to me before the effects of pollution in relation to motor vehicle emissions. The reality is that cigarette smoking is a self-induced condition. The Fraser Government banned direct cigarette advertising on radio and television in 1976. The Hawke Government will ban all print advertising from 28 December. This amendment is to remove the phrase that permits incidental advertising of cigarettes, which has been exploited by cigarette companies. Tobacco is the only legal consumer product linked to death when used as the manufacturer intended.

It is also argued that it has not been proved that advertising has an influence on young people. A review of a national survey of smoking in 12- to 14-year-olds shows that their smoking habit is strongly related to cigarette sponsorship of sporting events. For example, in Queensland and New South Wales, where Winfield achieved enormous advertising exposure by sponsoring Rugby League, nearly half the 12- to 14-year-old smokers smoked Winfield cigarettes. The argument is put that all this survey shows is brand differentiation.

By comparison, in South Australia hardly any 12- to 14year-old smokers smoked Winfield. Instead, they smoked Escort-the high profile sponsor of South Australia's popular football code, Aussie Rules. Again, by way of contrast, Escort did not even rate in the other States where it lacked a sport sponsorship profile. Similarly, at the time of the survey, Peter Jackson and Winfield were involved in sports sponsorship in Victoria, and this is reflected in the cigarette choice of children smoking in that State.

Cigarette companies are spending millions of dollars promoting smoking by their advertising and sports sponsorship. This clever marketing technique ensures that when our children look up to their sporting heroes they see them associated with cigarettes-all part of creating a climate of social acceptance of smoking. Children's peer group pressure to smoke, of course, thrives in that climate.

The link between kids' smoking and sports sponsorship is also why it is so important that parliamentarians close the loophole currently allowing cigarette companies to advertise on television under the guise of sports sponsorship. I applaud the Australian Soccer League's decision to ban tobacco company sponsorship. It has found alternative sponsorship, and so can Rugby League.

The Victorian, South Australian and Australian Capital Territory governments are already returning a proportion of their tobacco levy through health promotion funds to help the people in those States. In my own State, unfortunately, the tobacco levy is only 30 per cent while in each of the other States it has risen to 50 per cent, except in New South Wales where it is 35 per cent. This is despite strong evidence showing that an increase in the price of cigarettes helps discourage children from smoking.

The matter is urgent because, of the 15,000 children taking up smoking this year, one-quarter will die prematurely from smoking-related diseases. Meanwhile, the funding gap of sport will be filled from the tobacco levy, so that sport not only regains its healthy image but also retains its financial viability.

I too applaud David Hill for the stand that he has taken. I commend the amendment. It will not be the answer to all the problems I have outlined. It is one small step in that direction. As Mao Tse-Tung said, the beginning of a thousand miles begins with the first step. That first step was taken in 1976. The appalling aspect of the situation is that it is 14 years later that we are taking another step in the right direction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the two honourable senators who have just spoken in support of this amendment on the very cogent case that they have put. As is well known, they are both medical practitioners who, no doubt, have not only a personal but also a professional abhorrence of the connection between tobacco companies and sport, particularly as it affects youth.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to say something about a matter that Senator Herron referred to. Trying to define the effect of advertising is something that Senator Alston alluded to. I have to say that I thought his position was very effectively and totally demolished by Senator Peter Baume. Senator Alston would probably concede that too. Senator Herron put the rhetorical question: what can be said to parents who allow their children to continue smoking? I think it has an appallingly direct influence. I personally would be appalled if my children took up the habit because I have no doubt that it kills us. Even if there is an argument about whether or not it kills us, I do not think that anyone could seriously put forward the view that smoking cigarettes enhances our sporting prowess. I do not think that even tobacco companies would be cheeky enough to do that.

I constantly say to parents that one of the best things we as parents who do not want to see our children smoking cigarettes can do is to stop smoking cigarettes ourselves. I know many people who consistently say to their children, `I smoke and I will continue to smoke, but that is only because I cannot stop it, and it is not something I want you to do'. If parents enjoy a good relationship with their children, they should follow that old biblical injunction that has always been good of teaching by example.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I have been misrepresented by Senator Collins. The rhetorical question that I put to him--
—What is the point of order?
—Just that I have been misrepresented.
—There is no point of order. Senator Herron, you have the right to speak afterwards.

—I was not trying to misrepresent Senator Herron. He put the rhetorical question: what do we say to parents? I am not suggesting for a minute-and, no doubt, Senator Herron will clarify this himself-that there is not a very strong argument to ban incidental advertising, in terms of what is said to parents. In fact, I conceded that I think the argument against banning it has been very cogently put this morning by the Opposition and Democrat speakers in this debate, particularly, I must say, by the last two speakers. But, in conclusion, the Government does not oppose the intent of this amendment. As I understand it, discussions are being held today with the representatives of sporting bodies. I fervently hope that these negotiations and consultations will be dealt with expeditiously.

-Perhaps I was not misreported, but misunderstood. I was much crueler. The rhetorical question I asked was: what was Senator Collins going to say to the parents of those children who are going to die-the 32 out of 132 who take up cigarette smoking today-by the delay in not accepting the amendments?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I want to enter this debate in my role as shadow Minister for sport. I am a non-smoker and an anti-smoker and certainly find nothing particularly attractive about the linking of sport with cigarette smoking, which is clearly an unhealthy habit. However, I am concerned about the method of approaching this problem that is evident in this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: The point has been made, and I want to stress it, that this amendment bans television, not cigarette advertising. The simple problem exists that sporting people-and they have made it very clear-are locked into contractual arrangements in terms of advertising, in many cases for many years ahead. Those contractual arrangements presumably would stand in the event of such an amendment being passed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not if it is illegal.

—As Senator Peter Baume says, not if it is illegal. If the course of action to be taken is to make the advertising illegal we are adopting a different approach because here the televising is illegal. That is the clear distinction. I thank my cousin Senator Peter Baume for dramatising it so clearly. That is why this approach is the wrong approach. It is a muddle-headed approach.

SPEECH.PARA: If society is concerned about cigarette advertising and wants either to ban the product or to ban the advertising, it has a task of banning the advertising. If we ban the televising of that advertising, then the contractual arrangements, which have nothing to do with broadcasting, which exist between the sporting bodies and the advertisers to have these signs around ovals stand. Unless they are broken, unless the contracts change, or unless the sponsorships change-unless changes are made by law-then those contractual arrangements stand. The simple consequence is that the televising is illegal and the televising cannot take place. While those contracts exist the people of Australia will be deprived of getting the televised sports which are sponsored--

TALK.START.PARA: —They can die instead.

—As Senator Archer said, they can die instead. If he wants to make that interjection that is fine. If we want to fix this problem there is a better, more sensible, more rational and more effective way of doing so. All we will do if we pass this amendment is make it illegal to have those television programs, not to have the signs around the playing fields, on the playing fields or on people's jerseys or shirts. That is the essence of this debate. If we are opposed to cigarette advertising, as I am, if we are opposed to the smoking of cigarettes, as I am, do we approach the matter in this muddle-headed way or in a more effective way?

SPEECH.PARA: What the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) has said about adopting a serious approach to try to find the best way to handle this matter is far better than doing what is proposed at the moment. I want to stress that. It will still be the Winfield Cup, whether this amendment is passed or not. All that will happen is that the Winfield Cup will not be capable of being televised. If the Australian Democrats or anyone else have some good way to find out how we can pay out those contracts, how we can get rid of them legally, then I think it would be useful to have that sort of arrangement prepared before we just knock off the advertising.

There is one final point I want to make, which relates to alternative funding. Soccer football has been funded very successfully by QUIT. That is an example of a useful way in which alternative funding can take place. However, there are limitations in this regard. I picked that as a good example. However, there are bad examples of the way in which governmental bodies hand out other peoples' money. I have some difficulty in establishing the merit of some of the payments made by the Victorian and South Australian bodies that have been collecting this money. I am not saying that the lack of merit in some of those payments is enough to damage the whole concept; all I want to say is that problems arise when we get governmental bodies with a capacity for patronage with other people's money, often based on criteria which I have difficulty finding particularly interesting, attractive or rational.

In general, I do not want to enter the debate on the case of whether or not the advertisers are seeking to get new smokers or convert existing smokers. That is a problem on which I cannot pretend to be an expert. Probably on balance they are getting new smokers. I guess they would not be doing it if they were not, although, on the other hand, many of the sponsorships have come from cigarette companies whose share of the market has been continually falling. To that extent a lot of the sponsorships may be very defensive `advertising' in terms of holding their market share. So there is some argument in either case.
In any event, I conclude by saying that, if we want to ban advertising, let us do so, but I am not in favour of banning televised sport, and that is what this amendment does.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find this issue one of principle which simply comes down to a question of whether or not we are using censorship to try to enforce a point of view that a particular group within the society holds. I speak as one who gave up smoking some 16 years ago, but I am also one who will defend the right of another to have a cigarette. I believe that those people who want to convince others that they should either stop smoking or not ever take it up ought to rely on the strength and merit of their own argument, not try to enforce their point of view through the curtailment of the right to advertise what is a legal product.

SPEECH.PARA: As I listened to Senator Herron's speech, it occurred to me that he was making a plea to ban the sale and use of tobacco, rather than directing his attention to the question of whether or not one is entitled to advertise what is a legal product. Senator Peter Baume had a word or two to say about what constitutes a legal product. I think he was talking about what limitations are placed upon the sale of a product-be it cigarettes, alcohol or a range of other products. It concerns me that there are always within our society some people who think they are better able to tell other people how they ought to live their lives rather than letting them make up their own minds for themselves.

This also applies to credit. Some people might say that they are entitled to make a judgment about how somebody ought to be able to use credit. I have heard that argument put forward on the same basis and with the same passion as the argument adopted by people who wish to curtail the advertising of cigarettes.

In many ways, one can look at the question of tobacco advertising as being the thin edge of the wedge. That same group of people who want to say what one can or cannot advertise in respect of tobacco also would very often like to introduce similar restrictions on alcohol advertising or, indeed, on confectionery advertising-and we have already seen a move from the consumer groups to put limitations upon the times when the makers of confectionery such as Lifesavers or Mars Bars are able to advertise their products.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I see Senator Collins has some sympathy with curtailing the intake of sugar. That is a decision for him to make, not for somebody else to impose. If we allow people to tell us how to live our lives, perhaps we will be told that the design of some armchairs is not conducive to good posture and that taxpayers' money will have to be used to rectify the condition of peoples' spines. This sort of argument can go on in a never ending way. As I said, the question is not about whether one should ban the sale and usage of tobacco. This is a debate about whether or not rules of censorship are to be placed upon the right of people to advertise products that are legal.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume also made the point that back in 1976, the then Government-of which, of course, I was not a part-passed legislation to limit the freedom to advertise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you agree with the Senate's decision?

—I have already made my position quite clear, I would have thought, Senator Baume. Indeed, I believe that, if a product is legal, one ought to be able to advertise it. However, the legislation is in place. I do not want to see, as Senator Michael Baume has said, an extension of the legislation to ban the televising of sport. This is what would result from the amendment which is before us today. This subject raises passions. The Australian Democrats, from the sound of their interjections, are really wanting to debate the question of prohibition of the product itself, not the question of the advertising of what is a legal product.
—Have you read the amendment, Senator?

—I have read the amendment. However, I cannot help but think perhaps it is the thin edge of the wedge. It seems that because the prohibition case cannot be argued satisfactorily, a softer argument has been adopted. I do not believe that that course is open to anybody. The fundamental point is that it is a question of censorship, not a question of health.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us be clear about what Senator Bishop has just told us. First, she does not agree with the decision which the Liberal Party of Australia took in 1976 to move to ban the advertising of tobacco on electronic media. I think there is no doubt that she made that clear by way of interjection. Senator Bishop may also care to recall that she was here in 1989 when the Party and the Parliament, of which she was a member, extended that ban to the print media. I take it that Senator Bishop disagrees with that too-but she was a part of it.

SPEECH.PARA: I would be grateful if some honourable senators would listen to what I say. I make it clear that there is no question of banning smoking-none whatsoever. In fact, if anyone wanted to ban smoking, I would be with Senator Bishop in opposing that. I do not believe in that view. But neither do I take the libertarian view which seems to have been put out. In this society, we do limit the rights of people to do a large number of things. We limit the right of people to drink and drive-an infringement on their liberty perhaps?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is preservation of other people's liberties.

—We limit people's right to drive without a seat belt in my State-an infringement of their liberty perhaps? We limit the right of people to drive on the right-hand side of the road. We limit the right of people to advertise a whole range of products which are legal to sell. It is well known that we do so. How many advertisements have we seen for guns lately? One can sell them; one can buy them; but one does not advertise them. How many advertisements have we seen for pharmaceutical products lately? One has to go to a restricted group of publications to see those because we have restrictions on the advertising of those products which are legal to sell.

SPEECH.PARA: To argue that if it is legal to sell, it should be legal to advertise, is absolutely puerile. It does not accord with the realities of the law and the situation in Australia at the present time. Neither is it consonant with what this Party has done over 15 years. I will stay with the Party and its history. All we are seeking to do today is to close a loophole. There is no question of censorship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today is quite a remarkable day in this place. We have heard statements from Senator Herron and Senator Peter Baume which have been motivated by courage and by concern for human lives. They have had the principle and the courage to place on the record what they professionally believe in. They have also placed above party politics the sort of human principle that every member of the community should subscribe to and I commend them for it.

SPEECH.PARA: At the same time, we have heard sham sophistry of the worst kind. I believe that Senator Herron and Senator Peter Baume have demolished the spurious arguments which have been put forward both by the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins), Senator Alston and others that we as a community should have to do nothing when 19,000 lives a year are lost. Indeed, we should take every conceivable measure to reduce that toll. We do it in other areas; we should do it in this.

I do not wish to take the time of the Committee unduly. I wish to respond particularly to one aspect of the Minister's statements, and that is that the Government is not ready because the financial details have not yet been sorted out. There is no alternative. He is actually saying that 12 months is not enough for this Government to set up, for instance, a health promotion foundation of the kind that was set up in Victoria, Western Australian, South Australia and the Australian Capital Territory. I point out to the Minister that in Victoria alone this year, $20m is being provided for health promotion activities and for sports sponsorship in lieu of tobacco sponsorship. Yet, the Minister is telling us that the Government cannot do it in 12 months.

The Minister says that negotiations are proceeding at this very moment. Perhaps we can give him a chance and delay consideration of the legislation for a day or two. Perhaps he can make some unheard of progress and can get this legislation through after all. But there are other ways of dealing with this matter as well.

Some two weeks ago we were provided with statistical evidence which shows quite clearly that in real terms cigarettes now, in 1990, cost less than they cost in the 1940s. In our alternative Budget, when I suggested that the excise on tobacco and alcohol should be raised by 40 per cent to yield $1.1 billion, the thought was expressed that this was excessive. Yet we are prepared to accept a lower price in real terms than we had in the 1940s.

Someone else said that we have allowed tobacco companies to purchase the support of culture and sport. This is very obvious today: expediency, prevarication and simply a lack of caring are motivating the Government and the official Opposition, with some honourable exceptions, from taking the action that should be taken now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not propose to speak on the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 2), but, having heard the other speakers, I am tempted to make a contribution, modest as it might be. I do not have the divine knowledge to know what is right. I simply have some dilemmas in my own mind.
—Don't let Senator Alston intimidate you. You carry on.

—He said, `Sit down or I'll break both your legs'. Let me just take up a point that was made by Senator Peter Baume. I found the contributions of Senator Peter Baume and Senator John Herron very persuasive because they struck very much at part of the balance of the deliberations which exercise my mind.
—Are you going to vote for the amendment then?

—Senator-why do I always do it, Mr Temporary Chairman? I want to take up a point that was made by Senator Peter Baume the second time he spoke. He talked about the restrictions on the advertising of certain products. What he did not say was that those products in themselves are restricted in their sale. In particular, the pharmaceutical goods Senator Baume was referring to are obtained primarily by prescriptions and guns can be obtained only by citizens achieving an appropriate and proper licence.
—What about condoms and advertising?

—I will come to condoms in a minute because that is something else that was raised earlier on. I am an ex-smoker. Whenever one argues a position on cigarette advertising these days, one finds oneself saying `I am an ex-smoker' in the same way that when one debates South Africa one must start off by saying, `I am opposed to apartheid'. It is absurd, but that is really where we are because there are so many intellectually arrogant people in the world who know what is right and what is wrong. I do not.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently I have spent more time in the oncology section of the Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital than I ever want to for the rest of my life. I have seen young mothers dying of lung cancer, leaving behind a young husband and father with little children. I have seen the despair on their faces as they go to visit their mothers. I have seen young men in there for no other reason than that they insisted on smoking cigarettes, no doubt beginning because of peer pressure and no doubt because of advertising. One sees in such places not only the social cost but the personal cost, the individual cost, as a result of people choosing the right that society allows them to smoke cigarettes. This matter of society's tolerance of the consumption of some products which inevitably and inexorably lead to death goes to the heart of the debate, but time will not allow me now to pursue that now.

Like Senator Bishop, I find myself confronted in part with a question which many others have resolved. It is this: is it morally and intellectually sustainable to argue that there is intrinsic merit in the concept that society may judge something suitable and appropriate, and therefore legal for consumption, but which is sufficiently contrary to the public good that we judge it ought not therefore be allowed to be publicised or, to put it another way, to be advertised? That is something that I have some difficulty with. Senator Peter Baume gave some examples. What is the role of government in making judgments about the public good? What determinations do we make when we legalise alcohol or cigarettes but make it illegal for marijuana or other hard drugs or for other products? What is the threshold merit point where government decides one is acceptable and one is not acceptable?

I have not heard a proper sensible argument, except that other countries do it, as to why we should not have foreign ownership in television; in the same way, I have never heard anybody stand up in this chamber and argue a proposition as to how we determine the threshold. People can argue certain subjective moral propositions or can argue the general social cost to the community or the economic cost to the community, which is distributed across innocent people who are in no way involved in decision making. They can argue ethical standards or argue that governments have a responsibility to reflect the wider social mores and norms of community. But there are those, such as Senator Peter Baume and others, who will argue the intrinsic libertarian rights of individuals.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, he wasn't. That wasn't Senator Baume.

—I am sorry, I am not talking about cigarette smoking for the moment. I am talking about simple fundamental rights for people to do that which they wish which in no way impinge upon the rights-whether of a social, political, ethical or moral nature-of others. That is a compelling argument put by many people. One of the most persuasive propositions that can be put to us is that which was put by Senator Herron when he said that cigarettes are the one product--

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kernot interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot, we will still be here at 5 o'clock debating this if you don't stop interjecting.

—Senator Collins, I feel as though I am in a bird cage; every time I turn around I hear, `Cheep, cheep, cheep' behind me. Senator Herron made a very compelling point. He put it to us that cigarettes are the one product that will lead to death if they are consumed in the prescribed form and manner which is set out by the manufacturer. That does not necessarily carry the whole argument, but it is an important crutch in the view that is put by Senator Herron.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Peter Baume talked about seat belts. In Western Australia when seat belts were first made compulsory, putting aside the social and economic cost, I looked for an argument that could persuade me that any individual should be compelled to belt up. When we get to the heart of that argument, we cannot find one except that the government is telling us what is in our best interests. That is quite different from the case of a child or somebody else who does not have a capacity to make a judgment. When society tells us we have to wear a seat belt, it is making decisions about what is in the individual good.

Cigarette smoking does not cause lung cancer for everybody and does not inexorably lead to death by cancer for everybody. If it could be demonstrated that anal sex inevitably led to AIDS or had a high risk of leading to AIDS, would we take ourselves back into the trees and into the caves and argue that anal sex ought be illegal? It is essentially the same argument, though not one that is politically acceptable to some, because the comparisons are in some respects unpleasant for some people. But essentially the same argument might well be put.

From what I read and from those I listen to, there is no question, in my view, that smoking can cause lung cancer and can cause death. Yet just some months ago in the Charles Gairdner Hospital I was talking to a lady from the little city of Bunbury in Western Australia; she was dying of lung cancer and she had her young family around her.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., under Standing Orders I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Temporary Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
The Temporary Chairman having reported accordingly--

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Following the four-hour meeting last night between the Prime Minister and Mr Keating, can the Minister clarify an ambiguity in the Prime Minister's subsequent statement as to whether or not it is the intention of Mr Hawke to stand at the next election as leader of the Labor Party?

—I do not have the statement in front of me; I will get it out in a minute. If the honourable senator can find some ambiguity in it, good luck. The Prime Minister has made it clear on a number of occasions that he will lead the Labor Party into the next election. I am quite clear in my mind that it follows from that that he will remain Prime Minister after the next election.

—Mr President, I will clarify the question in the form of a supplementary, in case the Minister might like to qualify the answer that he has just given. The Prime Minister said in his statement that he intended to remain through this term as leader of the Party. There is nothing in the statement that indicates whether or not it is his intention to stand again as leader of the Labor Party. I think that becomes a matter of some importance regarding the capability of the Government in the meantime to address the serious economic problems facing it. Therefore, would the Minister like now to confirm that he understands the position to be that the Prime Minister will stand as leader?
—I have nothing to add to the answer I gave to the question.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is it expected that Japan will allow increased imports of foreign beef next year? If so, why will this occur? What steps are being taken to ensure that Australia will secure a significant share of the expanded market in Japan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Japan is already Australia's second largest market for our beef exports, taking around $900m worth in 1989. The liberalisation of the Japanese beef market that was agreed to in 1988 does offer considerable long term benefits for the Australian beef industry. The Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) believes that Australian beef exports to Japan could double by 1995.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia and Japan negotiated a beef access agreement in June 1988 which provides for the abolition of Japan's global beef import quota from 1 April 1991. Part of the agreement was its replacement by an ad valorem tariff which will phase down from 70 to 50 per cent over the succeeding three years. The agreement also provided for increases in Japan's beef import quotas between 1988 and 1992.

The more generous transitional arrangements now in force have permitted a significant increase in Australian exports of beef to Japan. There were over 176,000 tonnes in 1989, which was an increase of 30 per cent over the previous year. This represents 17 per cent of total Australian production and 30 per cent of total exports for that year. Exports for 1990 are expected to be 200,000 tonnes. There is some uncertainty currently in the Jap- anese beef market, although this is to be expected in the lead-up to April next year and until the market settles down after liberalisation.

The opening up of the Japanese market provides the Australian beef industry with enormous opportunities, but the market will be very competitive and success will be as a result of our capacity to provide Japanese consumers with the right product at the right price. It is encouraging to see that efforts are being made to develop the type of beef products desired by the Japanese market, including the significant expansion of the feedlot industry which produces grain fed beef.

It is also a matter of effective promotion. In this respect, I make the final point that the AMLC is involved in a comprehensive program of promotional activities which are designed to increase Japan's awareness and consumption of Australian beef. In fact, around $20m will be spent on promoting Australian beef in Japan this financial year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The Minister will recall that in November 1982 the present Prime Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: I am not making any challenge. That is and remains my position. I stand by absolutely the commitment I made at the joint press conference on July 16 where-in answer to the question: `Can you guarantee that there will be no further challenge before the next election?'-I answered yes.

Given that the Prime Minister sought and won the Labor leadership before that election, why should we assume that Mr Keating's word today is any more valu- able than the Prime Minister's then was and, having lived by the sword, should the Prime Minister now expect to die by it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that the Opposition would have had more sensitivity than to put a question in these terms. After all, Opposition members have been the absolute experts at all of this. We are talking about leadership issues and stability of leadership. Opposition members are all a bit flushed with excitement as they are looking a bit better in the polls than they have over the last few years. That brings on a great degree of excitement, and I can understand all of that. But Opposition members should look at the situation in their own Party-the Liberal Party. Soon, when things settle down a bit, the public will wake up to the fact that Dr Hewson is a man who needs to drive a Ferrari in order to take him out of the ordinary. What about the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, Mr Reith? I can tell honourable senators one thing about Mr Reith: he has to challenge for the leadership. Why? Because he is so miserable and unhappy as shadow Treasurer that he has to get out of that position at any price. He is not a man likely to go backwards.

ANSWER.PARA: Our erstwhile friend, the ex-senator Fred Chaney, may well come to believe that there is such a thing as third time lucky. I must say that McLachlan has a lean and hungry look to me. People in South Australia say that the problem with the McLachlans is that you can always tell them but you cannot tell them anything. That is what is said about the McLachlans in South Australia. Opposition members should not be full of overweening confidence about this issue; they have to be concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, no!

—Senator Hill keeps interjecting; he has to be concerned. When one looks at the history of Sir Robert Menzies' once great party, I am surprised that Senator Vanstone came in here asking a question of such sensitivity and indelicacy as the one she has just asked.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Mini- ster was asked a serious question about stability in the Labor leadership. He has, in his answer, commented about past instability in Opposition leadership but not on the substance of what he was asked. He knows that the rumours of instability in the leadership have weakened the Australian dollar. He knows that this is a serious question.
—Order! Senator Vanstone, would you ask the supplementary question.
—The supplementary question is: will the Minister now comment on the stability in the Labor Party leadership and will he rule out a challenge to the Prime Minister prior to the next election?
—The answer to the last part of the question is yes. In so far as the earlier part is concerned, I really think that I have already answered it.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I request that Senator Vanstone table the document from which she was quoting.
—Order! Is leave granted for Senator Vanstone to table the document?

—Can the Minister for Industrial Relations inform the Senate of the historic ceremony which took place at the Australian Industrial Relations Commission last Friday and the benefits of greater integration between the Federal and State industrial relations commissions?
—Tell us about the meat industry, Cookie.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would mind my own business if I were Senator Hill. I will answer the question put to me; I will not be drawn into answering interjections by Senator Hill. Last Friday, in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission court room No. 1 in Sydney, the heads of the State industrial relations tribunals were elevated to the level of Deputy President in the Federal Industrial Relations Commission. Two commissioners, in this case from the Western Australian State Industrial Relations Commission, were made commissioners of the Federal Industrial Relations Commission. Bryan Noakes of the Confederation of Australian Industry, appearing on behalf of the employers, in the ceremony described the occasion as the `most important reform of the Commission since the introduction of a Conciliation and Arbitration Act in 1904'. Martin Ferguson, representing the Australian Council of Trade Unions, described the ceremony as historic. The heads of the tribunals who have been elevated to the Federal bench echoed the remarks of both Noakes and Ferguson when they presented their formal views to the Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: This is another occasion when the Government has advanced by further micro-economic reform. Australia now has seven industrial relations authorities-one in each of the six States and, of course, the Federal Commission. We have taken the heads of each of the State tribunals and appointed them to the Federal Commission. The State governments have undertaken to amend the State Acts to appoint deputy presidents of the Federal Commission to their own benches, thus merging the six States with the Commonwealth structure to create, in a constitutional Federation, a national arbitration system. That is a significant reform. It was a reform first pointed to by the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems conducted under the auspices of this Government early in its term. It is a reform supported by legislation introduced by Ralph Willis when he was Minister for Industrial Relations. It is also a reform supported by the industrial relations Ministers of each of the six States and myself when, at a meeting in April this year, we resolved on this course of action.

It is now intended that we locate the courts and the chambers of the Federal commissions with the State commissions in each of the States; that we form joint registries; that we join their libraries and electronic information retrieval systems; and that we put together the inspectorates of both the Commonwealth and the State.

The names of those elevated in the ceremony were: in the case of New South Wales, Mr Justice William Fisher, President of the New South Wales Industrial Commission; in the case of Queensland, Senior Commissioner Lionel Ledlie, of the Queensland Industrial Relations Commission; in the case of South Australia, Mr Justice Brian Stanley, President of the Industrial Court and Commission of South Australia; in the case of Tasmania, Mr Fred Westwood, President of the Industrial Relations Commission of Tasmania; in the case of Western Australia, Mr Bill Coleman, Chief Commissioner, Mr Gary Halliwell, Commissioner, and Mr Jack Gregor, Commissioner, all of the Western Australian Industrial Relations Commission; in the case of Victoria, Mr Justice Alan Boulton, who serves concurrently as a Deputy President of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, having previously been appointed President of the Victorian Industrial Relations Commission.

I conclude by saying that Senator Loosley made a speech in the adjournment debate last week in which he said that, on that day 100 years ago, the New South Wales Labor Council carried a resolution which led to the formation of the Australian Labor Party. In the same resolution, they called for the establishment of arbitration as `a better way of settling industrial conflict in Australia than by strike action'. That resolution is the historic foundation of the Australian innovation in industrial relations of an arbitration system and of a conciliation commission. This reform continues as part of the same vision that the original founders of the system sought.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Does the Minister agree that if a $100m payment to the World Bank and Asian Development Bank had not been brought forward one year to 1988-89 for administrative convenience, the 1989-90 overseas aid budget would have been $1,274m? Secondly, assuming the 6.1 per cent inflation rate suggested by the Minister during his speech of 12 November on the report of Estimates Committee B, does he agree that to maintain the aid budget in real terms would have required an allocation in 1990-91 of $1,352m, $85m more than was actually allocated? Thirdly, does the Minister concede that the Government's attempt to sell this 6.3 per cent cut as a 1.6 per cent increase is a cynical manipulation of figures by the Prime Minister? Finally, can the Minister confirm that aid programs to alleviate poverty and protect the environment, such as assistance to Ethiopia, have borne the brunt of the cuts and will be cut by 24 per cent, despite the fact that two million people are facing famine in Eritrea due to drought and war?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Powell's question has no doubt been prompted by another press release on the subject from the Australian Council for Overseas Aid (ACFOA) in the last day or so which once again seeks to distort the truth about aid funding in recent years. I do not mind, indeed I welcome, robust public lobbying from the Agency for International Development (AID) and other groups on this subject, but petulant whingeing based on a deliberate distortion of known facts is not calculated to win hearts and minds, and it has not won my heart or my mind on this occasion. Let me repeat for the benefit of ACFOA, Senator Powell and the Senate--

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I would request that you ask the Minister not to mumble. He is the Minister for mumbles. I am afraid it is impossible to hear what he has to say or know whether it is relevant. Would you ask him to speak up, please?

—I have been accused of a lot of things in my life, but mumbling has not been one of them. Let me repeat for the benefit of the Senate the facts on the level of aid funding. Over the last four years the level of aid has stayed reasonably constant in real terms. The only exception to that was in 1988-89, when there was a significant increase in the level of aid funding when some payments to the World Bank and Asian Development Bank were brought forward, as Senator Powell says, from 1989-90; that is, the $100m she was talking about as payments to those international financial institutions.

ANSWER.PARA: The important thing to appreciate about that bringing forward is that the $100m in question was not part of the Forward Estimates for 1989-90; it was a one-off payment about which there was anticipated to be very great difficulty in the expected budgetary circumstances of that year, and there was a very real risk that that money would not be able to be found in 1989-90 at all, whereas it was able in the last months of 1988-89 to be incorporated in the outgoings for that year because of a shortfall that had occurred elsewhere in government expenditure. That fact was very well known and appreciated by the aid lobby, including ACFOA, with which I discussed the matter at the time. In constant 1988-1989 prices, the real levels of Australian overseas development assistance (ODA) have been, for 1987-88, $1,111.3m; for 1988-89, $1,194.6m; for 1989-90, $1,102.4m, and for 1990-91, $1,119.5m.

The 1990-91 Budget provided for an aid budget increase of 1.6 per cent in real terms, and that was in fact greater than the average increase in Commonwealth outlays. Might I also say that the Prime Minister made a commitment to maintain the level of aid funding in real terms in the 1990-91 Budget. That commitment has been met, and to suggest, as ACFOA does and as Senator Powell repeats, that the 1989-90 figure should have been artificially inflated is to extend some kind of statistical theory simply beyond reason. Because those arguments are both logically and statistically flawed, Senator Powell's question as to whether the 1989-90 budget might have been considered to be higher than it was is simply irrelevant to the question of whether the Government's commitment has been met.

To the extent that there is any truth at all in ACFOA's claims, it is that some program elements have had to be curtailed this financial year to accommodate yet another unanticipated-at least in the Forward Estimates-drawdown of moneys due to the international financial institutions, again of the order this year of some $100m. We have had to find an extra $100m this year-we did not get a supplementation to make that possible, other than as to about $30m of that. That has meant a $70m problem elsewhere in the aid budget.

Those effects have not been as dire, nonetheless, as has been claimed by ACFOA and the aid lobby, and, certainly, claims that poverty alleviation and the environment have borne the brunt of cuts are quite untrue. In fact, expenditure on the environment in particular is actually increasing.

Finally, ACFOA's assertion-and the last part of Senator Powell's question-that emergency assistance to Ethiopia will be cut by 24 per cent is really quite dangerously misleading. It is incorrectly based on a comparison of allocations to Ethiopia so far this year with a total allocation for last year. Emergency assistance to Ethiopia or anywhere else is allocated throughout the year as needs arise, and at this stage last year $6.3m had been allocated to Ethiopia, compared with $9.3m so far this financial year.

There have been pressures on the aid budget this year as a result of these unforeseen, unanticipated-at least as to timing-drawdowns from the international financial institutions, and that has created problems for us. But they are nothing like the pressures that would have been there for the aid program had the Opposition been in government. What needs to be appreciated is that in addition to all the matters that we are talking about here, the Opposition went into the last election with a clear-cut commitment to slash an additional $100m off the aid budget, on top of all the commitments, on top of all the obligations to the international institutions. So instead of talking about a $100m problem this year for the aid budget as a result of those additional drawdowns, there would have been a $200m problem.

I wish Senator Powell, the aid lobby and everyone else around the place who whinges about this particular problem would direct just a little of their enthusiasm when it comes to such whingeing to the people who really deserve it, those on the other side, who have no understanding of, no commitment to and no compassion for those people to whom this whole aid budget is directed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. On 4 December the Minister referred in Question Time to the important Antarctic meeting which was then taking place in Chile, and the evident reluctance of some countries there to accept a ban on mining in the Antarctic, or a comprehensive regime to protect the fragile environment of Antarctica. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the outcome of that meeting?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to confirm to the Senate, as has been widely reported in the media over the last two or three days, that at their meeting in Chile, the Antarctic Treaty parties last week all accepted a commitment to negotiate a prohibition on mining activities and a new legal instrument setting out a comprehensive environmental protection regime for the Antarctic. The Treaty parties adopted as a basis of negotiation a text which states that-and I quote:

ANSWER.PARA: Any activities relating to mineral resources, other than scientific research, shall be prohibited . . .

That text was slightly unusual to the extent that that language was then followed by three dots, which rather conveys the notion that at least some nations do not necessarily accept that as being the last word on the subject, but we know that; it is a negotiating text. The important thing is that the starting language of that text is couched in terms of the absolute prohibition, as I have just described it.

Obviously we will need to guard against continuing moves to qualify those clear words, but the important point again is that acceptance of them, even in this form, represents a very real move in our direction by countries such as the United Kingdom which, as I mentioned in my answer as recently as last week, were opposing us. All told, the outcome is really quite a remarkable advance since the Government took its decision last year to seek a ban on mining and a new instrument to preserve forever Antarctica as a nature reserve, a land of science.

The resolution adopted a few days ago at the general assembly in Perth of the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN) supporting our initiative is one more piece of evidence, if one were necessary, of the ground swell of world opinion in favour of protection of the Antarctic environment.

The decision in Chile is a very important achievement for Australia, France and our supporters. I also say that it is a tribute to the Australian negotiating team at that meeting led by our chief Antarctic negotiator, now the High Commissioner to Singapore, Alan Brown. A further session will be held in Madrid next April which will provide the opportunity to consolidate the process that we and our partners have made by developing effective compliance provisions in the new instrument. Much difficult negotiation does remain ahead of us to build an effective final instrument. However, there is now an agreement for this to be done and one that starts from the working assumption that mining and oil drilling will be prohibited.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security, putting yon Cassius to one side. Before the Minister moves into Brutus mode and fronts the Prime Minister with the bad news regarding the expiry of his leadership lease, can the Minister inform the Senate of one single--
—No wonder you had six goes at preselection.
— Do honourable senators want to hear the question?

— I will not direct it to honourable senators; I will direct it to Senator Richardson. I ask the Minister to inform the Senate of one single welfare initiative promoted by the Treasurer which would lend substance to his typically bombastic weekend claim to have built a market economy around a compassionate policy.

— During successive Budgets, the Expenditure Review Committee (ERC) sat for months at times-often for 16 or 18 hours a day-and during all those discussions we have managed to transform the welfare system that Australia has into one which countries right through Europe are now seeking to emulate. The Americans are the same. No other country has a welfare system as well targeted as this one is now. We have eliminated $8 billion worth of cheating and payments directed to upper middle class welfare and targeted payments to those really in need. Virtually every single payment out of social security has been increased during the term of this Government. The Treasurer, Paul Keating; the Prime Minister and all those members of the ERC; the Cabinet and the whole Caucus can take great credit for that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I refer the Minister to the decision by the Liberal-National Opposition to block the national companies scheme in the upper House in Western Australia on the basis that administration of company law other than by a local authority would prejudice both levels of service available to business and the degree of State involvement in decisions which affect the administration of corporations law in Western Australia. Can the Minister assure the Senate that the Government has made every effort to ensure that concerns of this kind have been met?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am able to give the assurance that Senator McKiernan seeks, because I believe in Western Australia there is now a growing recognition that once one puts aside some of the rhetoric tinged by the history of the secessionist movement there 60 years ago, and some of the ideology to do with States rights, there is a very real concern about the level of service that will be available to the business community there and thereby to the residents and citizens of that State.

ANSWER.PARA: I might just mention one or two of the features of the agreement as it has emerged in the last few weeks and months as a result of the considerable pressure that came from Western Australia-and that has to be acknowledged-in order to try to secure a certainty as to the level of service that might be provided by the Australian Securities Commission (ASC). For example, it is well to note that the Australian Securities Commission will, to the fullest extent practicable and efficient, delegate powers to regional commissioners.

TALK.START.PARA: —Aren't you giving your speech on this matter later today?

—I think this is such an important matter that the earliest it gets on record, it may have some influence and impact, even in Western Australia. I think every hour is useful in this particular situation. The Australian Securities Commission has made clear to the Western Australian Government, the Opposition, and the business community that it will ensure that the Western Australian regional office has all powers with respect to corporate regulation and enforcement that the ASC itself has. That office will be expected to exercise those powers in a coordinated way, consistent with ASC national operations.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe it is also worth while noting that a regional office and business centre will be established in each State capital and there are undertakings as to the current level of services being maintained. In order to ensure that is the case, we know that State Ministers are given particular rights of access to the Australian Securities Commission. They are entitled to raise complaints at ministerial meetings about the levels of service and to receive Commonwealth responses within one month. These are not complaints that will be allowed to sit on the shelf. There will be a response from the Commonwealth within one month if in fact a complaint is made by a State Minister. The role of State Ministers is a very fundamental one which complements the way in which the ASC and the companies and securities legislation have been constructed.

The Commonwealth has also undertaken to ensure appointment of a member from each State to the advisory committee and legal subcommittee. I believe that will be crucial too. There are in the heads of agreement several such provisions reflecting the need to provide assurances to the regional business communities of Australia. I seek leave to table the heads of agreement for the information of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not need leave.

— I simply table it. I believe that the Western Australian opposition-whether I am talking about the Western Australian opposition group comprising people of eminence from the legal world and the business community in Western Australia, or whether I am speaking of the formal Opposition in the upper chamber-should acknowledge the very considerable influence which their representations have evidently had over the last several months. I believe it provides a very sound foundation for the regulation of companies and securities in Western Australia as part of an advance which is now accepted by the business community in the West.

ANSWER.PARA: I urge the Western Australian Opposition in the upper House to take such kudos as is their due from the protection of regional interests that I have outlined and to allow this legislation to pass. I am sure that members of the Opposition will be vigilant monitors of that legislation in its operation, and I believe they ought to take the opportunity now, before Christmas, to ensure that we have the Australia-wide regulation of companies and securities markets which is so desperately required.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. The Minister will be aware that there are moves to replace 500 waterfront workers in Sydney and Melbourne without waiting for the reform process. I ask the Minister: is this in keeping with the in-principle agreement? Is he intending to take this proposal to Cabinet on Thursday? If it is agreed, will it need legislative or regulatory changes? Has the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority (WIRA) officially expressed total opposition to this proposal, as schedule 1, paragraph 1.1 of the in-principle agreement only allows for the statutory levy to fund employer contributions to the package? What justification has the Minister in going along with the proposal to spend taxpayers' money before the reform is in place?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I knew I had to break my duck on waterfront reform sooner or later. This is the first question I have had on this subject from the Opposition for about three months. I was starting to despair. I was thinking of slipping a few across the chamber to Opposition senators at Question Time. I am glad the question has been asked.
—And you can talk at length on it.

— Indeed, without any difficulty at all. Do not tempt me. I am glad the question has been asked because at the root of the question is one of the difficulties with operating on the waterfront, not just in Australia but anywhere around the world. That is in respect of idle time and the fluctuating nature of that particular industry, because there is not a single port in the world that does not have an element of idle time. The industry in fact operates that way.

ANSWER.PARA: At the time the in-principle agreement was negotiated, interestingly enough-despite the many widely exaggerated claims about what occurs on the waterfront-there was a national shortage of labour; a desperate shortage of labour on the waterfront. Even now, when there is a national surplus of labour on the waterfront as a direct result of the Government's deliberate policies in terms of cooling down the economy and trying to restrict imports, there are ports around Australia where a demand for labour still exists.

TALK.START.PARA: —You mean, through engineering the recession.

—Senator, this is hardly front-page news; this is back-page news. I drew the attention of the Senate to this matter months ago; that is, that the waterfront was the front-line industry which noticed the downturn in the economy first. That is old news; that is hardly new news. At the moment there is a serious problem with idle time on the waterfront. Again, this is not a new problem. There are a number of redundancy schemes in existence, which I am sure Senator Parer is fully across, that have dealt with this matter in the past: a voluntary redundancy scheme which provides 57 per cent redundancies and a voluntary compulsory redundancy scheme, known as the Robinson formula, provides for 70 per cent redundancies which have been used consistently over the last 10 years.

ANSWER.PARA: At the last council meeting of the Association of Employers of Waterside Labour (AEWL), the employers of labour carried a resolution asking the Government to address urgently the difficulties that are being caused by the current surplus of labour. That is a complete reversal of the situation that existed 18 months ago. The AEWL, the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia and other interested parties, including WIRA, have held a series of meetings over the last two to three weeks which have addressed this matter.

I have made it fundamentally clear on behalf of the Government in respect of all of these negotiations that no consideration will be given to providing for redundancies, unless enterprise agreements are negotiated which deliver the level of reform that the Government is looking for. At the moment we have an enterprise agreement negotiated with National Terminals (Australia) Ltd which will deliver very substantial redundancies if that agreement is considered to be adequate by the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not got the agreement. The foremen knocked it back.
—Mr President, I have just made it clear. As I understand it, the word `if' has a very simple English meaning.
—That is better.

—That is what it was before. How can it be better? If the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority considers that that agreement has achieved the Government's targets and it is approved, it will result in substantial redundancies being available from the industry. Contingent on that, the Government is prepared to consider-we have made this very clear-the early retirement of workers from the industry.
—Idle workers.

—Using idle workers. I have said that three times already.
