One of the difficulties-again I am sure Senator Parer is right across this-with the in-principle agreement which was negotiated at a time of national surplus labour, is that when the labour goes out of one particular enterprise it goes into a transitional labour list while all of these other enterprise agreements are negotiated. That is a structural difficulty with the process which was identified by all the parties to it. This was inevitable, given that the Government is moving to break away from a national pool of employment.
—I am glad he asked this.
—Indeed. It deserves a full answer because it is the first question I have had on this matter for three months.
—It will probably be the last.
—Order! I remind the Minister that this is developing into a very long answer.

—Indeed, Mr President; in accordance with your wishes, I am happy to conclude. The Government is not going to say, `This is an industry problem, let them figure it out as they have in the past', in view of the fact that the WIRA package has overtaken the two existing schemes that have been in place for some years, which Senator Parer has referred to. At this stage it is not clear whether the Government's consideration of this matter will require it going back to the Cabinet at all.

ANSWER.PARA: I am afraid the leakers of that slightly jumped the gun on that. Normally Cabinet submissions are leaked after they go to Cabinet, but in this case the news has been leaked before it goes to Cabinet. It may not need to go to Cabinet, but when the Government has taken a final position on that, which will be in the near future, I would have no difficulty--

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: I ask you to ask the Minister to bring this answer to an end. It is a speech. It has taken about as long as the Government is taking to introduce waterside industry reform.
—Order! There is no point of order. The Minister has taken a long time to answer this question. I have been lenient because the question came from the Opposition, but I ask the Minister to conclude.
—It is a subject close to my heart. I conclude by saying that when the Government has determined a position on this issue, the Senate will be advised. I am sure the Senate will still be sitting.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I can understand the Government being worried about Senator Collins, but I am asking a supplementary question because, notwithstanding the length of that answer, a lot of it was confused and unintelligible. I ask the Minister to clarify the position. The Minister said three times in his answer that the Government had, from my understanding, agreed it would pay redundancy payments under the system for idle time--
—Under what system?

—Idle time. This is the reform program under the in-principle agreement. Is the Minister saying that the proposal to use taxpayers' money for redundancy payments because of the Government-induced-and I use the Minister's words-downturn in the economy or recession, in other words, idle time, is not related to reform? To be consistent, does this mean that the Government will offer similar payments to other industries which find they have surplus labour because of the recession?

—The difficulty with both the original question and the supplementary question is that Senator Parer does not understand what is a very complex industry with a whole range of redundancy packages which have now been overtaken by the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority package. In the sense that the supplementary question was precisely the same as the original question, I have nothing to add to my original answer.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. What is the Government doing to ensure that consumers throughout Australia are adequately protected by uniform consumer protection legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Sherry for his question. Having a question asked by a Tasmanian senator of a Tasmanian Federal Minister is very apt because today the Tasmanian Parliament finished the process of putting into place fair trading legislation, thus concluding the Australia-wide protection of consumers in relation to matters of great concern to them. The legislation at both Federal and State levels covers such issues as misleading or deceptive conduct, false or misleading representations, product safety and information, conditions and warranties, bait advertising, pyramid selling and disclosure of the cash price. I believe the Tasmanian Parliament is to be commended for coming to this situation, albeit lately, because it puts in place Australia-wide the sort of protection which so many Australians, particularly on the mainland, have been able to take for granted for so long. I pay particular tribute to Mrs Fran Bladel, the Minister for Administrative Services and Consumer Affairs in Tasmania, who eventually got the support of the Legislative Council, the upper House in Tasmania, to pass this important legislation on behalf of Tasmanian consumers.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth Government does strongly support uniform consumer protection legislation. It is quite clear that differences and conflicts between legislation in various jurisdictions can pose real problems for business and result in confusion for consumers. I believe that costs can be reduced for business and the community if we have uniform laws and regulations in this regard. It has taken some two decades to get to this point, but I believe that consumer affairs is one area where, given the integration of the Australian economy and the great mobility of the Australian population, it is important that people moving from State to State understand that there is available to them the same regime of protections when they engage in making their purchases of goods and services in the marketplace.

I believe that this is only the beginning of the process. Tasmania, along with all other States, will shortly be putting in place uniform legislation to protect consumers in their role as consumers of credit services. I believe that this also will be extremely important, particularly as to the disclosure of the real costs to those seeking the benefit of credit of entering into arrangements whereby they have that particular facility extended to them.

This is a red-letter day not only for Tasmania but for all Australian consumers. As I say, I particularly thank Mrs Fran Bladel for the part that she has played in ensuring this Australia-wide protection for consumers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In view of the record number of small business and personal bankruptcies this year, numbering 8,636, an increase of 16 per cent over last year, and the record number of receiverships for incorporated companies, numbering 7,394, an increase of 19.4 per cent, making a total of 16,030 companies and individuals going belly-up due to Mr Keating's inept handling of the economy, will he, as the third most senior Minister in the Government, advise the Prime Minister that Mr Keating's crude high interest rates have turned small business into the killing fields of Australia and will he advise the Prime Minister, for the sake of the 750,000 remaining small businesses, that it is time to remove Mr Keating from the position of Treasurer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell asked a very erudite and literary question. These things are discussed amongst Government Ministers from time to time. Of course, they are a matter of concern to the Government. We have said that on a number of occasions. It is true that current depressed economic conditions, following a period of very high growth in the Australian economy, are a result of the Government seeking to reduce demand and to reduce the level of imports into this country by a series of policies which have been adopted over the last 18 months.

ANSWER.PARA: The consequences of that, of course, are not palatable or pleasing to anybody. In some cases, they are very unfortunate. I think one of the important things, though, is that even in the current downturn we have tried to avoid the situation which happened in 1982-83 when this country fell into double digit inflation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are nearly there now.
—I beg your pardon, Senator?
—You are very close to it now-I thought you meant double digit unemployment.

—I said double digit inflation. I was going to say-and I hope this will not encourage Senator Boswell to repeat his interjection-that certainly we do not have double digit unemployment at the present time. I hope that we will not have that. The dramatic figures that Senator Boswell plucks out about small business bankruptcies and so on I think can be obtained from time to time when one looks at the ups and downs of the business cycle in Australia. Sadly, those figures are not greatly abnormal. They have occurred in a number of other years.
—They are up 32 per cent on the last three months.

—I am talking about the longer term business cycle. Those figures are not, I believe, abnormal in Australian experience given the very great commodity dependence of the Australian economy and the cyclical nature of Australian business performance.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport. Does the Minister agree that the proposal of the Inter-State Commission (ISC) for a pay-as-you-go road use charging scheme for private vehicles, under which standing registration fees would be replaced by a revenue neutral increase in petrol excise, would send price signals which would encourage energy conservation without increasing inflation? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether this proposal on private vehicles was discussed at the recent Special Premiers Conference? Does the fact that only the Commission's proposal for new road use charges for heavy vehicles was endorsed in the final conference communique indicate that its proposed charging scheme for private vehicles has been dropped by the Federal Government? If not, what is the status of the proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no doubt that the adoption of such a scheme would give those signals. That would be a by-product of the process by which they were negotiated because the particular matter that the honourable senator raises-and I think it is a very relevant one-was not actually part of the deliberations of the ISC. It related more particularly to rationalising the current fragmented nature of registration to bring about what the ISC report identified as being potential savings of up to $2 billion a year for the national economy. No doubt, fortuitously, it probably would have that effect.

ANSWER.PARA: The Premiers Conference initiative of the Prime Minister has to some extent overtaken, as I am sure the honourable senator is aware, the process that was already in place through the Australian Transport Advisory Council, the conference of State and Federal transport Ministers. The question of heavy vehicle registration was determined at that Premiers Conference, but at this stage it is not proposed to proceed with the private motor vehicle aspect of that through the Premiers Conference process.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL LINE: KANGAROO ISLAND SEAROAD

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Following my question last week, has the Minister managed to extract a reply from the Australian National Line (ANL) about the Kangaroo Island Searoad? If so, can the Minister say with confidence that ANL's harassment of the South Australian based company for using the registered name `Searoad' is at an end? Can the Minister confirm that ANL has accepted the Government's advice that, in threatening to sue the Kangaroo Island Searoad, it was misusing an Act of Parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can confirm that ANL will not proceed down the original path down which it had the absolute legal right to proceed in respect of using that incorporation Act. I have to reject the assertions made by Senator Olsen, which are unworthy of him, I must say, considering the resolution of this difficulty. It was an extremely difficult matter for a Federal Government Minister to become directly involved in. I would have thought that, considering we have had such a positive outcome to these negotiations, he would have been a little more charitable. ANL was not harassing this company. If one were to talk to ANL-and I might add that this is expressed in the correspondence--
—Oh!

—All I can say to the honourable senator is-and this is why these matters are generally resolved in courts at the end of the day-that it has a story from its point of view about its relationship with the South Australian company, which is just as critical as, I guess, the South Australian company is of ANL.

ANSWER.PARA: The upshot of it is that I had a long discussion with Mr Bolitho, the Chairman of the Board of ANL, following representations that were made to me by the company itself, the South Australian Attorney-General, and latterly by Senator Olsen. As a result of that, Mr Bolitho wrote to me and expressed, in his usual robust fashion, his views on the matter and invited me to advise him in writing of the Government's position on this. I did so. I now have an indication from the company, as I indicated originally I would try to get, that it will not rely on this particular form of relief. If it does decide to take the matter further, it will do so by the normal legal avenues that are available to it, as are available to any other company.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs aware of strong Aboriginal opposition to the proposed Cape York spaceport? Given that Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders comprise 90 per cent of Cape York's population yet have only 18 per cent of land tenure, what guarantees will the Federal Government give to protect traditional rights and significant sites and to ensure genuine consultation with the traditional owners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an important question. The Aboriginal community of Cape York has, hardly surprisingly, many concerns about the proposal to establish a space base in its midst. Those concerns have been relayed to the Government through the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

ANSWER.PARA: The Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has made it absolutely clear to the Aboriginal people of this area that there will be no final government approval for the spaceport without an acceptable environmental impact statement (EIS) from the agency being prepared and before there is full consultation with the Aboriginal community on Cape York as to the detail of that developmental plan. The EIS will of course address Aboriginal interests in the site of the proposed spaceport as well.

I might add that Federal Government support for the spaceport is also subject to the results of a joint Commonwealth-Queensland government land use study for the whole of Cape York. The environmental impact statement will be an important part of the land use study that is taking place. Provision has been made by financial contribution to the study from the Queensland Government. A steering committee has already been established for this land use study which includes in its membership representation from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. I am also aware, through press reports, that at a recent protest at Temple Bay the Cape York Land Council was established, and I know that this Land Council is in communication with the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister indicate whether the Cape York Aboriginal Land Council will receive access to Government resources and advisers equal to that which proponents of the spaceport proposal will receive?

—I cannot confirm that. I do not have the detail about the resources that will be made available because this Land Council was established only very recently. I am happy to make inquiries of the Minister and respond to the honourable senator at a later time.

—I refer the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support to my question to him of 17 October 1990 regarding waterfront reform. I might point out that that is not two months ago-let alone three months ago. I ask the Minister whether the reason for his flamboyant misleading of the Senate today-as he did in those references to three months-is an attempt, firstly, to direct the Senate's attention away from his Government's miserable efforts on waterfront reform--
—What is the question?

—that is one of them-or, secondly, to disguise the fact that the attempt to reform the Cairns waterfront, which is a precedent for regional port waterfront reform right throughout Australia, is in shambles. Thirdly, in view of the Minister's poor judgment on timing, is it his fervent hope that he can fool people on the timing of the 12 months when he has to resign because waterfront reform has not worked?
—I have not misled the Senate today in the answer that I gave; I take significant exception to that assertion.
—And you certainly have not been flamboyant.

— I certainly have not been flamboyant; Senator Richardson is quite right. But I am glad that Senator Macdonald has raised the question of the Cairns waterfront. What we have in Cairns-again, it is symptomatic of the difficulties that are associated with getting reform in this particular industry-is a situation where, after tortuous negotiations with all the parties concerned and after the deliberate intrusion of, initially, myself and then the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority (WIRA) in meetings with all the parties in Cairns and then a whole series of subsequent private meetings with the principals on both sides of the debate, a position was reached where everyone agreed to disagree. The Waterfront Industry Reform Authority prepared a set of recommendations, which were widely supported, in terms of resolving the issue and getting the surplus labour out of the port. I will be delighted to put the first cheque in the hand of the first person who is going to leave the port.
—When does that happen?

— Let me finish. The difficulty then was that, having achieved the agreement of the union-the one and only party to this entire process singled out for special attention by the Opposition; no-one ever hears about the employers-regrettably, the employers made a decision, which was at odds with assurances that they had given me on previous occasions, to reject the WIRA proposal. That is where the situation is at currently. We are now advancing yet another proposal which will hopefully bring the matter to a conclusion. Those negotiations are being advanced by the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. What is the extent of sports injuries and the cost to the community of such injuries, particularly in light of the recent report addressing those? What has the Australian Sports Commission done to address this problem? What action is it intending to take in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —A report by Dr Garry Egger into sports injuries, which was carried out under the national better health program, suggests that the costs of sports injuries, which include indirect costs such as absenteeism from work, et cetera, are now running at around $1 billion per year. That figure includes activities which go beyond organised competitive sport and needs to be considered in context. For example, the annual health costs associated with the effects of smoking and physical inactivity are $3 billion a year and $3 1/2 billion a year respectively. Major causes of sports injuries are deficient training and preparation, overtraining, and playing on inadequate surfaces. Clearly, those sports involving body contact or strain on particular parts of the body such as ankles and knees have a higher incidence of injury.

ANSWER.PARA: In recent years the Sports Commission has contributed about $20,000, through the Australian Sports Medicine Federation, for the production of booklets and other material to educate coaches and players. Sixteen thousand coaches have been put through the national sports trainers scheme, which includes showing them ways to minimise sports injury. Sixteen thousand coaches is not a bad figure.

The Commission, through the national sports research program, has funded specific studies into injuries in netball, rugby, gymnastics, softball and cricket. The Australian Institute of Sport sports medicine centre of the Sports Commission has undertaken specific prevention programs which have contributed to a reduction of injuries in netball, basketball, athletics, swimming, tennis and rowing. Prevention of injuries is an essential component in all Institute programs and for all of the 55 sports covered by the national sports program.

The Commission is currently examining the Egger report in consultation with the Confederation of Australian Sport Inc. and the Australian Sports Medicine Federation to determine future action and funding requirements. Ideas are being developed for more extensive education programs. Discussions with those sports particularly prone to injuries regarding rule changes are being conducted. The Government regards this as a serious issue and, through the Sports Commission and the Department of Community Services and Health, will build on the work already done and develop a program to minimise sport injuries in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Calvert asked me a question about local government funding. I have some more information for him. I seek leave to incorporate that in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

Yesterday Senator Calvert asked whether I had concerns about a recent report in the Australian that councils are selling up people's homes to recover bad debts and whether the Commonwealth Department intended to do anything about it. I have now seen the article to which Senator Calvert referred.
I am of course concerned about the possibility of people losing their homes because of their inability to pay local rates.

The issue of rates collections however is not a matter for the Commonwealth-it is a matter for the councils and State governments. There is no data available on numbers of ratepayers against which councils have taken action, and the situation is further complicated by the need to distinguish between residential, investment and commercial properties. I would urge those councils which have not yet done so to view any inability to meet rates sympathetically and to introduce more flexible arrangements for their payment. Many councils have, of course, already implemented such arrangements.

We recognise that current economic circumstances are proving difficult for many Australians and are causing significant pain. However the lowering of interest rates over the last few months and the forthcoming tax cuts will go some way to easing this situation.
Local government, like the Commonwealth and the States, has had to shoulder its part of the burden of economic restraint.

Despite this, the Commonwealth has continued to provide significant financial assistance to local government. An estimated $1.2 billion will be provided this financial year, which comprises nearly one fifth of ordinary council revenue.

In some cases local government may need to put its own house in order. I note a weekend media report that a spokesman for the Premier of New South Wales has said that a State inquiry into local government spending had uncovered poor management practices and that councils in financial difficulty would be encouraged to improve their performance instead of asking the Government to throw money at the problem.
Let me also take this opportunity to clarify what I said yesterday about financial assistance for local government.

Financial assistance grants are provided under the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act-this Act allows the Minister to review the legislation after 30 June 1992, in consultation with the States and local government.
A decision on whether any such formal review will take place will be made closer to the event.
The current operation of the Act is presently being monitored by a group of Commonwealth, State and local government officials, at the request of Commonwealth and State Ministers.

These officials are focussing on a number of issues, including the scope for allocating some financial assistance on the basis of a council's efficiency-a move which would be consistent with the principles of microeconomic reform.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 December 1990 Senator Newman asked a question about the Concord Repatriation Hospital. I have further information on that. I seek leave to incorporate that in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

Senator Newman's question in the Senate on 5 December 1990 noted that the contract for the surgical and diagnostic redevelopment project at Concord Hospital involved a settlement of approximately $5 million in December 1989. She has tried to relate this to inadequate management practices within the department and in particular in the costing of the project, cash flow management and in not providing appropriate architectural advice or ensuring adequate supervision during construction.

I am advised that the settlement arose from claims which occurred during the progress of the contract for changes to the scope of works and disruptions to the contractor's program for construction of the project. The work had gone to tender in late 1985 with documents which had aimed to tightly control the scope and cost of the project. The documents for this project were prepared by private sector consultants.

Subsequently, changes were required to maintain hospital functions and by variations to accommodate developments in medical technology and practice in regard to control of AIDS and hepatitis ``B''. I am advised that these changes were compounded by some deficiencies in the documents, variations arising from existing building conditions unknown until the building structure was progressively exposed and on site industrial disputes relating to asbestos removal and a perceived safety hazard from Legionnaire's Disease.

Under a lump sum price contract, all these issues became matters of dispute and claim under the contract which can only be settled by negotiation or arbitration. To the extent that ACS was responsible for managing the works and administering the contract, it was party to the eventual level of claims received.

However, I am advised that the AC on-site team managing the project throughout its duration, made every effort to tightly control the works in the interests of the client and the Commonwealth. There was no culpable failure in management practices relating to cost control, cash flow management, architectural advice or supervision during construction.

Unfortunately, the financial consequences of all the problems relating to such a project only emerge when the contract is being finalised. The level of claims on this project reflected the complexity of the project and the problems occurring during construction.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a previous date, Senator Newman asked a question about the Garden of Remembrance at the Rookwood Cemetery and also one in South Australia. I have further information on that. I seek leave to incorporate that in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

The Commonwealth Office of Australian War Graves (OAWG) is currently constructing a garden of remembrance at Rookwood Cemetery NSW. The new garden is estimated to cost $6.0M and is scheduled for completion by Christmas 1990 and will provide for 100,000 plaques.

The contract, with a total commitment of 3.8 million dollars was let to Girvan (NSW) Proprietary Limited in August 1988 with an anticipated completion date of 17 July 1989. Progress in the first half of 1989 was extremely slow due to a combination of abnormally wet weather, brick supply problems, low productivity and severe industrial disputation.
The works were temporarily suspended on 4 July 1989 to allow the work to be redesigned to permit the incorporation of different bricks.
The suspension was lifted on 25 October 1989 and the resumed work proceeded well until Girvan went into receivership on 30 January 1990.

R. N. Cooper Constructions Proprietary Limited were subsequently engaged to provide a temporary construction management service to enable work to continue and avoid further industrial problems. Coopers commenced work on site on 16 February 1990 and work proceeded well until wet weather in April 1990 hampered progress.

After the Department of Finance approved an increase in authorisation to 6.0 million dollars in order to complete the project, a lump sum contract was signed with Cooper on 6 July 1990 and a contract completion date set for 25 September 1990.
Coopers have subsequently experienced delays resulting from wet weather combined with safety, industrial and sub-contractors problems. This has resulted in progress being slower than anticipated.

Coopers current program schedules completion by Christmas 1990 provided no problems are encountered. Based on current known claims and variations the project will be completed within the current authorisation figure of $6.0m.

However, the contractor has intimated that he may pursue claims for delay costs but at this time no submission has been received. The impact if any, can not be assessed until such claims have been received and admissibility or otherwise has been established.
SA-Garden of Remembrance

The project comprised the demolition of an existing garden of remembrance and the construction of a new larger facility for the Office of Australian War Graves (OAWG) in an adjacent location within the grounds of the Centennial Park Cemetery covering an area of some 4,000 square metres.

The work included the provision of an entrance building containing office and amenities through which access is obtained to a walled garden area. The garden area was provided with a number of internal walls for the mounting of commemorative plaques for eligible veterans from all arms of the defence forces and included landscaped areas, a central water feature, contemplation pools and a workshop/storage area at the rear for maintenance purposes.

Separate contracts were arranged for the demolition of the existing gardens and the construction of the new facility on 24 June 1986 and 6 January 1986 respectively, with completion anticipated in August 1986.
Work commenced in January 1986 on the new gardens and they were accepted into use by the OAWG on 4 November 1987.

Shortly after work commenced several major changes to the project were proposed by the Centennial Park Trust which were agreed by the OAWG and incorporated into the project. These changes affected progress of the project and required additional funding to be provided by OAWG together with an extension to the completion date.

During the course of construction and despite close supervision it became evident that the contractor's rate of progress and performance generally were falling below a satisfactory level. The project was also experiencing industrial difficulties.
After close consultation with the OAWG, AC initiated termination of the contract in July 1987 and took over and completed the works utilising a series of direct contracts.
Landscaping and plaque erection were undertaken by OAWG staff and overlapped the final stages of construction.
The original funding for the project was 1.078 million dollars however due to the above mentioned problems the completed cost rose to 1.328 million dollars.
An official opening was held on 18 March 1988 and was attended by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Treasurer's inept engineering of the Australian economy that has resulted in business and personal bankruptcies soaring to 16,030 an increase over the last financial year of 17.6 per cent.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I bring this matter to the attention of the Senate because it is of paramount importance. Instead of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) trying to undermine the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to push forward his leadership ambitions, he should be concentrating on the job of controlling an economy that allows 16,030 small businesses to go into receivership. That is an increase of 17.6 per cent over last year.

SPEECH.PARA: Small business and personal bankruptcies total 8,636; that is an increase of 32 per cent on the previous three months and an increase of 17.6 per cent over the last financial year. The figure given by the receiver, liquidator and manager for corporations going into receivership is 7,394. These are incredible tip of the iceberg figures that do not include people who just shut their doors and walk away from their businesses or the people who walk away from their farms. These people are bankrupt and file for bankruptcy.

It is a very telling indication of how the policies of the Treasurer have failed Australia. When we see 16,000 firms and personal bankruptcies occurring in Australia, we know that things are not right. This Government has had eight years to get things right. Unfortunately for Australia, things are getting worse. Today, Senator Button said that it is a cyclical arrangement, that business has its ups and downs and therefore we should not take much notice of it. I thought it was very unsympathetic of Senator Button--

TALK.START.PARA: —It would have been if he had said that, but he didn't.

—He did say it. The last time he made some comment he blamed the banks. Before that he blamed small business for not knowing what it was doing. He has never laid the blame fairly and squarely where it belongs; that is, at the feet of the Treasurer and this Government. Senator Button has said that, as have a number of other Ministers. Mr Keating, the Treasurer, has blamed the banks. Everyone has blamed everyone else and no-one has put the blame where it belongs.

SPEECH.PARA: The policies have failed in two ways. Firstly, high interest rates are certainly responsible for the demise of many small businesses; they have cut the demand, which is what the Government wanted to get inflation down. But, by gee, what a horrible price to pay to reduce inflation-the demise of 16,000 businesses. It is not just small businesses that are collapsing; we are starting to see massive businesses collapse. Thiess Watkins is one of the biggest and longest serving businesses in Queensland. The Fairfax organisation went down today--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the Government's fault?
—Of course it is the Government's fault because high interest rates are driving these businesses down.
—My God, we are responsible for Warwick Fairfax now.
—The Government is responsible for the demise of 16,030 businesses. It ought to take the blame squarely on the shoulders and not blame the banks, the economy, and everyone else.
—Take Nobby Clark.

—The Government should heed Nobby Clark's message; it could not sell shoelaces and make a profit. Secondly, prime interest rates in Australia have fluctuated between a low of 15 per cent and a high of 19.42 per cent. Over the last three or four years small businesses, farmers and manufacturers have had to face interest rates of up to 23 per cent. How can they be competitive against overseas manufacturers who are paying interest rates as low as 8 per cent? In Japan interest rates are as low as 6 per cent. It is an impossibility. Small businesses have not been able to pay these high interest rates and that is why bankruptcies have escalated to 16,030, which is a record for Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: However, there is another reason why we are seeing business failures, and that is the accord-an instrument that also has the support of the Treasurer. Senator Walsh has made the statement that the accord has not delivered any productivity. The accord may have kept wages in line with inflation, but it certainly has not kept oncosts in line with inflation.

The other night a Queensland businessman told me that he attended a lunch, I think it was, with Mr Keating and that Mr Keating got up and said that the business community was not pulling its weight in Australia. Mr Keating said to the business community that he had given a policy that had kept inflation in line with wages and that the business community had not responded. One person got up and told Mr Keating that the oncosts of his particular business had escalated to around 20 per cent and, for his trouble, Mr Keating roundly abused him in front of the whole meeting. If one cannot get agreement from someone, then abuse is the next best thing, according to Mr Keating.

The Confederation of Australian Industry has said that there has been a 22 per cent movement in labour costs during 1990. This Government has inflicted a 22 per cent movement in labour costs on the business community of Australia. It is costing 22 per cent more this year to employ someone than it did last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where do you think the other 17 per cent is coming from, over and above wages?

—I know where it is not coming from. It is not coming from the business community, because it is going broke and cannot afford to pay it; that is why we have seen record bankruptcies. I did my own costings and pulled out some figures on a company that I am connected with. Perhaps Senator McMullan could comment on these figures. Since 1988 there has been a 12.18 per cent pay rise associated with an arbitration case; a 3 per cent increase in superannuation; 5.26 per cent in shorter working hours; and 2.7 per cent in wage grants for opening up awards for structuring changes. Still to come is an increase of 12 per cent in the minimum rate, a 2 per cent training levy adjustment and a 3 per cent superannuation adjustment. That is an increase of 25 per cent on this particular company--
—You are declaring your pecuniary interests, are you?
—I have a minor shareholding, yes. If Senator Faulkner wants me to, I am certainly willing to do that. The employees of this particular company are under the storemen and packers awards.
—Self-interest, in other words.

—That is a very inept interjection, and I think it is unworthy of Senator Faulkner. I am going to a lot of trouble to point out where the oncosts are coming from and why small businesses are going broke. I thought it would behove Senator Faulkner to listen to what I was saying.
—Are you going to take that superannuation away?

—What I am trying to get through Senator McMullan's thick head, or the thick heads of the people over there, is that, whilst the Government may wish to give benefits to the workers, it cannot do so without getting productivity gains, and no productivity gains have been coming through. The corollary to that is a massive increase in bankruptcies caused by two policies: first, heavy interest rates have forced Australian businesses to pay up to 23 per cent; and, secondly, the oncosts of small businesses have been increased by the Government to a stage where small businesses have no capacity to pay them and, therefore, are going broke. We have seen a record number of bankruptcies in the last year-an increase of 17.6 per cent to 16,030 bankruptcies.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen superannuation increases, a 38-hour week, a training levy and also redundancy packages. The oncosts are the reason for the bankruptcies. I am not disputing that workers should have benefits, but I am disputing the fact that we cannot give workers benefits when the companies they work for go bankrupt. This is not in the interests of the worker, it is not in the interests of the economy, and it is not in the interests of the company.

Senator McMullan will know, because he is anything but unintelligent, that we cannot put the cost of business up 25 per cent and inflict a 23 per cent interest regime on manufacturers without getting horrific bankruptcy figures. You know that, and everyone on this side of the Parliament knows that, but you have been emasculated by the unions. You are not allowed to move.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell, would you address your remarks through the Chair?

—Sorry, Madam Acting Deputy President. Senator McMullan has been emasculated by the unions. The Treasurer is well aware of the problems facing the Australian business community and so is every intelligent person on that side of the House. Yet they are impotent, incapable of doing anything about it, because the Australian Council of Trade Unions will not allow any movement in the accord.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen, in the three months to May last year, 60,000 workers in the manufacturing sector alone lose their jobs. This 25 per cent increase in costs is not the end of the road. There is still additional superannuation and mark 6 wage increases. Minimum rate adjustment is expected to add another 15 per cent to labour costs for many industries over the next 12 months. This is why I say it is a matter of urgency to bring this to the attention of the Senate.

What is happening to Australia as small businesses close down? As we are closing our small business sector down, we are replacing its manufactured products with imports. So the Government's high interest rates policy has failed once again. It was designed to get imports down, but what it has effectively done is close down factories that manufactured Australian products, and those products that they manufactured are being replaced by imports.

We find that our current account deficit last year rose by $21.6 billion, which is up 19 per cent on the previous year. So that policy has failed. It has failed the workers. The high interest rate policy to dampen the economy down and cut imports has failed. It has driven imports up because it has closed our manufacturing sector down. That is why 60,000 workers were replaced in the manufacturing sector in the three months before last May. The Treasurer is reigning over a country that is going broke to the tune of $20 billion a year. Our net foreign debt has risen from $23 billion, when Labor came to office, to $124 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a half a billion.

—I am not going to have an argument with Senator Patterson over $500m. It is $124.5 billion, as Senator Patterson quite rightly points out, and that is a shocking indictment of the Treasurer and the Government's failed policies.
—But he engineered it.

—I know he engineered it. This man has the audacity to put himself forward as the leader of this nation. It is shocking that he had the cheek last Friday night to imply that he was leadership material.

SPEECH.PARA: It is now taking 30 per cent of our total external receipts to service our external debt, and that is the highest figure since the Depression. Senator Button has blamed the banks and small business for being uneducated and unqualified. Keating has blamed the banks. I hope Senator McMullan recognises the true problem and is man enough to admit where the problem lies. Unemployment has rocketed. In November, the unemployment rate was at 7.6 per cent-650,000 people unemployed. There were 455,300 people on the dole and youth unemployment was running at 20.3 per cent, the worst level for three years. I know Senator Harradine has taken a particular interest in this matter.

There are other economic indicators that clearly illustrate that the Government is well off its economic course. Dwelling approvals fell by 25 per cent in 1989-90 and they are still falling; they are about 12 per cent less than they were at this time last year. Registrations have fallen for three consecutive months. In August, September and October registrations fell by 2.8, 2.9 and 2.4 per cent. There are no indications of any recovery.

Under the stewardship of the Treasurer, we have been embarrassed in the eyes of the world. Our economic rating has been reduced from AAA to AA1 and then further reduced to AA2. Australia's rating has been downgraded and that has never happened to this nation before.

The Treasurer denied that we were in a recession and then he told us that it was a recession that we had to have. He said there has been short term pain, but there will be gain. I tell the Treasurer that 16,030 businesses have died painfully. Thousands and thousands of people have lost their jobs. There is plenty of pain out there, but there is no sign of any gain. I have never seen a worse situation. I was in business for 20 years before I came into this place and have kept in contact with business people. I have never seen it worse in the business sector. Companies that I have been associated with for years have laid off half their staff. Some companies are considering whether it would be worthwhile opening for trade after Christmas. I never saw that situation in the 1983 downturn or in the 1960s. I have never seen the economy worse than it is at the moment.

The promise of plenty of pain has been fulfilled, but I do not believe there is going to be much gain. If his past record has anything to do with it, the Treasurer, who offers himself for the leadership of this nation, should resign from the Parliament. He has made an apology to the Prime Minister. He has said he is sorry for what he said last Friday night. But he should go down on his hands and knees and beg forgiveness from all those people he has put out of business, the hundreds of thousands of people who have lost their jobs, and the hundreds of thousands of people who have lost their homes because of his policies that have driven this nation into the ground.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is necessary to acknowledge that there are a couple of redeeming features of this otherwise inadequate and unsatisfactory Opposition matter of public importance that Senator Boswell has put forward today. One is that it quite properly raises the significant question of the current state of the Australian economy, and that is an important matter to debate. The other feature, which is unique, coming from the other side of the chamber, is that it does at last make some recognition of the human consequences of changing economic circumstances. I think that is important and it must be acknowledged that it is so.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the matter of public importance and the speech which supported it failed totally as a constructive contribution to any debate about Australia's current economic circumstances. Firstly, it failed to meet the basic test of analysis of cause and effect. It reflected no understanding of the factors which have led to the current economic situation in Australia. Secondly, it failed totally to bridge that yawning chasm between talking about something important and saying something important. Senator Boswell spoke about a very important subject, but he said nothing of significance about it whatsoever.

Underpinning all this-although to his credit Senator Boswell could not bring himself to advocate them, and made no mention of them-are the economic proposals expounded by the Opposition and the relevant shadow Ministers, which fail totally to take into account the human and social consequences of the policies the Opposition is putting forward.

If Senator Boswell did not have any constructive contribution to make, why did he bring on this matter of public importance? I think this was summarised by Senator Button so eloquently in Question Time a few days ago when the question of the recession was finally confirmed by the statistics when they emerged. He described the Opposition as `buoyant with gloom'. That is exactly what we are confronted with again today-people delighting in the fact that they hope to get some political gain out of the economic adversity that Australians are suffering.

Why is it that we find no proper and constructive contributions? It is not so much a question of why there are none from Senator Boswell-people might have their own private theories about that-but why are there no constructive contributions from the Opposition overall? One of the fundamental reasons is that it fails to acknowledge-some members of the Opposition would understand this, although I do not know of any Opposition senators in this chamber who would-that the economy is much more complex than the simplistic solutions it likes to put forward.

The economy is influenced by a very complex array of international and local factors and there are many players in there influencing the outcome. It does not suit people who want to attribute all the blame to the Government to acknowledge that there are a large number of players and that internationally Australia is itself only a small player in the economic game. Within Australia even, the Federal Government is just one of the players in determining the economic consequences of decisions made. It is, of course, arguably the most important of those players, and I accept that. It has the capacity to create the climate in which investment decisions, savings decisions and consumption decisions are made; the totality of which determine the rate and direction of Australia's economic growth. But, in the main, the Government does not make those decisions itself; it merely creates the climate. That is in fact the point which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) would have been making at the meeting in Brisbane, and which Senator Boswell failed to understand.

Having put those background things behind us, let us look at how we came to be in the situation we are in now. Nobody would try to pretend that the economic situation in Australia on this date is in and of itself a desirable thing, because it is causing pain to individuals and everybody would prefer not to have that. I do not pretend that the Opposition would revel in the fact that individuals might be hurt. The Government does not; nor would any of the other parties here, if they understood it.

We need to look at the background. Australia has had six years of continuing record economic growth-much greater than the rate of growth of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries as a whole, particularly in the area of jobs where the rate of growth was twice that of the OECD as a whole. While it is true that unemployment is getting worse, and the social consequences of that are a cause of significant concern, if the participation rate of the work force were the same today as it was when this Government came to office in 1983, unemployment would be 3 per cent. It would have fallen from double digits to 3 per cent, and would have been less than 3 per cent last year. Due to six years of continuous growth, a lot more people have been attracted into the work force, and socially and economically it is very desirable that they should be.

However, it shows up in the statistics as a rate of unemployment somewhere comparable to that in the worst years of the conservatives, although nowhere near as bad, even without taking into account the participation rate. Even 18 months ago Australia was in a record boom situation with a high level of investment. That took place in the context of an economy still trying to come to grips with 30 years of structural deficiency, which structural deficiency has always meant that every post-war boom has caused a balance of payments crisis in Australia. Notwithstanding my point about some of the micro-economic reform changes already made, that took place again last year.

Another factor, which is too complex for me to go into much today but which needs to be taken into account, is that the consequences of the 1987 crash are still working their way through the economy. That has led to significant distortions in investment patterns and in the money supply. Those factors together led to the balance of payments problem with which Australia had to deal and because the supply side of that equation cannot be resolved immediately-increases in supply are slow and there are long leads-to get supply and demand in balance requires demand to be slowed down. The Opposition was not saying that the Government did not need to slow demand; it was saying that we probably were not slowing it enough. The Opposition may think there is a magic wand by which it can slow demand and nobody will be hurt. There is no such mechanism and everyone but Senator Boswell knows that lead times in increasing supply are very long.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you try increasing productivity?

—In fact I just made that point but Senator Boswell was not paying attention. There is no such mechanism. The Opposition supports a policy of reducing demand. Different mechanisms, to which I want to refer-- Senator O'Chee-But we don't believe in increasing on-costs at the same time.

—Ignorance is not an excuse, Senator O'Chee. There were economics involved in dealing with the slowing down of the economy. Let me divert briefly and talk about the one point Senator Boswell thought he was making; it was actually mumbo jumbo, but the little bit that was true came when he talked about the dramatic increase in on-costs and said that somehow there had been a 22 per cent increase. He did not understand that that was not a real increase but that, over and above inflation, it means about 16 per cent. There was no increase in wages in real terms. So somehow or other Senator Boswell found a 16 per cent real increase in costs at a time when the profit share is going up. I can tell the Senate that statistically that is impossible.
—You had better take it up with the CAI.
—The Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) knows it can be true for any one company but cannot be true for the economy as a whole. Everyone in this place but Senator Boswell understands that.
—You had better take it up with them because they say 22 per cent.
—Order! Senator Boswell, if you wish to interject could you sit in your seat?

—I do not mind Senator Boswell interjecting from there when he is wrong. I acknowledge that economic management is an imprecise art. Economists have a lovely throwaway phrase, `All other things being equal, X will be the outcome', but all other things are never equal. There were some factors that nobody could have put into the equation at the time of a slowdown and they are causing real hurt to individuals. There is no doubt about that. There have been dramatic falls in wool and wheat prices, regional problems in Australia-I refer particularly to Victoria-with a consequent decline in confidence, and uncertainty generated because of the Middle East conflict. Uncertainty is an immeasurable factor in economics which slows down people's preparedness to make investment decisions and to spend their money. It has the desirable effect of increasing savings, which is necessary, but the corollary of that is a slowdown of demand, which has economic conse- quences.

SPEECH.PARA: That slowdown has been greater than anyone would have wished. If there is a recession, it is causing pain. If this debate is designed to prove that, it is fruitless because everyone has acknowledged that. Nobody would pretend that pain is desirable, and it may be that people are in pain. I acknowledge that was inevitable, and the Opposition should acknowledge that there is no way to slow the economy without causing pain. The Opposition proposed to slow it; we proposed to slow it. The questions are: how far, how, and who bears the burden?

But I do not back away from the proposition that there needs to be gain for the pain, as has been said. There is no point in trying to colour the fact that there is pain. These policies do exact a price.

TALK.START.PARA: —When are we going to get the gain?

—That is exactly the point I am coming to. I thank the honourable senator for the question. The fact of the matter is that these policies are exacting a price, but they are the only mechanism which will get Australia towards a steady and sustainable growth path. Nobody in economics can pick the exact timing of the upturn with a great degree of accuracy.
—It is a bit flexible.

—If Senator Olsen thinks he can, he is only confirming his ignorance because nobody can. He can ask: what factors point to an upturn? There is no doubt that the factors that indicate that there will be an upturn in 1991 are clear and evident.
—Westpac didn't say that today.
—In fact, it did, if Senator Olsen understood it.
—No, they didn't.
—It argued about when in 1991.
—December 1991.

—What year is that? Senator Olsen is an ignoramus. The necessary policy decisions are there. Monetary policy has eased five times in 1990. As the tightening of monetary policy in 1989 has caused a slowing in 1990, so the easing of monetary policy in 1990 will cause a pick-up in 1991. There is no doubt about that; nobody argues about that. Evidence is starting to emerge that the first sign of activity will be a pick-up in dwelling investment. Financial institutions, the Housing Industry Association and others are starting to note that the first signs of that are emerging, but all too slowly.

SPEECH.PARA: We all wish that the process would be quicker, but it will not be quicker because of two factors: firstly, people are apprehensive because of those matters to do with uncertainty, which I mentioned; and, secondly, they are optimistic that there might be a further fall in interest rates so that they can make their investment decision under a lower interest rate regime. Two key preconditions for a further fall in interest rates are apparent-the key precondition being a lower rate of inflation, which means that we can keep the same real interest rate with lower absolute interest rates and deliver benefits to the people of Australia.

In addition, other obvious factors will lead to an economic upturn next year: firstly, increased consumption flowing from very substantial tax cuts implemented on 1 January; secondly, increased consumption flowing from the increase in wages that will follow later in the year in May; and, thirdly, increased consumption flowing from the reduction in interest rates and mortgages that people have to pay and the benefits flowing from that.

In addition, any analysis will show that the stock cycle is getting to a point where stocks are being run down. During 1991 the need to accumulate stocks will inevitably create a pick-up in demand for manufactured goods.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why they are putting in just in time.

—People still need stocks; there is still a stock cycle. If Senator Olsen does not understand that, he does not understand anything. These factors will lead to a pick-up in 1991. One of the reassuring things about this debate is that we never have to worry about those opposite that their new people in the Senate will lift the standard of their contribution to the economic debate. They have all shown that they either do not understand or choose not to understand.

SPEECH.PARA: Necessary conditions are emerging which show that in 1990-91 Australia can expect a pick-up in demand. I do not just assert that-in the Bulletin of this week, six economists talked about what they would do to fix the economy. Those economists were not selected by the Government, they were selected by David Barnett. It may be that he has recently changed his political spots and deliberately chose economists who would give a favourable analysis for the Labor Party, but I doubt it greatly. I will quote one economist in the time I have available.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only one was in favour of the Treasurer. That is why you are doing only one.

—No, the honourable senator is absolutely wrong, and he can quote any of the others he chooses in this debate. But I just quote Don Stammer, who is not-I do not think anybody would say-a member of the Australian Labor Party or a great Labor supporter but a very good economist and a respected economic commentator in Australia. He said that the most important thing the Government should do is stay with its present policies. He also said:

SPEECH.PARA: Looking ahead, it is most important to maintain the broad thrust of existing policies.
As I do not have time to quote all of it, inter alia, he said:
It is a very Australian attitude-
and, if I might interpolate, reflected by Senator Boswell today-

to extrapolate the low point of a business cycle and to miss the prospect of the next economic upswing. What the Government should do is maintain some of its existing policies unchanged, particularly the budget surplus, the tremendous boost to Australian savings through changes in superannuation, the ceiling on wage increases and the greater priorities within government spending on social security.
He went on to say:

Most of the big decisions on macro-economic reform have now been taken and Australia is further down the path of micro-economic reform than has been realised. What has to be done in the next couple of years-
and I agree with this-
is a further freeing up of the labour market. We are in a very frustrating gap between impact and results.
I think that is a correct and independent analysis, and one that people opposite do not like because it does not suit their prejudices.

I want to spend the couple of minutes that I have left speaking about the Opposition's prescription. One thing about conservatives around the world is that they can be relied upon for three things, and they come together as one element of their economic policies: first, they always propose to deal with unemployment by reducing jobs; secondly, they propose to deal with inflation by putting up prices; and the third factor in their traditional equation-which came out today from Senator Boswell-is that it is always the fault of the workers because they get too much. Those are the three factors that come together.

The way that the Opposition will solve unemployment is to tighten fiscal policy. What is the human cost of that policy? The Opposition will increase unemployment, reduce services and have less equity and social justice in our society. The Opposition will deal with inflation by introducing a consumption tax so that prices go up. However, the Opposition has no wages policy to cope with the consequences of those increasing prices. Australia will get back into the old cycle of boom and bust. The Opposition has absolutely no strategy for non-inflationary growth. All the international experience, which my colleague Senator Maguire will be able to expand upon, confirms the fact that the policies that conservatives everywhere are expounding have failed. There is more pain and less gain in what the Opposition is proposing.

An absolute responsibility of governments and parties that aspire to government is to acknowledge that sometimes there is a need to take hard decisions; that it is not simply a question of populist assertions, of putting together a loose collection of wish lists or outlining problems, and not taking the responsibility of proposing solutions. Public life imposes obligations on all of us to endeavour to be positive, constructive and analytical in dealing with the great public policy issues which we confront. We all at all times confront those policy issues; they change from time to time.

When inflation was a problem but the job situation was booming, the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, said how terrible inflation was and that the jobs we were creating were being created at too high a price. He said that anybody could create a lot of jobs but that we were paying too high a price for them. The biggest issue now is jobs, because suddenly the Opposition finds a different problem on which to batten its political hopes. We all have a responsibility to be positive, constructive and analytical in dealing with the great public policy issues. This matter of public importance and the speech which supported it totally fails that basic test of the public obligation of members of this Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before making my contribution, I want to respond to some of the comments made by Senator McMullan. I say at the outset that I-and I am sure my colleagues-am not buoyant that this country is in a recession. Like many of my colleagues, I have friends who have businesses and have family who have had businesses but who now no longer have them as a result of this Government's economic policies. So Senator McMullan should not stand up in this chamber or any other chamber and preach to the Opposition about the rights and wrongs of and what its attitude might be to the recession. We are seeing out in the community first-hand the impact of this Government's economic policies on individuals and people within this community. It would do him well to get out of Canberra, out of this fixed secure income town, into the cities of Australia and experience first-hand what most Australians are experiencing at the moment-desperation and no light at the end of the tunnel.

SPEECH.PARA: It was rather pedantic of Senator McMullan to say that he had misinterpreted Westpac; the upturn is coming next year. It might be December next year but that is still next year. We have gone from using financial years, 1 July to 30 June, to working on calendar years, 1 January to 31 December. The movable feast of this Government when it has difficulties is indicated by its moving the figures and criteria around to suit its case and its argument. We have a clear position in the community of quite serious consequences as a result of this Government's single monetary policy direction. The Government has certainly had its hands on the lever, but it has been only one lever-the high interest rate policy lever-over the course of the last three to four years. That is what has wrought havoc on the business community out there, particularly the small business community, which has not been able to insulate itself, protect itself, against those high interest rates policies.

The Government has not been prepared to put in place a series of policy directions-monetary policy, fiscal policy, privatisation and reform of the waterfront, to name but a few. Instead of having its hand on one lever which has brought about these consequences, over the last three to four years the Government should have been making a number of policy adjustments affecting a number of the levers so that the situation we have in Australia at the moment was not brought about.

What we are discussing here today is the plight of the forgotten people. There is plenty of talk of recession, redundancies, failing companies and poverty-all the result of this Government's lethal cocktail of high interest rates, tight fiscal policy and deliberate government policy. It is a recession that was engineered, that we had to have, and a pain that we have to go through. The newspapers, posters and headlines over the past few weeks have told of such recession stories as, `11,000 more to go by Christmas'; `A public service freeze'; `No jobs for school leavers'; `The unemployment we have to have'-and the list goes on. But what of the thousands of small businesses across Australia which have collapsed completely or have had to retrench most of their staff in the last couple of years? For them there are no glaring headlines of outrage and few stories of sympathy. It is the big companies and their problems which make the headlines, yet small business is this country's largest employer-a fact obviously forgotten by the Government and media.

There are an estimated 800,000 small businesses in this country. Small business accounts for some 96 per cent of all firms. It accounts for half of private sector employment. It accounts for approximately 30 per cent of gross domestic product. Most importantly, far more people from the small business sector than from any other sector have already been affected by this economic crisis. While the economic commentators have been discussing soft landings and hard landings, the small business community has already experienced a crash landing. But its trauma has been greeted with deafening silence.

The estimated couple of hundred small businesses which have been retrenching their two, three or four employees over recent months-a number which adds up to many more than big company retrenchments-just do not seem to rate. It seems as though the small business crisis, which has been ignored by government, has also been largely ignored by the media. It seems to me that there is an ingrained perception that the small business community cries poor but lives rich. There appears to be a media view that being poor for small business means trading down from a Mercedes to a Volvo. That perception is wrong, damaging and unfair. But that perception is so entrenched in media circles that the Government has been able to get away, somewhat successfully, with the attempted murder of an exceptionally vital component of the Australian economy. It is about time that the extent of that damage caused by the Keating policies to the small business community was given the coverage it deserves by the media and the concern it deserves from the Government. That way, the public of Australia may at least be able to see the full extent of Labor's attack on a group which earns its description as the engine-room of our economy.

The damage is not even hard to find; it is glaringly evident. In a walk along any suburban strip or through any shopping centre in our major cities we see empty shops and closing down sales. A stroll down the main street of any country town shows the same result. Some country areas of my State, South Australia, are so badly affected that even the local chemists have closed their doors.

The small business community in Australia today is in desperate shape. Bankruptcies have reached an all-time high of 2,767 for the September quarter, up almost 700 on the same quarter last year. That is the tip of the iceberg. The next quarter will be the quarter in which we will see bankruptcies simply skyrocket. Many people are seeking to last until Christmas and then will be making a judgment over Christmas as to whether, in January, they even open their doors or what staff will continue after the Christmas holiday period. The effect of that, of course, is escalating unemployment within the community.

Yet the Government's tired old line is that this crisis is a point in the economic cycle. Senator Button referred to it today. It is almost the inevitable. You have to go through this every couple of years. What is so unusual about it? That is the perception this Government is trying to paint at the moment: we are having a recession, but should we not be having a recession as part of the economic cycle?

TALK.START.PARA: —They can't manage and they don't care.

—Exactly. The Government has no answers to the problem because it is not prepared to identify those other areas that need to be put in place. It is heartless and it is an ignorant commentary on the Government. It is inexcusable from a government which has created the problem.
—What are they?

—I can well remember Senator Crowley's Government opposing privatisation forcefully and vigorously but five years ago. Had the Government five years ago put in place a privatisation policy as well as its tight monetary policy, had another look at its fiscal policy, started reform on the waterfront and investigated oncosts for shipping our products overseas and around the States of Australia, it might not be in the position it is today.

SPEECH.PARA: Had the Government backed Paul Keating, put in a broad based consumption tax, which he wanted to do four or five years ago, and reformed the taxation system of this country and got rid of the wholesale sales tax system, which is a nightmare for small business and a nightmare for manufacturers trying to compete against imports from overseas when we do not have the basis to compete fairly and objectively and cannot enable those small business manufacturers to compete in the international marketplace, we might just have spared the small business community the havoc it is going through today, the pain it is going through today and the bankruptcies that are being inflicted upon it. We might have spared the families that are suffering enormously today, not to mention the thousands who are going to join the unemployment queue through no fault of their own but through the fault of Mr Keating and Labor's economic policies.

It is all the Government's own work. It cannot, as Senator McMullan said today, blame international influences for this downturn in the Australian economy. The Government has been in power for nearly eight years now; this is all its own work. It is the economic policies that the Government has put in place that have had this impact on the Australian community. What concerns me is that members of the Government seem to have no comprehension of what that impact is.

It is all very well to say that this is part of the cycle, that we are going through a little pain, we will get the gain later. When we pose the question `When is the gain going to come?', that is like asking how long a piece of string is? It will depend upon the circumstances at the time; maybe next year or the year after. I have news for the Government. There are many businesses out there that cannot wait until next year, let alone the number of people who are depending on those small businesses for their jobs.

What we are seeing is clearly a position where the Government, disturbingly so, continues to peddle a line which ridicules and denigrates the thousands of small business people whose businesses have failed through no fault of their own. It is typical that this Government has the gall to try to get away with the inference that small business has caused its own problems. It has not. Small business is the unfortunate meat in the sandwich and it has ended up being minced. It is caught between the damaging policies of both State and Federal governments. State charges such as power and land tax have increasingly crippled the small business sector in recent years. Senator Crowley would have seen that clearly in South Australia, with a massive hike of 18 per cent in taxes and charges in that State alone this year. This Government's economic policies and changes to the company tax system have been nails in the small business coffin.

In a recent small business survey, 40 per cent of small businesses indicated that they had experienced a downturn in sales of 15 per cent or more compared with 1988-89 levels. Not their fault; no, it is Mr Keating's fault. It does not take an economic genius to realise that this downturn could be sufficient, subject to their level of borrowings and profit margins, to cause financial failure. In the same survey, almost 50 per cent of small businesses reported an increase in bad debts and 11 per cent are experiencing an increase of 100 per cent or more in bad debts. Not their fault, not the fault of small business; no, it is Mr Keating's fault.

Business is well down; bad debts are well up. Some 75 per cent of small businesses also indicated they would be using borrowed funds, with the average interest rate at 18.75 per cent. Many more were paying some 24 or 25 per cent on their business loans. Not their fault; no, Mr Keating's fault-a direct impact of this Government's policies.

Small businesses report that they are being bled dry, with a vastly decreased cash flow, and the high interest rates on the borrowings necessary to stay afloat in the short term are destroying them in the long term. To make matters worse, over 50 per cent of small businesses report they will have to borrow more funds to meet the 15 December deadline to pay company tax. Seventy-five per cent of small businesses report that the Government's insistence on their paying 85 per cent of the due tax by this month will cause them critical cash flow problems. That is why they are waiting to get through to Christmas and will then make a judgment as to whether their liquidity will allow them even to reopen their doors in January next year.

This Government does not seem to care about that plight and that problem. It also appears little understood that, far from the popular myth of driving home in a Mercedes to a mansion, most small business proprietors go home on a Friday-if they are lucky-with less money in their pocket than their workers because they are chasing an increasingly scarce consumer dollar. There is little left for them to take home when, added to the high interest rates, there are obligatory wage rises for staff, superannuation increases and changes to working hours, not to mention the problems for the 64 per cent who reported increasing costs in Workcare and Workcover. In other words, small business is being squeezed at every turn.

After the Beddall report, the Government said it would proceed to implement a range of recommendations. What did we see this year in the Budget implementing the Beddall report? There was only one recommendation picked up in the Budget. The Government's response to the Beddall report is peppered with comments to the effect that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) will have continuing discussions on this important point.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose this matter of public importance brought into the chamber by Senator Boswell and the Opposition today. I find it interesting that my remarks follow those of Senator Olsen who, when asked by me across the chamber, actually ran out a litany of things that might have been better done if the Opposition had been in power. I presume that if the Opposition had been in power it would have done these things. It would be very interesting to see whether or not Senator Olsen speaks for the Opposition when he lists a number of those things, because already we have had from Senator McMullan a clear indication that the Opposition would not do those things when it had the chance to tackle some of them, for example, undertake a small amount of fiscal restraint. Dr Hewson, the Leader of the Opposition, was unable to hold his troops to that.

SPEECH.PARA: How is the Opposition going to manage its fiscal policy when it is in government if it cannot manage it when it is in opposition? I would not like to see the Opposition's chances when it is in government. I presume that when the honourable senator talks about fiscal policy he means to tighten it.
