He has, as a member of the Opposition, claimed on a number of occasions that the Opposition will cut $3 billion-sometimes the bid is only $2 billion-off expenditure, but he has never said where he will cut and he has never given any evidence that he means it seriously. When the Opposition had its first chance to do it in the recent case of the assets test, Dr Hewson was unable to hold the Opposition to its policy. The Opposition went to water on the one chance that it had. How is it planning to do it? Does the Opposition mean it seriously and when, if ever, will the Opposition come in here and tell us what it means by fiscal policy and, indeed, where it will make its cuts?

The Opposition has talked about one example-that is, that after nine months people who are unemployed will get no further dole assistance. That will go down very well with people who are going onto unemployment benefit! Is Senator Olsen really serious about fiscal policy? He comes in here and says that, if the Government changed fiscal policy in the way that the Opposition would like to change it, it would make a difference. The Opposition could not do it in the example of the assets test. But in an area where the Opposition has said it would do anything-one of the few examples it has given us-it has said that it would cut the unemployment benefit after nine months. That is a very persuasive policy indeed; I am sure that will go down very well with those people out there who the Opposition is saying are in pain. What is the Opposition going to say? Will it say, `The pain under us will be worse because you won't even get unemployment benefits'? I say to Senator Olsen that that is a very persuasive policy. It should go down very well with the people out there.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about privatisation? Have a go at that.

—I am so pleased that you mentioned privatisation, because who is going to privatise welfare? It is you. Of all the interesting questions you put to me, you want to privatise welfare. You want the St John's--
—I would ask the honourable senator to direct her remarks through the Chair.

— Senator Olsen asks, `What about privatisation?'. I am prepared to say to him, `What about it, indeed?'. He is from the Party that wants to privatise welfare-what little bit it is going to leave, it is apparently going to give out to charitable organisations around this country and ask them to do the Government's work. There is not one welfare organisation in the community-according to any of the quotes, which I do not have with me today, of spokespeople representing the welfare organisations-which would support that privatisation. They say that it would allow for piecemeal application of benefits, it would allow for inequities, they would not have sufficient infrastructure to provide anything like a reasonable assessment and, of course, it carries the implication that those organisations would then become assessors of a person's worth-precisely the sort of problem that none of those organisations wants to get into. They do not have the capacity to address that problem; they do not want to address it. It is being addressed better and better by this Government which, over seven years, has actually lowered expenditure through the Department of Social Security while increasing every payment because of its targeting, its fiscal responsibility and its restraint. Because it has actually required tougher justifications for people making claims this Government has been able to lower expenditure under social security and at the same time increase payments to those people who are deserving of them.

SPEECH.PARA: This Opposition says that we should be aware of the pain we are going to cause people out there. But this Opposition says, `Give them to us; we'd make the pain worse. We'd deny them unemployment benefits and, yes, privatisation will follow. We will privatise the welfare system to make the assistance for unemployed people even worse'. They are very persuasive policies. If Senator Olsen wants to stand on the back of a truck anywhere in Adelaide and run with them I will stand up there with him because I do not think they are persuasive at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —On privatisation, any day. I would go to Trades Hall on privatisation.

— Privatisation of welfare is a hoot. Senator Olsen has asked me a very good question. His question is remarkable. The honourable senator is also a member of an Opposition that contradicts itself any time it can, moving from one sort of policy to another. As Mr Keating has said in the other place, the Opposition Leader is opportunist. He does not argue a consistent line; he has not gone on the record for what his Party's policies-fiscal, monetary or economic-will be. What he is doing-and what the honourable senator is doing in this place-is running with a cheap debating point without actually getting to the crux of the matter. The Government's position has been very well spelt out in this debate by Senator McMullan.
—And by you, Senator Crowley.
—I thank Senator Faulkner. I will not disagree with that assessment.
—It's pretty rough when the only support you get is from your own side these days.

—I certainly think that is an improvement on getting none, and Senator Olsen was not getting much at all. The Government's position has been spelt out. As Senator McMullan said, the Government has actually had to deal with this difficult, tough decision at this time and, yes, there is pain. Of course, nobody wants it and we wish that it did not have to happen; but there is a light at the end of the tunnel. If Senator Olsen wants to argue about the December 1991 date instead of the June 1991 date, that is undoubtedly up to him. But, for the record, it is the year 1991 and people do understand it. Even Westpac Banking Corporation assesses that there will be an improvement in conditions, and the figures already show some encouraging signs of turnabout.

SPEECH.PARA: We should also note that while this Government has been in office it has appreciated the importance of looking after our young people. In this place last week I highlighted the record of this Government and its alternative policies, which were called gimmicks by the Opposition. Can I presume from that that the Opposition is intending to do away with all of those policies when, if ever, it gets into office? We have put in place things that we do not call gimmicks, such as an increased education encouragement for people to stay at school until year 12, turning those figures around from about a 37 per cent retention rate to well over a 60 per cent retention rate. The Opposition said that that was just one way of reducing unemployment. You betcha, Mr Deputy President, and what better way of doing it than having young people not unemployed, not looking for insufficient jobs, but staying at school right through to year 12, with the prospects of tertiary training-whether that is by way of apprenticeships, in colleges or universities? Of course that is an improvement.

We are not afraid or ashamed of saying that one of the things we did-not as an unemployment policy, but as a direct policy to tap the talents of our young people-was to encourage them to stay at school. We have done that. We have presided over two dramatic increases in the number of places and facilities in universities and colleges so that, having completed year 12, young people can then proceed into tertiary education of their preferred choice.

We have also implemented traineeship programs. Bridging courses have been put in place to assist those people who are without the benefit of year 12 education or those people who have made a choice not to take that path and who then find themselves struggling to get into employment or to get back into the work force if they have been out of it for any length of time-either by choice, to raise families, or by lack of choice, because of unemployment. Those facilities remain. That commitment by government is still there and that will certainly soften the blow for those people who have to endure a period of unemployment.

We also must appreciate that we have had a massive period of growth with a very high participation rate in the years that this Government has been in office. As Senator McMullan said, if that participation rate was the same now as it was in 1982-83, unemployment would be at 3 per cent. So, yes, we recognise that those figures are higher but we also acknowledge why they are higher. They are at that level because of this Government's commitment to employment creation.

Senator Olsen, who is leaving the chamber, would not want me to acknowledge that the Government does appreciate where the jobs are. The jobs are created in the private sector. Its policies have been designed to encourage that. It got out of the community employment program creation scheme, which was put in place as a buffer once it came into office, and allowed the private sector to take up those jobs. The private sector has done that. There are bankruptcies-no-one can deny that-but, as Senator Button said, they are part of an ongoing pattern of bankruptcies. We regret that, but we also appreciate that the private sector is where the jobs are. Some 90 per cent of jobs are in the private sector; the Government knows that, recognises that and supports that. Its policies to this point have been designed to encourage the creation of those jobs.

I think a small point of caution for the Opposition in all of this is that, in referring to the number of bankruptcies, it makes no distinction between one sort of bankruptcy and another. Any number of senators, if they were honest, could stand up in this place and talk about the way people now exercise their right to go bankrupt as a way out of debt. I urge Opposition senators, if they are not prepared to accept those figures through the bankruptcy courts, to check out what is happening in the Family Court. On a number of occasions people have chosen the path of bankruptcy rather than staying in there and fighting.

I am not suggesting that all the people going bankrupt are in that situation, but there are a number of stories of that sort. I think we have to urge caution about the nature of the bankruptcies and the number of people who are out of employment because of it. I use none of that as an excuse for denying those figures. Yes, we have those figures, but I urge a caution about their size and the unemployment that is associated with them. As far as I know, we do not have a sufficient breakdown of the types of bankruptcies, the number of dollars involved per bankruptcy or the number of people who are unemployed per bankruptcy. They will differ from place to place.

To actually find that we are talking about bankruptcies and then hear Senator Boswell say that we should also consider the Fairfaxes, for example, in that kind of category, I think is laughable. As Senator McMullan said, who is responsible? At what stage are the decisions of business people their own responsibility? As Senator McMullan said, the Government sets the economic climate in which business takes the decisions; it is going to make those decisions. Certainly the climate is one of interest rates that have been high to this point but they are now clearly falling and have been falling for the last six to 12 months.

We do not deny that those conditions do create an unfavourable climate for business. In fact, the Treasurer has made it quite clear that some of the decisions which needed to be taken have caused short term pain but in the long term they will lead to falling interest rates and inflation. Hopefully, those things will set in place an opportunity to reduce the swings-or the cycles, which seems to be the word in vogue at the moment. But there is no way we can take all the responsibility away from business and put it on government. Some of those decisions are made by business people; they are making them not only in this climate but also in terms of their own personal preferment.

I do not believe that the Opposition, in lumping all bankruptcies together, is giving us a proper understanding of the decisions that people are making in this area. What we have to choose between is a government which set in place a commitment to its young people, a commitment to people who have been unemployed, and a commitment to assist unemployed people back into the work force through structured career counselling, particular job training and traineeships, against an opposition that, as much as we can understand of its fiscal policies, would cut out those things altogether.

We have a government that has put in place a commitment to helping people who are unemployed by urging them and assisting them, through those job creation schemes associated with welfare, through social security, to get back into the work force. We have it from the Opposition that, first, it would cut out unemployment benefit after nine months and, secondly, that it would privatise welfare.

Senator Olsen made a number of suggestions concerning monetary policy, fiscal policy, oncosts and waterfront arrangements, none of which he spelt out because the Opposition cannot. He also suggested that a consumption tax would be the way to go-if only Mr Keating had done that years ago. But, as Senator McMullan argued, the consumption tax way is a very interesting and direct way of increasing inflation-precisely what the Opposition says is causing trouble for small business at the moment. Does it want inflation going up or does it want it coming down?

Our policies which are in place at the moment are seeing a fall in inflation, with predictions that the rate will continue to fall slowly over the next 12 months. The Opposition argues for a consumption tax, which has a direct inflationary effect. How does the Opposition get these two things together in the back of its head? I do not see anything from the Opposition that would encourage those people who are hurting to appreciate that the Opposition has anything better to offer. The Government has put its programs in place. It will continue to provide support to help those people who do, from time to time, have to suffer some pain, but I would not chance my arm with the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Senate that we are debating a matter of public importance which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer's inept engineering of the Australian economy that has resulted in business and personal bankruptcies soaring to 16,030 an increase over the last financial year of 17.6%.

So far Senator Crowley and others have suggested that we ought to look carefully at those figures because they may not be real. Of course, people are either bankrupt or they are not bankrupt. The truth of the matter is that Australia is looking starkly at the reality of seven years of Labor Government. No longer do we have the rhetoric, the promises, the broken promises or the false dawns; we have the reality of a recession which is perhaps the worst since that of the 1930s. Certainly it is worse than the 1982-83 recession and as bad as we have had since the Second World War. This is all the result of the deliberate and conscious decisions made by the Treasurer, Paul Keating; the Prime Minister, Bob Hawke; and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), led by Kelty. This nation is now plunged into recession as a result of their endeavours. This is the recession that the Treasurer promised we would never have. He said that we would not have a recession. On 22 March of this year he said:
We won't let there be a recession.
He did not say that some years ago; he said it earlier this year. He also said:
. . . high interest rates are behind us.
He went on to say:
We don't have high interest rates now.
Time after time he promised that we would be in for the good life. In 1987, he said:
If you look at Australia in a few year's time . . . you're going to see the Australian economy emerge as one of the most successful and balanced economies in the world.
Again in 1987, in May, he said:
The Government has not sat idly by and watched the nation's living standards decline. Instead we have acted decisively to turn the situation around. Tonight I can report that Australia is winning.
In the May 1988 economic statement, he said:
The measures I have just outlined represent another milestone in the transformation of the Australian economy and another chapter in the proud economic history of this Government.
In the Budget of 23 August 1988, he said:
This is the one which brings home the bacon.
In the same Budget Speech, he said:
The Government's policies will secure for Australia an inflation rate of 3 to 4 per cent . . .
On 24 August 1988, the night after the Budget Speech, he said:
We are now well on our way back to prosperity.
In his economic statement of April 1989, he said:
That is why . . . Labor not only claims a superior economic strategy and performance-it has proved it.

That is the history of the promises of this Government. We all know that with this Treasurer we have seen style and no substance. We have seen the world's greatest Treasurer with plenty of panache, plenty of front, plenty of brass, plenty of cheek, plenty of rhetoric, and plenty of self-congratulations. But when it comes to the hard reality of the results of his endeavour, what do we see? The recession we are now having visited upon us. He was always good at making excuses. I am reminded of the occasions when we had that continuing deficit-the monthly deficit-where, month after month in Australia, we went into further debt, and Paul Keating would say:
These numbers today, large as they are, are still reflecting conditions which were obtaining in January and February when the whole fever of demand was running at its highest.
The month before, when asked to explain the figures, he said:
. . . but there is a pipeline, obviously, quite a long pipeline from imports ordered six and nine months ago.
When the Treasurer was asked to explain the previous month's balance of trade deficit, he said:
This month's current account figure reflects conditions in the economy six to nine months ago. Policy has already been adjusted to deal with that condition.

In January, again trying to explain away another disastrous figure-what the Treasurer describes, of course, as a beautiful number-for another month when Australia went $1.5 billion into debt, his comment was:

This January number again reflects some substantial history; that is, a lot of the decisions which would have been taken in ordering equipment, which is now appearing on our docks and did appear in the month of January, would have been taken a year, nine months, perhaps 15 months ago.

Every single month we are living with the history of previous decisions, according to Mr Keating. Of course, the reality is that it has now all caught up with him. Everybody else in Australia has known for six, eight or nine months that we have been in recession. The only person who did not know was the man in the pinstripe Italian suits who travels to the football in a VIP aircraft. Everybody else knew the reality of the economic environment.

First of all, we had the J-curve and then we had lag, the effervescence effect, the pipeline effect-it is all effects with this man. What is the reality? A recession-and all of his own doing, all his own work. If it were not for the fact that we have had very favourable terms of trade, the annual deficit would be running at around $27.5 billion. Instead of us going into debt by about $17.5 billion, we would be going in at about $27 billion, if it were not for the fact that up until this point the value of our export commodities has risen most significantly.

Now we are in recession, what is the solution of this Government? It is screw the workers, screw small business, screw the economy; hurt everybody who ought to be a productive citizen in this community. The Government has one solution, one macro-economic lever to hang on to, that is, high interest rates, a tight monetary policy-which has had what effect? It has had the effect of driving this country into recession. It has barely constrained imports in relation to exports, nor has it helped to stimulate local production. It certainly has not made us competitive with our exports-and that is for a very good reason: the moment interest rates go up, the exchange rate is driven up; and the moment the exchange rate is driven up, imports are made cheaper and exports are made more expensive. So the perverse effect of Mr Keating's high interest rate policy is not to throttle off imports but simply to encourage them by making them more competitive.

If that is not sin enough, it has had the final effect of throttling off any capacity of local manufacturers, local producers, to invest in new plant and equipment to make themselves more effective, more efficient and more competitive because they have not been able to afford 22 per cent or, if they are buying second-hand equipment, as many are, because they cannot afford to borrow money at 24 per cent. That is the one instrument he has had, which has had the effect of driving us into a recession.

We are told that the one great virtue of all this hot money rushing into this country, jacking up the exchange rate and destroying our farmers and our exporters is that it has gone into capital equipment; that we are restocking; and the capital base has developed in aggregate terms so that we are now on the verge of an export explosion. That is absolute rubbish. The Treasurer says:
At the same time, the historically high rate of business investment of the past two years is finally providing us with the capacity to trade our way out of our troubles.

That is from the Budget Speech of 21 August 1990, just a few months ago. What he is telling us is that all this hot money coming in is setting us on the edge for an explosion in exports. It is fundamentally untrue, like most other things that drop from his lips. The truth of the matter is that private investment in this country has not increased. It has increased perhaps slightly since the early 1980s but there has been no significant increase whatsoever in capital equipment investment.

As a result of that, we are not on the edge of anything. We are not in any way likely to have a capacity to improve our exports in terms of our competition. In 1985-86, the percentage of gross domestic product (GDP) in buildings and structures, plant and equipment was 3.5 per cent and it went up to 4.4 per cent in 1988-89. Unfortunately, time prevents me from going through all the figures, but very clearly we are not on the edge of an export boom at all.
The one person who knows all about that, if I can find his beautiful quotes, is Senator Walsh, the ex-Minister for Finance. He says:
For three quarters, plant and equipment investment has been falling. High investment in CBD-
central business district-

office blocks et al will not service foreign debts . . . Australia has resorted to inducing a domestic recession to deal (temporarily) with a balance of payments problem . . . We are living on Japanese savings and we are sending the bill for that to the next generation of Australians . . . We are, in my view, in a fundamentally worse economic position than we were in 1986.

Whose words of wisdom were they? They were the words of Senator Peter Walsh. The only thing is that Senator Walsh waited until he was scampering out of the Cabinet to say that, when he could no longer, even with his shred of integrity, live with the lack of integrity of this Government. They are his contributions to this Government.

Where are we now in terms of our bankruptcies? As Senator Boswell demonstrated in a very articulate way, they have risen dramatically over the last quarter. Unemployment has risen dramatically. Unemployment now numbers 650,000 people-650,000 Australians cannot, for the life of them, find a job because of this Government-not because of a downturn in terms of trade, not because of a world recession, not because of external factors, but simply because this Government has thrown them on the unemployment scrap heap.

Let us look at the levels of company profits, which are always an excellent indicator and which are one of the things that Keating used to be so proud of in the early 1980s, when he let the money supply run crazy and when profits were up. What are they now? For quarter on quarter they have gone from $4.9 billion to $3.3 billion. The largest declines in profitability are in manufacturing and retail-they are both down about 36 per cent-manufacturing being the area that the Treasurer claims is attracting the investment which will give us an export explosion.

We have only 15 minutes to speak in these circumstances. Therefore, one is unable to detail with any care the full litany of disasters this Government has visited upon us. The truth of the matter is that in the near future interest rates will come down again because this Government will drive them down and, as a result of that, one will see an expansion in demand. As a result of the expansion in demand, we will see inflation again, and we will go through this whole inflated cycle that we are presently experiencing because there is no structural adjustment and there are no fundamental changes in the economy that are going to make anything different next time-not a thing-because of the rigidity and the fixed, straightjacketed approach of the trade union movement, which controls and manipulates the Treasurer and the Prime Minister.

While the Government has deregulated the financial sector, it has not deregulated the labour sector. There are no consequential reforms in coastal shipping, waterfront, communications or transportation-any of the fundamental areas. So we can expect much of the same, and next year is going to be a great deal worse than this year. Anybody who says otherwise would be telling lies, and I will regret it if I hear the Prime Minister or the Treasurer again tell the people of Australia that they can look forward to a happy new year, because the truth of the matter is that they cannot.

We now have Keating having the outrage and the gall to call upon Australians to dare to be great. He very much reminds me of an Italian chocolata: he is superficially attractive but he quickly makes one unwell; he melts under the slightest heat, goes sticky-drippy and goes to water. That is what he did last night when the Prime Minister called him in and had words with him about his outrageous comments to the press, when he thought that he could get away with it and he would have the media running out there and selling him as the next Prime Minister. It is absolutely outrageous. History will show that this Government, of all governments, has been the greatest failure since Federation. The sooner it is ignominiously dumped out and a capable and responsible government of the Liberal Party and the National Party is elected, the sooner we will see a recovery in the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator POWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take only a few minutes of the Senate's time this afternoon. In fact, the Australian Democrats were rather staggered that the Opposition brought this debate on today because we have probably something like 50 Bills yet to deal with in seven more days of sitting and we have been treated in the past couple of weeks in particular to longwinded Opposition talkfests, mainly dealing with head kicking and obstructionism and delaying the progress of legislation. We see this as a further mischief. Nevertheless, we will take a few minutes to outline our response on behalf of the Democrats to the matter brought forward by Senator Boswell today, which is:

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer's inept engineering of the Australian economy that has resulted in business and personal bankruptcies soaring to 16,030 an increase over the last financial year of 17.6%.

From our point of view the strategy of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is based on two aspects: firstly, an ideological commitment to deregulation and privatisation leading to the private sector irresponsibility which we have seen; and, secondly, unrestrained borrowing overseas, which has been a major factor in blowing out our foreign debt.
Mr Ian Campbell, the Chief Economist of the Australian Mutual Provident Society, in the economic notes for the September quarter in 1990, said:
. . . deregulation and exposure to market competition, which have been confidently put forward as the answers to economic mismanagement, don't seem to be leading us to utopia either.

A master understatement, I would suggest. The second plank of the Treasurer's strategy is, of course, high interest rates to choke off demand for imports-a single strand strategy using a blunt instrument, which is counterproductive. In part, high interest rates are responsible for the high exchange rate, making it more difficult for Australian primary producers and manufacturers to compete against the rest of the world. The Treasurer has been only too successful in one way-we are in a recession. That is admitted. We are harvesting the cost in human terms.

The Smith Family has reported that in the last four months there has been a 40 per cent increase in emergency relief requests. The Brotherhood of St Laurence has documented that currently we still have 310,000 children living in absolute poverty. In the past few days many of our daily newspapers have outlined that our relief agencies in the community are distressed that they are unable to meet the requirements of the growing numbers of poor families for the Christmas season. Nevertheless, foreign debt, which this is all supposed to tackle, is continuing to rise.

On 5 November, the Melbourne Age reported that the current net outflow of interest is $11.9 billion per annum-in other words, $700 per head of population for every woman, man and child. There is another measure for that. It is 20 per cent of export income, and at the level of 25 per cent international bankers start cutting off credit.

In October 1989 unemployment figures reached 457,400. That figure rose to 569,300 in July and to 607,700 in October. We are staring down the barrel at one million Australians unemployed. The Government should tell us its predictions for unemployment, given that the Budget estimate has already been exceeded. There is no doubt that the Budget estimate of 2 per cent growth in gross domestic product for 1990-91 has been discredited already.

There is an alternative to the Treasurer's disastrous economic policy. It has been identified in the Australian Democrats alternative Budget. I will list just a few major points from that alternative Budget: an increase in revenue by plugging tax avoidance loopholes-we have identified 22 measures totalling $2.6 billion in lost revenue; higher indirect taxes on luxury goods, including tobacco and alcohol, would be another important measure; support for export industries-for example, accelerated depreciation allowance for export projects; increased withholding tax and removal of exemptions on interest paid to overseas lenders to discourage overseas borrowing and to bring the dollar down; and higher expenditure on research and development. These are just some examples of the way a more interventionist approach would work-accepting responsibility for the economy and making it serve the people instead of the people having to serve the ideological market forces economy put forward by the Government.

There is no comfort on the other side of politics in bringing forward this matter of public importance today. The conservative Opposition offers only more and faster deregulation, full privatisation and even-as Senator Crowley has said-welfare. It offers a consumption tax to hit the poor and low income families, simply because they are not prepared to chase the real tax cheats and avoiders and offers at least $2 billion more in cuts to government spending on social infrastructure.

I simply want to put down the bare bones of our response to the matter of public importance brought forward by the Opposition. We have no brief for the Government's economic policy or for the alternative put forward by the Opposition. We commend to the chamber and to the community the alternative Budget of the Australian Democrats, which we are prepared to send to anybody who wants it. Our view has been outlined in more detail several times in this chamber by our economic spokesperson, Senator Spindler. I refer to the appropriations debate on 8 November and a debate on a matter of public importance on 29 November. On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I will not delay the Senate further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon Senator Boswell, as Leader of the National Party of Australia, has brought forward a matter of public importance in the Senate condemning the Government on the handling of the economy. I say, on behalf of those on this side of the House, that we are concerned by the position in the economy; we are concerned by the rise in the number of people out of work; we are concerned by the difficulties some small businesses are facing in our community; and we certainly are concerned about the problems faced by our agricultural sectors as a result of the trade practices of overseas blocs, such as the European Community, by subsidising exports in our traditional markets.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that members of the Liberal Party and the National Party should stop trying to talk and knock down the economy and, above all, they should stop promoting doom and gloom in the Australian community. They are basically going around talking down the economy and promoting doom and gloom. This matter of public importance today is yet another example of the practice of conservative politicians going around talking down the economic situation and promoting doom and gloom in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what Paul Keating is doing.

—When we look at their record in office we see that they cannot preach to us. In 1982 and 1983 they drove the Australian economy through the floor; they drove it into the ground. I will cite one figure this afternoon-that of price rises, the inflation rate as measured by the consumer price index.

SPEECH.PARA: When I came into this Parliament in March 1983 the annual inflation rate under Mr Howard and the Liberals was 11 1/2 per cent. We had double digit price rises under the conservative government, which was thrown out in March 1983. I remember that well. Today we do not have 11 1/2 per cent inflation; we do not have 10 per cent inflation; we certainly do not have 9 per cent inflation; and we do not have 7 per cent or 8 per cent inflation. Under this Administration the price rises are going up at only 6 per cent per annum. In effect, price increases have almost been halved under this Government. The consumer price index is well down on what it was under the Liberals.

When we look at the underlying rates of inflation, the broader based measures of inflation that relate to overall activity in the community, we see that they are growing at 5.2 per cent, effectively halving the inflation rate under the Liberals. The rise in the consumer price index for the September quarter-July, August and September-is 0.7 per cent.

The Liberal Party leaders were going around the community, talking up the inflation rate, saying it was going to be 1.5, 1.7 or 1.9 per cent, and it came in at 0.7 of a per cent-the lowest quarterly inflation rate for about two decades. We have a tremendous reduction in the rate of inflation.

Let us turn to interest rates. There have been five rounds of cuts in official cash rates this year. There has been a five percentage points reduction in interest rates this year in the Australian community. Interest rates are not at their peak; they are now 5 per cent below what they were in January. When we look at the prime lending rates, the indicator rates, charged by the Australian trading banks on their large overdrafts, we see that in January this year they were 20.5 per cent. In October, they had fallen to 17 per cent. So in that space of 10 months, there had been a 3.5 percentage point reduction in the prime lending rates of the Australian trading banks. Those rates helped lower the cost of finance; they reduced the cost of interest to borrowers; and in the future they will certainly help finance extra investment spending.

I turn to the exchange rate, the rate between the Australian dollar and foreign currencies, particularly the rate between the Australian dollar and the American dollar. Earlier this year, $A1 was the equivalent of US83c. That was too high; it was hurting our exporters and making imports cheap. Yesterday we were able to have the dollar reduced in value to US77c-it has come down by about US6c-which is making imports more expensive in Australia and helping to close the import gap. It means that people in the export sectors are getting more Australian dollar proceeds from their sales overseas. Exchange rates are helping Australia get a competitive edge, and that is being fuelled by the continued fall in inflation in the Australian community. The three fundamental variables in the Australian economy-prices, interest rates and the exchange rate, the value of the Australian dollar-are all trending in the right direction. These three fundamental variables are all moving to correct the situation in the Australian economy. All of them will help Australian firms to be more competitive.

It is interesting to note that in the last 12 months imports have fallen in real terms. After allowing for changes in value, the actual quantities of imports have fallen by 2.3 per cent in the last 12 months. Exports-Australian products sent overseas-despite this recession which those opposite are talking about--

TALK.START.PARA: —No, you are talking about it. You engineered it.
—Shut up.
—Exports have grown over 8 per cent in the last 12 months. There has been a tremendous turnaround in our trading position. There has been an absolute reduction in imports of 2.3 per cent--
—Tell him about the level of foreign debt.
—Shut up.
—Order! Senator Kemp, would you please cease interjecting.
—But there has been an 8 per cent growth, almost a one-twelfth increase--

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I am getting somewhat tired of this Government and the foul language of its members. Senator Bolkus has now interjected twice to ask Senator Kemp to shut up. How much more bad language are we going to have to put up with from this Government after the outbursts of Senator Gareth Evans, Senator Cook yesterday and the outburst of Senator Collins the week before? I ask that Senator Bolkus be brought back into line. He is a Minister of the Crown and surely he can start to behave as one.
—Yes, Senator Knowles, I take your point of order. I do think, Minister, that `shut up' is not a very parliamentary term.
—Why not?
—I was told that those were the words you used. I did not hear what you said.
—I do not know whether you are asking me to withdraw, but the term is used everywhere and it has been used in this place. Are you ruling that it is unparliamentary?
—Yes.
—You don't rule.
—I do not think it is very polite.
—It may not be, but it is parliamentary.
—I certainly do not think that it should be used by Ministers or any member of the Senate for that matter. I call Senator Maguire.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I now want to look at the policies of the Liberal and National parties, because I think it is very important in this debate to explore what these people would do if they ever got into government. They are here today criticising us, talking down the economy as fast as they can and promoting doom and gloom. Let us have a look at what they might do if they ever got into government.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the guides we have is the number of Liberals and Nationals who made the pilgrimage to London to see Mrs Thatcher before she fell from government, to sit at her knee, worship in her room and find out the magic formula that helped her get into government and run Britain for 11 years. I think that this is where the Liberal and National parties want to go; these are the policies they want to copy. They have always sought her recipe for success, her so-called magic formula for winning government and how to run the economy. For a long time, the Liberals have been looking at Conservative policies in the United Kingdom-the policies of unlimited privatisation of public enterprises, the manic dependence on market forces, unfettered deregulation of the economy, slashing public sector investment, fire sales of public assets and, last of all, the policy of shifting more and more of the nation's tax burden, in the case of the United Kingdom, onto lower and middle income earners. That is what the Liberals want in Australia. They would copy those policies if they ever got into government.

It is very relevant at the moment to look at what has been happening in Great Britain under the policies of total deregulation of privatisation and selling off public assets which the Liberals would like to copy in this country. The Confederation of British Industry, the peak organisation in Britain, is saying that Britain is on the brink of recession. That is a headline in the Guardian Weekly of 12 August. Another headline on 26 August is: `More Families Losing Their Homes'. A headline in the Australian Financial Review of 17 September 1990 is, `Britain's Inflation Rate Surging'. In fact, the inflation rate in Britain is 11 per cent and, as I pointed out, ours is 6 per cent. Under the policies that the Liberals and Nationals would like to pursue in Australia, if they ever got into government, we would be seeing double digit inflation.

The Confederation of British Industry on 30 September forecast an even deeper recession. I point out, and it is very relevant to this motion that was moved here this afternoon, that 10,000 jobs are being lost every month in British manufacturing under the Conservative's policies that the Liberals and Nationals want to pursue in this country. Most relevant to this motion today, in which Senator Boswell has made claims about bankruptcies, is that in the United Kingdom at the moment, under the right wing policies of the Conservatives, bankruptcies are at their highest level in 50 years. I have here on my desk a quote showing bankruptcy levels in the United Kingdom at 50 per cent. It is no wonder that Mrs Thatcher was thrown out. The Conservatives are in trouble; their economic policies have failed. Yet the Liberals in Australia want to copy these policies. They will introduce these policies at the earliest opportunity in this country.

I checked out some other policies this afternoon of the conservatives sitting opposite. Every time there is any suggestion that something might need to be adjusted in the Australian economy, the conservatives call for a mini-Budget. That is their tired old formula. Twice a year, we can be sure that the conservatives and Nationals will call for a mini-Budget in Australia. That happened even at the State level. Senator Olsen spoke earlier in this debate. When he was the Opposition leader in South Australia, at least twice a year he would call for a mini-Budget. It is a tired old Liberal and National formula.

Mini-Budgets are not deep and meaningful concepts for the Liberals. As Senator Walsh pointed out a couple of weeks ago in this place, their mini-Budget is really a wish list of expenditure cuts. That is what it really comes down to-expenditures that they would like to cut. They would like to axe and slash government spending. But, of course, those wish lists are very selective. In the very near future in this place we will be debating Labor's Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill. That Bill aims to impose a tighter assets test on family allowances. In other words, if that Bill is passed, it will bring about cuts in government spending.

The Liberals and Nationals say they want to have cuts in government spending. We know that they are proposing to vote against that legislation. They are proposing to block legislation moved by the Labor Government to reduce spending on family allowances going to very wealthy families. They are proposing to block that so that those families continue to get family allowances. Time and time again they call for expenditure cuts and mini-Budgets, yet here we have a case where they are going to vote in favour of higher levels of expenditure. The Opposition Treasury spokesman, Mr Reith, is clearly crippled. He is unable to deliver expenditure cuts, despite the rhetoric in the Liberal Party about small government and cutting Government spending. There is clearly a very big gap between the reality and the rhetoric in the conservative parties.

We deserve to know what the Opposition would do about the capital gains tax if ever it got into government. As I pointed out yesterday, the Government is now collecting through that tax $543m every year. It is a significant tax, and it is vital to the Budget surplus of the Government. But what do the Liberals propose to do with the capital gains tax? In 1985 they said they would throw it out. Now apparently they are flirting with some kind of so-called speculative gains tax, and they are also flirting with the idea of dropping the 1985 starting point for the capital gains tax. If the Liberals were ever to implement that, it would cost billions of dollars of revenue. It would cost the Government substantial revenue and, of course, to replace that revenue it would have to increase taxes in other parts of the economy.

I would also like to find out how the Liberals propose to remedy our economic situation by bringing in a consumption tax. How on earth can the consumption tax-by reducing the price of luxury cars by $20,000; by reducing the price of a $97,000 car to $77,000-help the Australian balance of payments? How can the current account deficit in the Australian balance of payments be reduced by Dr Hewson's proposed consumption tax, which would stimulate the purchase of overseas produced luxury cars-and most of them are produced overseas--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired. The time allotted for the discussion has concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CENTRE FOR INTERNATIONAL AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I invite honourable senators, if they have not already done so, to have a look at this 1989-90 report and see some of the important work that is being carried on by the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research. ACIAR's goal is stated at page xiii:

ACIAR's goal is to build the capacity of developing countries through collaborative research in the agricultural sciences to improve the social, physical and economic well-being of the poor by increasing productivity, stability and sustainability in the agricultural sector.

It is accepted generally, and certainly accepted by the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, that this organisation is by and large doing very good work. One would have thought that in that case, and given the objectives of the organisation, the Government would be supporting it. But what has happened in this year's Budget? Effectively, the Government has cut funding to this organisation. So far as 1990-91 is concerned, an allocation of $18.5m would have been required to maintain the real value of the 1989-90 allocation. Therefore, the allocation of $17m in the 1990-91 Budget for this organisation represents a cut to ACIAR funding of 8.1 per cent in real terms.

If anything shows what the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, is all about, this report does. Senator Gareth Evans increases funding for the United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA) by 44 per cent, and cuts funding for this organisation-and agriculture research is vital-by 8.1 per cent. I might remind the Senate that the United States Government refuses to fund UNFPA on these grounds:
It contributes to the management of a program of coercive abortion and involuntary sterilisation in the People's Republic of China.

Here is the Australian Government on the one hand using taxpayers' money to increase its contribution to that organisation and, on the other hand, decreasing in real terms the amount allocated to the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research by 8.1 per cent.

The Government should just have a look at what Senator Gareth Evans is doing in this area, because the end result will be that the poor in these countries will not have the chance that they should have. I refer to the study showing that Zaire, alone in Africa, could, according to the Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations, feed the population of Africa several times over. Yet Zaire is not being given a go. There are all sorts of other elements such as corruption, inefficient economic systems and so forth that intervene, but we should not allow the Government to get away with cutting funds to this particular organisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some comments on this Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research annual report, particularly in light of the comments that have been made by Senator Harradine. I do not necessarily agree with him that cutting costs in certain areas of expenditure is a bad thing; I think it is more important that a balance be obtained between funds that are given to a particular corporation and the tasks or activities it undertakes. There are a number of very important things in this report, and I note that there is a potential for them to have some feedback and benefit to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I would particularly refer to page 9 of the report, where there is reference to salinity. It has been long demonstrated in a number of areas-for example, western Europe, America and China-that there is quite a lot we can learn about salinity and salinity control. It is appropriate, as salinity is a major problem in Australia, particularly in parts of Western Australia and in the Murray River area, that as well as assisting other countries in terms of a salinity report there be a flow-on benefit back to us.

Page 9 of the annual report shows the break-up between the various research programs, and we see a very balanced approach, I would suggest, to the research being done. The break-up is as follows: 22 per cent is going to crop sciences; 7.6 per cent to plant nutrition; 9.2 per cent to soil and water management; and 13 per cent to forestry. I would suggest that this break-up has been handled in a very appropriate manner.

I am not sure whether I mentioned crop sciences, but the figure of 22 per cent will be of real benefit to these underprivileged countries and will have a medium or longer term flow-back to Australia by building up and helping to make viable their economies. That is in direct contrast to what has been done by the more developed countries, particularly those in Europe, which have dumped products into those underdeveloped countries, thereby undermining their economies and their chances of developing them.

My other point is dealt with on page 31 of the report and deals with the efforts being made in respect of biological control of pests that damage crops, stock pasture and so on. Once again I see this as an opportunity not only to assist these countries but also as something from which Australia can learn. In view of the problems we have had in the past with some chemicals, particularly organochemicals, it is important that in the future efforts be made to control pests and get a balance.

I note the area dealing with the corporate management and support services program. This area is headed by John Allwright, the current President of the National Farmers Federation. He has had a long involvement in scientific research. I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate him on his appointment in respect of the corporate management and support services program.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SCHOOLS COUNCIL-AUSTRALIA'S TEACHERS-AN AGENDA FOR THE NEXT DECADE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This report deals with a key aspect of what is arguably one of the most vital institutions in Australia, our education system. The purpose of the paper, as outlined in the letter of transmission to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), is `to stimulate debate and action on the complex matters that affect the quality of teaching'.

The report will certainly stimulate debate, as the authors expect, but whether it will stimulate action remains to be seen. The report raises some interesting issues. For example, it argues that the assumptions governing teaching have become less straightforward and more tied to political concerns than previously. As a Victorian I can see the accuracy of that statement almost on a day by day basis in the changes initiated by the Kirner Government. The report points out another important effect on the work of teachers:
A sense of professional control and the nature of relations with employing authorities (at school regional and central level) are enduring issues for teachers.

I assume that this statement refers among other things to teacher unions and their increasing activity and influence over secondary teaching during the last two decades. If the report is saying this-and it is hard to see how one could ignore the impact of teacher unions on the profession of teaching-it is a pity that the language in the report is not more straightforward and forthright. Indeed, the role of teacher unions in our schools, the impact they are having on the profession and their appropriate role as we try to reform our education system should have been important subjects for discussion in a report such as this. We have largely to content ourselves with comments along the following lines:

But it should be noted that teachers have also taken larger socio-political responsibilities on themselves over the past few decades, responsibilities which are not necessarily acceptable to all. A teachers' union without a range of policy concerning issues such as gender equity and sexism, multiculturalism, Aboriginality and racism, the environment and peace is a rarity.
The report goes on to say:
It can always claim that these things directly relate to education, but they do presage a shift of concern from local, concrete, education issues, to more amorphous universal and mainstream issues.

Such problems are not amenable to simple resolution. In some cases teachers have been plainly encouraged to assume, or assumed on their own behalf an unreasonable burden of responsibility for intractable social and political problems.

To that I think we can all say, `Hear, hear!' Interestingly, the report argues that one of the lessons from the experience of the 1970s is that a massive increase in resource allocation will not of itself necessarily improve the quality of education. The report further argues that the growth in spending does not indicate a rapid rise in the salaries of individual teachers; instead it reflects a considerable increase in the total numbers employed and teacher-pupil ratios. It also argues that teachers' salaries have declined in real terms. It further argues:
The view that the standing of the profession and the morale of its members is at a low ebb is also widespread.
I hope to address these issues at a later stage. However, I would briefly like to discuss one other matter today. The report argues:

Teachers need have a thorough grasp of the content of what they are teaching. Their knowledge should be sufficient to have an understanding of the underlying structure of the subject matter, and its relationship to other areas of knowledge. They should appreciate and be able to convey its complexity and richness.

Teachers need to appreciate that process and content of learning are inextricably interwoven, and that an education, or view of education, which concentrates excessively on either one or the other is unsatisfactory.

This raises the issue of teacher training. It was a pity the report did not deal with some of the issues raised very effectively by the Institute of Public Affairs-an organisation with which I have had a long association-through the work of its education policy unit, which is directed by Dame Leonie Kramer. For example, in a recent report prepared by Dr Susan Moore, a research fellow of the Institute, she argues:

Prospective primary teachers devote on average less than half their teacher training time to curriculum subjects-ie English, Maths, Science and so on-and if time on the curriculum is further divided between study of the content of these subjects and methods of teaching them, how can they possess enough substantive knowledge of what they are teaching to function well in the classroom?
Further on, Dr Susan Moore argues:
In a typical three-year dip. teach program of 100 credit hours, 10 of which are given to English, two hours go to the teaching of reading. A subject so fundamental gets no more than that!
She goes on to say:

In the past decade, major work by psychologists, linguists, reading experts, and literature specialists has demonstrated that unless young children are given a broad background of knowledge of this country's history, values and customs-they will rapidly fall behind in reading.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly about the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust annual report 1989-90. The fund manages the Commonwealth superannuation funds. As from 1 July 1990, it will have its charter widened to enable it to invest moneys for a wider range of clients. We have no problems with that. Government business enterprises must be efficient and accountable and should be able to compete vigorously with the private sector.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Funds Management Limited Bill, which is currently before the Senate, proposes to further that process by formally separating the function of trustee and fund management. There is then the further possibility of the monopoly which the Commonwealth funds management will enjoy over Commonwealth superannuation moneys being terminated after five years.

The immediate reaction of the Opposition to the creation of a new government business enterprise seems to be, `Let's privatise it immediately'. It seems to the Australian Democrats that this is a purely ideological approach and does not look after the people that these funds are supposed to serve. Certainly, we will ensure that this privatisation program is not carried to the extent of privatising this Superannuation Fund Investment Trust.

The Left of the Australian Labor Party, probably because it felt guilty about the disgraceful pro-privatisation actions of the Government concerning the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, has apparently succeeded in forcing the insertion of an anti-privatisation clause in the Commonwealth Funds Management Limited Bill. Unfortunately, it does not quite work. While there is a prohibition on the Commonwealth disposing of its shares, there is no prohibition on the issuing of new shares to private interests. Clearly, the Government has made a blunder on this occasion in its anti-privatisation legislation.

Similar problems exist in the anti-privatisation provisions in the Commonwealth Banks Restructuring Bill, which I have drawn attention to and which at this stage the Government apparently does not intend to amend, leaving significant loopholes which would allow the complete privatisation and sale of the Commonwealth Bank to foreign interests.

But, returning to the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust, the Democrats will ensure that this clause is amended when the Bill is before the Senate to ensure that the antiprivatisation clause, which the Government apparently intended to insert, will be made watertight.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

In rising to speak to the Resource Assessment Commission annual report of 1989-90, I point out that the Resource Assessment Commission was a creation of the previous term of government supported, after very considerable amendment to its structure and charter, by the Australian Democrats and accepted by the Government. Since its creation, it has taken on a number of tasks. I wish to address one in particular which I hope the Resource Assessment Commission will take on and in respect of which several weeks ago I moved a motion in this place-that is, the matter of sandmining in Australia and the industries which relate to and are dependent upon it.

In years past, we have seen very extensive sandmining on the beaches of New South Wales and Western Australia and, to some extent, in other places. A lot of that mining has been carried out by multinational companies operating in Australia which, through a process of transfer pricing, have taken their profits and paid their tax substantially in other countries. That relates particularly to companies which have operated on the New South Wales coast. At the same time, there has been very extensive environmental damage. Despite claims to the contrary, it is a fact that in many instances it has been quite impossible to restructure the beaches as they were before those areas were mined and considerable long term damage has resulted.

More recently, there have been a number of proposals to value add with the products of that sandmining. The Democrats certainly are not opposed to that. We understand that in the past only some one-sixtieth of the value of the products which result from the mining of beach sands has actually accrued in Australia; 59-sixtieths accrued elsewhere. We are not in any sense averse to value adding.

But many of the industries which are based on sand products are environmentally suspicious. They result in considerable hazards to those who work in the industries and, moreover, the end products in which those sandmined minerals are used have serious question marks put over them by the Democrats and by those who are concerned about the end uses to which resources are put. I refer particularly to the use of some of the metals in military hardware.

It is for that comprehensive range of reasons that the Democrats would like to see the whole area of sandmining referred to the Resource Assessment Commission, including mining as such, its environmental impacts, the types of industrial processes through which those mined materials are put and the environmental and occupational health hazards associated with it. Here I refer particularly to the considerable concerns being expressed in Port Pirie in my own State over the products and the waste which will arise from that industry, particularly the radioactive products. Port Pirie has a very poor history with respect to exposure of its citizens to radioactive materials as a result of a previous exercise working through wastes in that city.

Also, as I have indicated, the overall economics of the industry should be referred to the Resource Assessment Commission to ensure that the maximum benefit flows to Australia from the maximum value adding which arises from the results of the mining and the processing of those minerals and, finally, the end products into which those materials are then manufactured. We urge upon the Government that that whole process be referred to the Resource Assessment Commission for a comprehensive report on the industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The whole notion of making a database of the resources available in Australia is very important in the work that the Resource Assessment Commission (RAC) has begun to do. What seems to be a large problem with the Government's actions of late is that it is coming in with resource security legislation before the Resource Assessment Commission has done its job. We have not seen a draft copy of that as yet, and there seems to be some doubt in various Ministers' minds about the timetable for that and exactly what shape it will take. However, what little we have heard about it as yet is very worrying. It does seem to cut right across the whole purpose of having this Resource Assessment Commission put in place.

SPEECH.PARA: Sustainable development committees have been put in place, again, to look at the issue of forestry. When forestry is one of the two major areas that the Resource Assessment Commission is looking at so far, it seems that the Government is undermining the RAC, which it set up with such great flourish. It must be a little difficult at times for people in the RAC, who are doing as good a job as they possibly can, to figure out exactly what is on the agenda of the Federal Government because they are not being given either enough resources or the unfettered run that they should be given so they can consult with the community as they work on these two inquiries. One inquiry is into forestry. It really makes one wonder why forestry is the reference for one of the nine environmentally sustainable development committees being set up by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

The other area is the Kakadu inquiry the RAC is conducting at the moment. Everything I have heard so far about the conduct of the inquiry has been highly commendable. The commissioners are certainly doing a very good job of listening to all parties in that matter. I know that when they bring down their report, which may or may not contain recommendations for the Government, they will have given everybody a good hearing. I hope that they will have the courage not only to put the information before the Government and say `Well, there you are; it is over to you to make the decision', but also to make some recommendations. It is my understanding that most of the information they have obtained in the Kakadu inquiry so far has been overwhelmingly in favour of leaving Coronation Hill as it is at the moment and not going ahead with the mining proposition which the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd is so forcibly trying to put forward. The evidence so far has been that, on environmental grounds and taking Aboriginal considerations into account, there are two very good reasons indeed for not going ahead with mining at Coronation Hill.

The Resource Assessment Commission has to be free to take all of the information and put that before the Government in a very open way. We only hope that when the Government looks at all the evidence it will come to the conclusion itself that Kakadu is too precious a resource to be trammelled, to be interfered with any further. As it is, huge sections of the whole area have been removed, have previously been excised for mining, and we in the conservation movement are very concerned about the whole of Kakadu and the parts that have already been declared for World Heritage. At the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources last week in Perth it was suggested that stage 3 should also be listed as a World Heritage area.

We hope that the Government, when it comes to looking at the Resource Assessment Commission's findings on Kakadu, will be very critical and look favourably on the conservation values that are put forward rather than going down the path that it seems to be going down at the moment, the very worrying path of putting short term economic gains ahead of long term conservation interests which are in the best interests of all Australians and the ecology of our whole nation in the future. That is a very important part of the Resource Assessment Commission's job, and I hope that it will be able to continue with that job without being starved of funding and without the feeling that it is being undermined by legislation or committees which the Government sets up.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990 and the amendments moved by Senator Powell to clause 2. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there is anybody in this chamber who really thinks that anti-smoking legislation will not continue to come in an effort to protect public health. Only today we have had notification of the passing of the Western Australian Tobacco Control Bill, which goes a long way towards looking at the question from a State point of view. I have been approached by many of the manufacturers over a period and they have put all sorts of outrageous propositions to me, as they have to most others. I have also been approached by the sports organisers, who are addicted to the product they get-the money-and would find it very difficult to change their habits.

SPEECH.PARA: The sort of thing I have had put to me is that the advertising is not for recruiting purposes; that it may be to get people to consider changing their brand but it is not intended to recruit. It is the old argument, `If it is legal, it should be advertisable'. It has been said that the sort of proposition we are discussing is censorship. We have had all sorts of propositions about the huge losses in the advertising industry. But when I come back to talk to the manufacturers again I find that sooner or later it gets down to the nitty-gritty.

If the manufacturers are genuine about the issues that they raise, a way will be found to overcome the problems of advertising on the fences, in the air or wherever it happens to be. That is not a problem if there is good will in the issue. The manufacturers need to develop their own code of practice to fit in with what is clearly the public wish and the way the public wish is developing still. If I or any of us in this chamber choose to kill ourselves by cigarette smoking that is one thing, but we have a responsibility to others. We have a responsibility to our young and to the young of others to see that they do not unnecessarily become involved in matters such as this.

The question of long term contracts was raised. Of course there are long term contracts. If I were in the position where I might lose one of my best avenues of advertising, I would want to take a long term contract as well. This does not worry me. It is the gravy train of the advertising industry and of course it wants to retain it. But of course we must raise the issues to see that these sorts of things are dealt with.

There is one particular group that I have difficulty with, and that is motor sports. Motor sports are very heavily tied into cigarette advertising, and I do not know what the answer is, but at least I have been able to discuss it with those involved in motor sports on many occasions and I retain a very good and useful rapport with them so that we can continue to discuss it. I am also a member of the East Torrens Cricket Club. I am a member of that club for a number of reasons, but mainly because of the absolute magnificence of Dean Southwood and the work he has done for the good of sport in South Australia and Australia-wide. I think he has done a magnificent job. He has also been able to prove that it can be done. He has proved that one can still win when it is done as far as the sporting effort is concerned.

Senator Herron this morning cited the number of AIDS deaths, and we are all well aware of the number of motor vehicle deaths, but what would happen if the number of motor vehicle accidents reached the stage where they were killing 10 per cent of the people that died every year? There would be an enormous hullabaloo, but the fact that we assist in 10- per cent of all deaths per year with cigarettes is acceptable. Well, it is not acceptable to me.

Governments in some States have made it law that kids on bikes must be provided with crash helmets-and providing a crash helmet for a kid on a bike is exactly the same as providing protection for people from the urge to smoke. If sport killed, it would be stopped or the rules would be changed. It is the same as the padding that goes with a game of football, and the helmets for a game of cricket. It is the discouragement of recruitment that we are debating. We just do not want more people to start. It is the community cost and the community loss that we have to be looking at.

I just ask some of the people who would support the open slather business to please spare us the salesmanship because we all know, however we ultimately look at this, that there can be only one answer: we must endeavour to discourage non-smokers from going into the field of smoking. The question comes back: do we care about the death, the pain, the suffering and the cost or not? Do we or do we not? Of course we all do, but we are shielding our care in all sorts of ridiculous ways by saying that something else is involved that is greater, or whatever. But underneath there is not one person who would not concede that this question of death, pain, suffering and costs has to be considered.

The Victorian Anti-Cancer Council and various other people have given me certain figures, and I have a desire to incorporate these in total in Hansard. Those figures show that, in 1988, a total of 9,228 people died from all forms of cancer. They also show that 17,960 died from cigarette smoking activities and other illnesses arising therefrom. That is a great many people. In fact, it represents 15.6 per cent of all the deaths in Australia-one in seven of all deaths. In men, it was one in five; in women, it was one in 12.

Going further, various analyses have been made in Western Australia by the Department of Health, which has attempted to put dollar values on this. It has finally come up with a figure representing the computed cost by 1990 of the loss to the Australian community arising from deaths by smoking. That figure is $4,122m for the year. Are we prepared to see that continue? Are we prepared to just keep on brushing that away and saying that really it is not terribly important? It is important. It is worth trying to cut that figure down.

What we are talking about here is a very tiny step, but it is a worthwhile step until we take the next bigger one, such as the one that has now been taken in Western Australia. Please, no-one believe that it will not come. Please, no-one believe that legislation like this will not be passed, because we all know that it will. We will all want to know that we have been part of the passing of that legislation when the time comes. Finally, I seek leave to have the document from which I quoted certain figures incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
