SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Previously, I was saying how persuasive were the arguments I had thus far heard from the anti-advertising senators. I think I was making the point that of course cigarettes do cause lung cancer-not for everybody, but for very many people. I remember that I was making the point that I was visiting the oncology section of the Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital recently where I talked to a young mother who had at least two or three young children and was dying of lung cancer. She said to me, `Noel, you know, I don't believe smoking causes lung cancer, but I think that once you have lung cancer it exacerbates the disease'. And I thought to myself then: with all the known medical science of society, a lady who is in hospital dying of cancer and clearly receiving very good treatment-notwithstanding it being a public hospital-still is not persuaded that cigarette smoking causes lung cancer. It really shows the quantum leap yet to be made in persuading people of the ills of their habits.

SPEECH.PARA: I suspect, like all of us, that that lady was wishing not to be convinced of that fact because it would have denied her the pleasure that she had had in the previous years. One can still see cases of people on chemotherapy drips standing outside of hospitals smoking cigarettes with the drips actually inserted in their arms. It just goes to emphasise the point which I think was made by Senator Peter Baume this morning or perhaps by Senator Herron-it is an addictive drug.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have even seen them smoke through a tracheostomy.

—When people smoke through a tracheostomy, it really does give one an idea of the grip that nicotine has upon people. I commenced my comments by saying that the dilemma for me in distilling down the arguments was still to some degree somewhat clouded. I wish for the divine determination that others have made, that is, whether or not it is acceptable in a modern, enlightened society to place no proscription or prohibition upon the use or consumption of a substance but, at the same time, provide a ban on the publication and the publicising or, in other words, the advertising of that substance. It seems to me that it does cause some sort of a conflict in the measures one applies to the intrinsic responsibilities of individuals.

SPEECH.PARA: It can be boiled down, I suspect, not unreasonably, to the view that it is simply censorship-and censorship in many respects is the denial of freedom to publish information, whatever form it might be in. That is the purport of those who believe that cigarette smoking should not be advertised. For reasons that we have heard in a very articulate and persuasive way, that has some merit.

I know that it is not the issue before us now, but raised today was the issue of whether or not the kernel of the question is: is it proper for society to accept the social and the economic cost of allowing the manufacture, the sale and the distribution of a product which, as Senator Herron said this morning, applied in the form and manner prescribed by the manufacturer is capable of leading to death-not used in a capricious, improper way, but used precisely according to the terms under which it is sold?

There is a very significant body of opinion in the community, one for which we must have respect, that governments have a responsibility to say, `No, we do not accept that as a reasonable thing'. An interesting point was made this morning about cigarettes. To my knowledge it is not illegal for adolescents under the age of 16 to smoke cigarettes, but it is an offence to sell cigarettes to adolescents under the age of 16.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are being modest; you made that point.

—Somebody made the point about it being legal. I said that it is not illegal for cigarettes to be smoked by adolescents under 16. To my knowledge-I can be corrected-it is not an offence to provide cigarettes to adolescents under 16. Again, governments have gone only part of the way. Perhaps they have gone as far as they think is tolerable; perhaps they have gone as far as they think they can without costing themselves revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: There seems to be a contradiction in principle that it is an offence for a shopkeeper to sell cigarettes, but it is not an offence for that shopkeeper to give away the cigarettes and it is not an offence for a youth-for whom it is an offence to be sold cigarettes-to smoke cigarettes. I do not understand the logic of that law. I suspect that in the same way that we address the consumption of alcohol, it is a case of what we think a significant part of the community will tolerate.

We had a debate in Western Australia recently about alcohol consumption levels of 0.08 and 0.05 before one is said to have committed an offence. It has been argued with some persuasion that the level of deaths through accidents in motor vehicles significantly declines if the legal alcohol level is reduced to 0.05. A more profound statistic is that, if the drinking age is increased from 18 to 21, the level of deaths caused by the use of alcohol amongst young people drops very significantly. Why do we not deal with that? Why does the Government not have the courage to increase the drinking age to 21? The reason it does not--

TALK.START.PARA: —You would escape; you are over 21.

—I am only over 21 by 18 years. I am not that far removed from it. I did not drink until I was 21, but I made up for it with some sort of endeavour afterwards. I used to be a heavy smoker, but enlightenment comes to all who wait. Now I do not smoke and, as Senator Collins said this morning, I would be devastated if I thought my children were going to smoke. I would do everything in my power, and some things outside my power, to stop them.

SPEECH.PARA: In the same way that we do not address the fundamental questions of the use and abuse of alcohol, we do not address the fundamental question of cigarettes. For my part, if there were a law which could be enforceable-and that is always a measure of what laws are appropriate and what laws are not-I would ban the sale and distribution of tobacco. I am also opposed to marijuana and all other drugs which are damaging in that way. They are banned at present because that is politically acceptable to the majority.

The reason we do not ban cigarettes is that so many people are hooked on them that it would be politically untenable for any government. At least this Government has had some courage in respect of one thing-I always thought that there would be a riot when it banned the use of cigarettes in domestic aircraft. I am amazed that it was received so well and that it is widely accepted. I suspect that at the end of the day the one thing that will win this debate on the use and abuse of cigarettes is social pressure. If a person goes to a dinner party now and he is the only smoker, it is no longer sociably acceptable. The majority of people find it offensive and ask the person concerned to leave the dinner table and smoke his cigarette out on the veranda or wherever.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crichton-Browne, could you address your remarks through the Chair.

—I am sorry, Madam Temporary Chairman. If we are going to be serious about these matters, these are the questions we will to have to address. With regard to the amendments that we are addressing, I see no intrinsic fundamental difference between incidental advertising, accidental advertising and intentional advertising; they all have the same effect. If we were serious about it, we would ban the lot. There is no fundamental difference between advertising on television, on radio and in the print media, but certain forms of advertising are more penetrating and more influential than others. Other than that, it is the same argument and the same debate. Until such time as governments address that matter, they will not be facing up to their real responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply conclude by saying that at the end of the day the norms and the mores of society and community pressure will change this with the help and the persuasion of those senators who hold a strong view. I find it interesting that some of us have the impertinence to stand up and correct Senator Peter Baume and Senator Herron. If we were to see them in their private capacity with their white coats on and their stethoscopes, and we said, `What do you think is wrong with us?', and they said, `Give up smoking,' we would not be having a vote on it; we would throw our cigarettes in the bin straightaway because it would be self-preservation. However, that is not the issue before us. The issue is whether or not the legislation is thoroughly honest in its endeavours and whether the amendments are honourable in their endeavours.

It does not take an intellect greater than mine to understand that it does not matter whether the advertising is incidental, accidental or deliberate: it has the same penetrating effect. The question at the end of the day is whether we are prepared to accept the social and economic cost of allowing people to kill themselves; whether we believe governments, societies and the majority of the community have a greater interest and responsibility to impose legislation which restricts the rights of other people; whether we are prepared to allow substances to be consumed or used by society in a thoroughly legal way; and whether we are fulfilling a proper responsibility by saying that one can consume them but one is not allowed to learn anything about them which encourages one to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today when I spoke, Senator Collins said that I had almost convinced him. Then Senator Crichton-Browne said that if it were a matter of self-preservation there might be another attitude. It is a matter of self-preservation. Honourable senators will recall that earlier this year Senator Newman wrote to the President of the Senate and brought to his notice a problem which he thought was caused by the air-conditioning in Parliament House. They will also recall that the President of the Senate then wrote to all senators and asked whether we had any problems in relation to the air-conditioning of Parliament House. He also wrote to the engineer.

SPEECH.PARA: A survey of members was then conducted, the result of which I have with me. It is quite interesting. One member complained of sore eyes and was unable to wear contact lenses; another complained of sinus problems; another had sinus problems; another complained of conjunctivitis; others complained of respiratory problems, sore eyes, sinus problems, bloodshot eyes, fatigue and headaches. I will not read what the honourable senator wrote himself; I am not identifying anybody.

There were no health problems, but attention was drawn to the temperature, itchy eyes, colds and so on. This was then attributed to the ageing of the building. When I left the debate this morning I walked out to the far area of the building and there were 10 staffers out there all smoking away to their heart's content. So I rang the chief engineer. It is interesting to note that there is 90 per cent recycling of air in this building in cool weather. The percentage of recycled air goes down for energy saving purposes at other times, so it can be less than that-actually, it can go down to 10 per cent in winter. Everyone in this chamber and in the public areas of this building, whether we like it or not, is inhaling cigarette smoke; so it is a matter of self-preservation.

An article in the New England Journal of Medicine for 1990 showed that the odd ratio for people exposed to the baseline for 25 smoker years was found to be 2.07. What it all means in non-jargon terms is that there is twice the chance of a person getting a cigarette-related disease through passive smoking than there is if a person is not exposed to passive smoking. I mentioned earlier today that 32 children of every 132 who start smoking will die of a cigarette-related disease. The interesting aspect is that the children of parents who smoke have a 17 per cent incidence of lung cancer. So there is a passive smoking effect as well.
Finally, I want to refer Senator Collins to the Tobacco Control Bill 1990 which was passed in Western Australia a few days ago. A press release that has been put out states in relation to the Bill:
- bring to an end the advertising of tobacco on billboards, awnings and everywhere except at the point-of-sale
- prohibit advertising by the use of tobacco brand names or trademarks on other products
- end competitions involving tobacco products and free samples of tobacco products
- end tobacco promotion through sponsorship of sport and the arts
- establish the Health Promotion Foundation to replace sponsorships, promote healthy lifestyles, with particular emphasis on young people, and support health research
- increase penalties on the sale of cigarettes to anyone under 18 years of age from the current $4 to $5000.

That is what the Labor Government of Western Australia is doing. What are we doing in this Parliament? What is the Government doing in this Parliament? Is it denying that the Western Australian Government is correct? This Government is procrastinating day by day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Death by death.

—Death by death; I thank the honourable senator. The time has come to act. The arguments of the death dealers in the community who have a vested interest are `Let us get it right' and `Let us put it off'. It is not my argument, and I believe it should not be the argument of this chamber.

—I wonder whether the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) would care to elaborate on his earlier explanation that the Government is not prepared to agree with the amendments at this stage. As I understood it, he said that the Government was in the process of negotiating with a range of sporting organisations. Presumably that means that the Government is in a position to indicate, at least in aggregate terms, what sums of money are involved and over what periods of time we might be talking about agreements running. I think we would all find it helpful and at least understand the bona fides of the Government if we could have indicated to us just what is currently inhibiting the Government from moving on the issue. I ask for further and better particulars on those matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I can use the opportunity that Senator Alston has provided to respond very briefly to some of the other questions that were raised to which, because of the time that is elapsing, I had not intended to respond. Some of the points raised earlier today by Senator Michael Baume were in fact absolutely correct. I know that there is probably not a lot of disagreement about what he said in relation to some of the short term difficulties associated with simply moving immediately to resolve this issue-for example, in respect of problems that were raised by long term contracts. Of course, there are long term contracts but, as I mentioned earlier in the debate, a number of contracts around do involve substantial sums of money, although they have let-out clauses in them to prepare for the day when this will happen. In other words, they provide for an opportunity to declare the contract to be effectively void almost immediately, so the effect will be short term.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the other issues that was raised-I think this has to be said in response to Senator Alston's question because I have asked the same question myself-is that it is difficult, for obvious reasons, to absolutely isolate that section of financial support which is perhaps directly related to the question of sponsorship and so on because there are grey areas involved. In broad terms, the figure I have been provided with in relation to replacement is around $20m. The Confederation of Australian Sport figure is around $20m, and that of course is recurrent. I have not actually confirmed whether meetings did take place today, but a brief I read yesterday said that meetings were due to take place today between representatives of certain organisations in receipt of this funding and the Government. Earlier in the debate, a question was raised about the action that has been taken by various State governments in replacing this money and how quickly it was done. The difficulty of course is for the Federal Government to do this on a national basis. For example, in Victoria I am told that only a few groups were involved that could be very easily identified and it was possible to take fairly quick action on it. But in terms of introducing this nationally, the number of organisations is very large and the requirements of all of those organisations are quite different.

One of the heavy questions that has to be properly answered by government-I thought Senator Michael Baume, in his particular shadow portfolio responsibility, put it very well today-is that it is not the black and white simple solution that others have suggested. You cannot simply say, `Okay, we will establish a committee or form a group of people and provide some sort of overriding government grant that instantly replaces all of this money with taxpayers' money and they will dish out the money, by and large, across the board'. As I said earlier, I hope that the issue is handled expeditiously. I was told only as late as lunchtime today that it will be handled expeditiously by the Government. But to put a proposal together is a little more complex than that. As Senator Michael Baume quite rightly said, the arrangement will be fair and will be seen to be equitable, no matter what that arrangement might be.

The question of keeping these sporting and cultural organisations financially viable and able to operate is very high on the Government's current agenda of discussions as regards what mechanisms can be brought in, what potential budgetary impact they might have and where that impact will be felt, if it is felt. At the end of the day, it may well be appropriate for the Government to provide this replacement, at least partially, for the estimated $20m that is involved on a recurrent basis per year. It should not be thought that 12 months is not sufficient time. The Government is not indicating that it cannot be done by then. As a result of the very detailed negotiations that are currently taking place, the Government's position simply is that it is too early to know whether that is sufficient without harming financially the organisations that are currently in receipt of these funds.

I think it can be seen, in response to Senator Alston's question, that the Government has very firmly stated its position on the substance of the point of debate, that is, it is not opposed to the intent of the legislation. We are quite clear about that. We are also saying, and I repeat it, that we are not necessarily of the view, at this point in the negotiations, that it will take longer than 12 months.

As Senator Michael Baume and other honourable senators have commented during this debate, when we spend hour after hour in tedious debate in the Senate on all sorts of subjects, it is refreshing to listen to a debate like this every now and again. Various points of view have been put. Senator Bishop and others have expressed their different views. But the question of sponsorship has been most adequately addressed in the debate by Senator Michael Baume. It is not as cut and dried an issue as many people think it is. We have to address the very real problem of providing an alternative mechanism for keeping financially viable all of these organisations that provide the services, and in some way that is going to fairly and equitably replace the current heavy dependence-that was a very good way of phrasing this-on tobacco, which has grown out of the proscriptions that were applied by the then Government in 1976 for the direct advertising of tobacco.

TALK.START.PARA: —Out of that 10-minute contribution I gleaned one fact.
—Five minutes, in fact.

—It seemed like 10. I gleaned one fact, and that concerned the recurrent amount of $20m. But I also asked what that involved in terms of lengths of contracts, fixed or otherwise. The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Collins, says there are escape hatches attached to some of them--
—Some.

—If that is the case then in a sense they can be disregarded for the present purposes. If they cannot, then surely we ought to know whether $5m relates to contracts that are for five-year fixed periods with no escape clauses. It is surely of interest for the Senate to know whether some of them are 10-year contracts, fixed, with no escape clauses, or whether the vast majority of them are simply one-year renewable options, in which case we would take an entirely different position. We want to know what precisely it is that the Government believes might flow from any premature termination of those contracts because it would seem to me that we could certainly say there is an obligation on the networks to mitigate their losses. If they were to find alternative sponsors of programs then the organisations would not be out of pocket. If that is the case, then that is another reason why I would have thought there is no need for a government funding rescue package to be put together.
—We are talking about--

—Yes, but it is the benefits that flow from those organisations being able to have an event described as the Winfield Grand Prix or whatever it might be. They can then manage to get an inordinate amount of coverage under the guise of incidental or accidental advertising.
—Money does not flow to the television channels. It goes to sporting bodies.

—If it goes to sporting bodies direct from the cigarette companies, they are saleable only because they are being promoted on television. So if the sporting organisation is able to go to a non-cigarette company, then presumably that company would be prepared to pay the same or similar rates as are currently being paid by cigarette companies.
—Gillette or Cornhill.

—Gillette or Cornhill or whoever else. So one cannot take the worst case scenario and say that if we chop off cigarette company funding there will be no other alternative source of funding. Therefore, I want to know what account is taken of that in the Government's projections of the financial cost involved in terminating the current arrangements.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did answer the question. I deliberately qualified what I said about let-out clauses when I raised this matter by saying it is believed that a number of these contracts have let-out clauses, for the simple reason that they are contracts, private agreements between, in the main, private organisations. It is between sporting organisations and the people who sponsor them. I would hate to see a situation arise where the Government simply, as of right, had the power to haul people in and get that information provided instantly on a statistical basis.
—What do you mean? Has it asked for it?

—Yes. I thought I had made that clear. The Government is currently in the process, in a detailed way, of going to identified organisations that get these arrangements and seeking their cooperation by discussing the contractual arrangements that do exist. But they are private contracts--
—So what? I am not asking you to disclose the contents.
—That is precisely what the question asked me to do-to tell the chamber what are the details of the contracts, and their length of operation.
—In aggregate.
—That is precisely the process the Government is currently engaged in.
—How many organisations have you spoken to so far?
—I am not actually conducting negotiations with any organisation.
—How many?

—I will get that information. If this discussion indicates that there is a change of view on the part of the Opposition in terms of how it is going to vote on this amendment, and I am quite serious about that in trying to contain to some extent the time of the Senate in respect of the legislative load we have to get through in the next fortnight somehow-and I do not know how-perhaps the shadow Minister, Senator Alston, could indicate that to me directly.
—I am asking you a question.

—I will get the information, Senator. It is a fair question in terms of the discussion we have already had on this issue to ask whether this does indicate that there is going to be a change of view on the part of the Opposition.
—It does not indicate any change.

—I was just curious about that point. I believe it is legitimate curiosity. I will get that information, if we can get it. But the aggregate figure I was given earlier today when I asked the question was that the replacement value of the total amount combined is estimated to be in the order of $20m recurrent. We have conducted negotiations with the peak organisation, the Confederation of Australian Sport, which represents several hundred sporting organisations. We are seeking further information on what individual organisations may have been consulted so far by the Government. The Confederation of Australian Sport I am advised is the principal body with which the Government is dealing in terms of these consultations.

—Would the Minister be prepared to advise the Committee in due course of the number of organisations from which the Government has managed to glean information to date and to be a little more forthcoming in terms of those contracts? We do not want names, addresses and wives' maiden names; we simply want to know in aggregate terms how many contracts there are that are of more than one year's duration and what sort of money is applied to each of those categories, so we can have some general idea of what the consequences might be if ever the Government gets around to this sort of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised-not to my great surprise-that this is not the easy task it may appear on the surface to be.
—You have not made it obvious.
—For obvious reasons. In the case of some of the larger organisations, they have flatly refused, and they have a right to do so--
—No-one has said they do.

— Let me finish-to provide the information that the honourable senator is seeking. What I am doing at the moment is trying to find out details of the number of organisations being consulted. Another senator has referred to this matter. I refer to Senator Archer, who is on the other side of this debate. Senator Archer is not alone, of course, in having received representations from sporting organisations that are concerned about the loss of financial support, which in the case of many of the ones I know in the Northern Territory, as distasteful as I find this form of sponsorship, currently face dissolution if this level of support is involved.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I make that point-and it is an important point-is that the Government simply cannot afford to take the position of brushing aside the problems of these organisations as being of no account. That is why the Government at this point is reluctant to set a time of 12 months. Hopefully, the negotiations will be concluded prior to that. But the number of people affected the other way, if you like, by the passage of this amendment is significant; it is not a small number of people. A very large number of people who belong to a very large number of organisations, rightly or wrongly-and I have made it quite clear, in my view, wrongly-are currently in receipt of very substantial amounts of sponsorship from tobacco companies.

There are many arguments, and I have the same distaste as other senators have expressed for the salesmanship or attempted salesmanship involved. I said earlier that I have had the same experience as Senator Archer in receiving these representations from sporting bodies, and I am prepared to listen to them. But I do draw the line at getting lobbied by the tobacco companies. I have in fact declined because I know what they are going to say and I am not interested in the nonsense. It is specious to assert that they are interested only in getting people to change brands and not in recruiting. The joining of cigarette smoking with sport has the effect of recruiting new smokers and persuading people that it is the fine thing to do. Because I am not interested in hearing that kind of nonsense from the tobacco lobby-and I think it is an insult to anyone's intelligence-I have declined the approaches that have been made to me by lobbyists from the tobacco industry; I have declined even to talk to them.

Having said that, one cannot simply brush aside as a matter of no account the very large number of Australians who are in the position, unfortunately, at the moment, of placing so much reliance upon the very substantial sums of money that are currently provided by the tobacco industry. The Government is not brushing those concerns aside. It has indicated it is not opposed to the intent of this legislation but it does want carefully to consider, but not in a protracted fashion, the arrangements that can be put in place to ensure that these organisations remain viable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator POWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to a few things that have been said in this committee debate. I endorse what Senator Collins said. This has been a debate-something which we do not see often enough in this chamber. I thank honourable senators for their contribution. I want to make it clear, though, that we are not, by these amendments, calling for a ban on smoking. However, these amendments are part of our preparedness -a preparedness that goes back before my time in this place -to take all necessary steps to reduce the incidence of tobacco use in the community because of the cost. Those costs have been articulated: costs in financial, social and personal terms.

SPEECH.PARA: In answer to Senator Michael Baume specifically, we acknowledge that this is only one of the measures needed; there are many others. But we have this legislation before us, it needs amending and should be amended, and now is the time that it should be amended. There are other things we can do, for example, in regard to pricing, and I will have something to say about that in a minute. In regard to packaging, the latest edition of the Australian Medical Association journal talks about possible generic packaging, doing away with all the flashy colour and attractiveness in the packaging and just putting `cigarettes' on the front of it. That is an interesting issue for the future.

Direct mail is another issue we have to address. I am pleased to see that the Western Australian legislation which has just been passed ends competitions involving tobacco products and free samples of tobacco products, which of course is the new ploy that the tobacco industry is getting into in order to replace its losses through the print ban which is to come into place at the beginning of next year.

There are other States and Territories that do not yet have legislation. All of that has to be done and we have to support the lobby groups and the organisations and put pressure on our political colleagues in those States and Territories. We believe that education will eventually be part of the package that comes out because the point that Senator Archer made is absolutely true: this loophole will be closed. The tobacco industry knows that, and we should be closing it here today.

I congratulate in particular Senator Peter Baume, Senator Herron and Senator Archer for their contributions. I am not sure yet whether I ought to congratulate Senator Crichton-Browne; I think not-perhaps I could for obfuscation. Other Opposition senators, I think, have not distinguished themselves in this debate-the furphies, the non-arguments, have been quite undistinguished.

I also want to congratulate some of the others out in the community who supported this and other moves that have been taken and that have been proposed. Other colleagues have mentioned Mr David Hill, the Managing Director of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), for his stand with regard to his rugby league team, North Sydney, and his preparedness to take on the League itself. Of the things that David Hill has said in the last couple of days, perhaps the thing we need to listen to most, as legislators, is his complaint that on the ABC, for which he is responsible, Allan Border, the hero of little boys-and little girls-all around this country, stands up during this cricket season in front of the Benson and Hedges logo time and time again during the week-probably again tonight, as there is a one-day match on, which my son is watching on television in my office at the moment. This is it: cult heroes, sporting heroes and tobacco logos. On the ABC it is inappropriate, as David Hill said. When asked whether he would stop telecasting that sport, his answer-if he was quoted correctly in the Age this morning-was as follows:
I think what's got to be done is the Federal Government has got to get rid of the legal loophole that allows that (sponsorship) to happen.

That is what we are attempting to do here today, and that is what we should be doing. I also want to mention motor sports, which were raised by Senator Archer. I want particularly to commend Bob Jane and the Calder Thunderdome in my own State of Victoria. They have steadfastly refused tobacco advertising and they are to be commended for that. If honourable senators ever try to get down the Calder Highway when there is an event on at the Thunderdome, they will know that that has not exactly diminished the popularity of that particular sporting event, and there are others that could be mentioned. But Mr Jane has been in touch with me and I particularly wanted to thank him for his support.

The Government says, `Not now. We cannot do this now'. Government spokespeople, I am told by the media, in the interim between this morning's debate and the debate this afternoon, have been talking to the media about Democrat grandstanding. This matter has been on notice, as I said earlier, for a year, and Senator Collins should note that the year I am talking about is not the year referred to in the amendment, which is the year until implementation. I am talking about the year since last December, when it was clearly on notice from me to the Government that the next move would be when the Broadcasting Act came back for amendment, and that these amendments would be moved. I had them drafted last year and they were probably in the Minister's office last year-as I recall, in December. The broadcasting Bills were before us in the last week in December last year. They were pulled off, I might add, because of a certain weak-kneed attitude to foreign ownership at the time, which has been rectified today, I am pleased to see.

That year is the year that has been wasted. My heart warms to the thought that these negotiations are going on today and that these hundreds of sporting bodies are finally being consulted. But what has been going on for this whole year? Yes, we have had an election; and the Government has forgotten and not cared about what the community thinks of this issue. So it is this year that has been lost; this 12 months just passed. There is yet another year ahead for implementation.

Basically, I gave the Government two years to get its act together on a $20m package. Victoria is running a $20m plus package for its Victorian Health Promotion Foundation and it is buying out sport nationally-such as national soccer. It is the Victorian Health Promotion Foundation that is part of that buy-out. I am proud of my State and I am disappointed and disgusted with the Federal Government and the Federal Opposition on this issue.

It seems to me that there are too many people here who accept the arrogance of the tobacco companies when they say that there are no other sponsors. That is absolute rubbish. It is also rubbish to say that we are actually stopping sponsorship, because we are not. We are only stopping the advertising in an incidental fashion on television, and on radio, by this measure. Sponsorship will still be possible.

Surely these esoteric tobacco companies-which, as we know, fund media outlets out of the goodness of their heart because advertising does not work-might still be interested in doing some sponsoring even though they are not allowed to put up their signs and logos. Actually, they do that in Europe. It is called colour sponsorship. They just wear the colours of their tobacco company. I would not want to encourage that in Australia, but it is possible, and it would be possible under this legislation. So it is possible that not all the sponsorship would go. That is something that one would have to ask the tobacco companies. But I, like Senator Collins, do not engage in discussion with them. They came to me two years ago and I think they judged that I was serious. I also told them about the disclosure provisions in my Party's constitution when it comes to funding.

If the Government and the Opposition are really going to cop out today, which it appears they are, they are going to give a gigantic gift to the tobacco companies-a bonanza-which even the tobacco companies did not expect to get. They have been expecting this loophole to be closed. They have formed task forces and all the rest of it to try to lobby against it. Obviously, they have been effective. The form of that gift is to give them more time to up the ante, to push up the price of sponsorship so that when the Government does get around to doing something, it is going to cost that much more. That is stupid, short-sighted, ridiculous and dangerous. How are we ever going to persuade a Treasurer if the price keeps going up and up? This does a disservice to those States and Territories which are doing the right thing-South Australia, Victoria, Western Australia and the Australian Capital Territory. Those States are having their buy-out costs pushed up by a Federal government which is not prepared to act even though it has had the time and has been on notice to do so.

The Government, as I said, makes a rod for its own back because it has to close these loopholes-it knows it does and it will only cost more. I can back up those claims. We are now in the dying days of print advertising and what have we seen? In a few months the tobacco companies have spent the equivalent of a 2 1/2-year print advertising budget so they can move out into wider circles beyond the print ban.

In the latest edition of the Women's Weekly a calendar was provided for those people who do not want to go cold-turkey, so they can have printed ads all next year in the Benson and Hedges calendar. There have been pop-up books in Cosmopolitan, mail-outs and competitions, and new brands launched with massive spending-all in a few months. That is what they will do when it comes to the sporting sponsorship. So why not act now? I cannot help remembering what Senator Herron said about 132 kids today taking up smoking and 32 of them dying.

As I said, the Government has had a year and it can have another year. We have talked with the Government and the Opposition. We have worked with the Government. We have pursued this with the Government. We did not let it forget. We did not lob this on it last week. I commend the work of Minister Staples's office. I regret that he has not been able to achieve the necessary breakthrough. I would like to help the Government in its deliberations.

It seems that the electoral popularity of this move has been discounted in this post-election period. I remind the Government of a survey that was done in 1987 on the political acceptability of an increase in tobacco taxation in which it was quite clear that the approval rate of a ban on tobacco company sponsorship of sport-if money were replaced from tobacco tax-was 57 per cent in Victoria and 75 per cent in South Australia. In 1988 there was 67 per cent approval in New South Wales. In July 1990, most recently, there was 69 per cent approval in Queensland. Clearly, the community has not set its sails against this kind of move and is prepared for progressive action on behalf of government.

In terms of cigarette affordability in Australia, as my colleague Senator Spindler said earlier, cigarettes are cheaper in real terms than they were in 1949. Based on 1949 prices, for which we have a comparable consumer price index figure, we see that a packet of 20 Craven A filter cigarettes cost two shillings and two pence. That is equivalent to $3.20 in 1990 or 16c per actual cigarette. Today an actual cigarette costs 10.5c.

In terms of cigarette taxes as a percentage of retail price-as I said in response to Senator Michael Baume, pricing is one of the areas where we can act-Australia's proportion of tax is the lowest in comparable Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries. Its rate of 55 per cent compares, for instance, with that of France at 72 per cent; Italy, at 72 per cent; Canada, at 59 per cent; Germany, at 73 per cent; Ireland, at 75 per cent; Denmark, at 86 per cent; and so on. I have plenty of other information. I am absolutely certain that the organisations that have been giving it to me have been giving it to the Government as well.

The Government needs to do a cost-benefit analysis. The millions of dollars that it is costing the community must come into the calculations. The Minister says that he hopes and believes that measures will be taken expeditiously. As I have shown, they must be taken expeditiously. I challenge the Government to get its negotiations done and come back to us with amendments next week. We will ensure their speedy passage. The House of Representatives is coming back. Let us put it to work on this and get this thing done.

In this place last week I raised the question of the Prime Minister's XI cricket match being part of the Benson and Hedges sponsored Australian Cricket Board England tour. Immediately before the last election, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) accepted the strong approach of the AMA and others, and we banned print advertising. That has not happened this time. Why not? I believe that is a legitimate question. Senator Peter Baume said that the tobacco companies have purchased sport and culture in this country. We would have to be asking the question today, as these amendments do not get support, as to whether or not the tobacco companies have not also purchased the other political parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened carefully to the remarks that have been made during this debate. The contribution made by Senator Herron has been the one that I believe has influenced me most, and I say to the Committee that he should be congratulated on it. But there have been a number of other quite important contributions from the other side of the boat as well. Senator Michael Baume indicated that this is not an amendment about banning advertising: it is an amendment about banning the televising of advertising-in other words, banning the televising of sports, in this case, where there is incidental advertising in the form of billboards and the like. As such, we have to be clear on what we are doing at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: There is obviously a substantial amount of information available-scientific and otherwise-as to the adverse effects of smoking on health. Each one of us probably has a example in our own mind. There is a responsibility, I believe, on the State parliaments to grapple with this issue in so far as it is largely a matter for their responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) After clause 2, page 2, insert the following clauses:

Leave of absence
`14. (1) The Minister may grant the Chairman leave of absence on such terms and conditions as to remuneration or otherwise as the Minister determines in writing.
`(2) The Chairman may grant another member or an associate member leave of absence on such terms and conditions as to remuneration or otherwise as the Chairman determines in writing.'.
Termination of office
``2b. Section 15a of the Principal Act is amended by omitting from subparagraph (2) (b) (ii) `granted by the Minister'.''.
These amendments, quite simply, are to streamline the provisions for achieving leave of absence on the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.
Proposed new clauses agreed to.
Clause 3 agreed to.
Clause 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 4, page 2, proposed definition of ``networking agreement'', line 25, after ``licence'', insert ``, but does not include:
(a) an agreement under which the holder of the licence is obliged to:
(i) broadcast a program supplied under the agreement; or
(ii) broadcast any program at a particular time; or
(b) an agreement where the holder of the licence is, otherwise than under the agreement, under an obligation to the supplier to:
(i) broadcast a program supplied under the agreement; or
(ii) broadcast any program at a particular time; or
(c) an agreement under which the holder of the licence is prevented from purchasing programs from another supplier''.
4. Clause 12, page 6, proposed subsection 89ea (1), definition of ``networking agreement'', line 19, after ``licensee'', insert ``, but does not include:
(a) an agreement under which the competing licensee is obliged to:
(i) broadcast a program supplied under the agreement; or
(ii) broadcast any program at a particular time; or
(b) an agreement where the competing licensee is, otherwise than under the agreement, under an obligation to the supplier to:
(i) broadcast a program supplied under the agreement; or
(ii) broadcast any program at a particular time; or
(c) an agreement under which the competing licensee is prevented from purchasing programs from another supplier.''.

The second amendment is consequential upon the first. Both deal with networking. Amendment No. 1 inserts a definition for networking and amendment No. 4 deals with the application of this definition of networking.

A number of clauses in this Bill relate to the so-called networking agreements which exist between regional television stations and the major television networks providing for the supply of programs from the networks to the regionals. Clause 12 of this Bill will provide exemptions from ownership and control limits for the parties to the networking agreements.

The provision of these exemptions has come about from a recent ruling by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) that networking agreements may breach the 60 per cent audience reach limit allowing networks to participate in the benefits of the regional licences, thereby breaching section 89a (1) (b). Since the aggregation of our regional markets relies heavily on these agreements, we accept that some action clearly had to be taken. It is already on the record that the Australian Democrats were opposed to the aggregation process from the beginning because we were concerned about the potential effects of this on local content.

The policies of the Hawke Government have been directly responsible for the emergence of the three major networks in Australia. With the Hawke Government policy of aggregation, regional television monopolies are to be broken down. The pressure is now on for closer affiliation agreements and, because of the small number of networks, the regionals are virtually compelled to align themselves with one of these networks.

The Democrats accept that regional viewers deserve to have the same choice of programs that their city counterparts have and are conscious of the widespread support there is for aggregation, particularly in rural areas. While we have reservations with respect to the aggregation of our regional television markets, we would have to say that to dismantle networking agreements at this stage-as the Opposition amendments are suggesting-would, in our opinion, be most destructive.

Of course, when considering the Opposition's attitude to these clauses of the Bill, it must be remembered that it has a policy of 100 per cent audience reach, which is essentially a nationwide aggregation policy. Indeed, paragraph 2.2 of the Opposition's communications policy states that it will ensure the availability of a wider range of television services through aggregation in regional areas.

One area of concern to the Democrats relates to the access that regional stations will have to programs the networks purchase but choose not to show. This is an important issue as the networks have purchased much of the overseas product. The networking agreements, which I have had an opportunity to sight, allow this access. I hope that future negotiated agreements will also allow this access. I expect this to be an issue the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will consider when looking at the networking agreements that are lodged with it.

The Opposition has stated that it feels that regional stations will become chained to the wheels of the networks. The Democrats recognise the potential that networking agreements provide for the networks to exert control over regionals and are concerned to ensure that this does not eventuate. The experience of the United States with respect to networking agreements shows us that certain rights of the regional stations do need to be protected. These include the affiliate's right to reject any network program it does not want to purchase; its right to show programs at the time of its choice; and its right to purchase programs from whichever network it chooses.

The amendment I am moving to this clause will, I believe, ensure that the autonomy of the regional stations involved in networking agreements is protected. My amendment alters the definition of a networking agreement to include a proviso that networking agreements are valid `if and only if the agreement does not require either party to broadcast any particular programs or broadcast programs at a specific time, and does not prevent purchase from other networks'. This amendment will clarify the limits of networking agreements. It will provide the regional stations with a legislative reference where they believe the networks are in fact seeking to exercise control over their programming. Importantly, it will outlaw the `must buy' program clauses that the Federal Communications Commission in the United States identified as a major means by which networks in America exerted control over regional stations.

The amendment will not impose any additional requirements on the parties involved in the agreements. The amendment will ensure that networking agreements are mutually beneficial. If the Opposition is serious-as I believe it is-in its concern for regional stations, then I ask it to consider supporting this amendment, because the reality is that we will be supporting networking exemptions. The Opposition needs to consider the regionals' position in the light of this reality. What will the regionals say if in a couple of years the networks attempt to impose `must buy' conditions on the regionals?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not support these amendments. The Government recognises that it is only through effective and equitable networking arrangements that commercial broadcasters can provide the high quality broadcasting services they currently provide to the public. These proposed amendments would impinge to some extent on legitimate arrangements agreed between networks and affiliates. I notice that Senator Alston's circulated amendments go much further than that, but these proposed amendments would impinge on the networking arrangements-for example, to carry national advertising, which I know the commercial regional station in my area would be dead without, which are programs for the purpose of the Broadcasting Act.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments also purport to introduce matters currently adequately covered by the Bill. The Bill confers no protection on agreements which do not provide for the supply of programs; hence paragraph (b) of these Democrat amendments is superfluous. This is also the case with paragraph (c), since under proposed section 89 (2) protection is accorded only to bona fide terms relating to the supply of programs. In respect of the business relationship created by those terms and the dependence of the licensee on that supply for the provision of that service under the licence, restricted trade practices are not covered by the protection of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) has indicated, the Opposition's amendment seeks to omit the current provision. I do not wish to canvass all the matters dealt with more than adequately in the House of Representatives during the course of debate there, but I invite the Minister to indicate whether the Government has had any second thoughts or whether it is now in a better position to respond to some of the matters raised by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) at that time. The Opposition is particularly concerned about the term `lodged', so that a networking agreement merely has to be lodged with the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, but otherwise there is no requirement for it to be further considered. That would seem to be in conflict with the requirements of proposed section 89, which involves the Tribunal in giving its active written consent.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition does not support these amendments moved by the Australian Democrats. We see them as not only emasculating the current provision, but also effectively trying to turn the clock back and wishing in many ways that an audience reach limit as generous as the 60 per cent provided for in the legislation had never come into existence. The Opposition does not take that view. Although there might not be much inclination for going down that track at present, we think that it ought to be possible. In the meantime, agreements ought to be capable of being scrutinised and, if necessary, approved by the Tribunal.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that arrangements have to be lodged. By so doing, they come to the attention of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in a public way and can, by that simple lodgment, be taken into consideration by the Tribunal in bringing into effect all the other provisions of the legislation in respect of control and so on. At this stage I indicate that the Government will not support these amendments.
—Would the Minister explain what is meant by `coming to the attention of the Tribunal in a public way'? Does that mean that any networking agreements will be available for public scrutiny?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the normal practice of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is to make these documents public, the whole purpose of the exercise being to provide public purview of the process.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 5.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Clause 5, page 3, subclause (2), lines 6 to 10, omit the subclause, insert the following subclause:

(2) Without limiting the application of the amendment made by paragraph (1) (a) to licences granted by way of renewal or further renewal after the commencement of this section, that amendment also applies to licences in force on that commencement otherwise than because of subsection 87 (3) of the Principal Act.''.

The Bill increases the maximum licence renewal period from three to five years and clause 5 (2) of the Bill is a transitional provision setting out which licences will have that increased renewal period. There was a defect in the original clause 5 (2), in that as it was originally drafted it prevented the increase in the maximum renewal period to licences in categories when they were subsequently renewed; that is, licences that were being subjected to processes of the Tribunal. This amendment omits the original clause 5 (2) and substitutes a new clause which recognises that the increase in the maximum licence renewal period in clause 5 (1) (a) applies to licences renewed after commencement. It also applies the increase from three to five years to licences in force on commencement, other than those in force because of subsection 87 (3); that is, those that are being applied to Tribunal processes. The amendment makes no express reference to licences in force at the commencement for a period of less than three years as the amendment in clause 5 (1) (a) would not operate to increase the period that those licences continue in force.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will oppose this clause. Part of the motivation behind this amendment could well be to reduce some of the workload of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. However, I believe the Government has approached it from the wrong direction. The Democrats believe that the solution to the Broadcasting Tribunal's backlog of work is not simply to remove some of the very important work that it does. Instead, it is to give the Tribunal sufficient resources to enable it to undertake sufficiently each and every one of its important tasks.

SPEECH.PARA: When the areas of inquiry that wanted the attention of the Tribunal were originally identified, the issue of the three-year licence renewal was seen as sufficiently important. To my knowledge, nothing has happened in the intervening period to make three-year licence inquiries less important. Given the current state of the Australian broadcasting industry, I would argue that this is considerably more important. I believe the Tribunal is being snowed under in its work as a direct response of chronic underfunding by this Government. Simply to say that the solution to this underfunding is to reduce the issues into which the Tribunal need inquire is unacceptable to the Democrats. I believe this a highly inappropriate time to extend licence periods. Licensees are facing financial turmoil. We have the uncertain effects of aggregation and new requirements for Australian content. With these conditions prevailing, I believe that more rather than less Tribunal oversight is required.

With a five-year licence, a licensee's service may be inadequate for two years but not attract any Tribunal sanctions because of an improvement in the last two years before renewal. We do not seem to be able to trust our politicians for five years, and I do not believe that it is unreasonable to review the performance of our media owners once every three years. As such, the Democrats are opposing this Government amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —We trust you for six.
—Not me.
—Senator Alston cannot be certain of six years. Also, the Democrats are opposing the extension of licence periods from three to five years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose the amendment of the Australian Democrats. The official position is that we support the Government, but might I say that from my experience of following the peregrinations of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, it is quite clear that an enormous amount of time, energy and resources is wasted on the current exercises. In many ways, I think there is a much better case for having a perpetual licence which is capable of being revoked at any time if sufficient cause is shown. I might say that this is not a revolutionary proposal; it is one that has been adopted in other countries. It enables automatic renewal after whatever period.

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment, there is the worst of all possible worlds where, in theory, at the end of each period of three years a person could lose his licence because someone wants to lodge a heavy objection. He would get some warning of that, but quite often not sufficient. So a licensee has to prepare for that hearing as though his life is at stake. People will put some months of effort into preparing a case on the off chance that it might be opposed or that someone might want to argue that the licensee is no longer a fit and proper person.

It seems to me that that is quite an inappropriate way of handling the business. There is no reason why we ought not be entitled to continue to have a licence until we forfeit our right to do so. We could forfeit that right at any time. If a person has just been granted a three-year licence and commits an offence three months down the track, why should that person then have two years and nine months of sanctity.

Whilst we go along with five-year licences mostly because of what the Tribunal has said about unnecessary licence renewal hearings-I notice that in many ways the Government really has not really fixed that up; it could have network hearings rather than individual licence hearings-the fact is that there is an enormous amount of time wasted that could be much better spent in all sorts of other areas of scrutiny, if that is the way to go.

My preference would be that once a person is granted a licence there is a presumption that he is entitled to retain that licence until he takes some action that puts it in jeopardy, in which case he will get a show cause summons and will then have to defend himself against a real charge-not against the prospect that every three years he might find himself in big trouble. We are content in the interim to go along with a five-year term.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is perfectly true, as Senator Kernot has said, that one of the purposes of this amendment is to reduce the workload on the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, but I can assure Senator Kernot that that purpose has not simply been prompted by a desire of the Government not to spend more money on more hearings of the Tribunal. It has been very largely based on the Tribunal's own experience that it is unnecessary to review the performance of licensees every three years.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has accepted that an extension to five years as the maximum period is necessary to have an appreciable impact on the Tribunal's workload and to enable it to devote more resources to substantive rather than formal scrutiny of licensee performance. The Government accepts that five-year renewals would still allow public interest groups and concerned citizens adequate opportunity to participate in the evaluation process. In this respect we note that if circumstances warrant it the Tribunal, as the legislation quite clearly says, still has the discretion to renew for less than the maximum period and also retains the power to inquire into matters of real concern at any time.

The amendment proposed would not improve public participation in the evaluation of licensee performance and could in fact have an adverse effect on it by denying the Tribunal the very free use of its resources to address issues of substance, both at licence renewals and during the specific inquiries that the Tribunal has the power to hold from time to time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak on the Government amendment for two reasons. Firstly, I acknowledge the points that were made by Senator Alston with regard to the problem of the time of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT). Certainly, as it is currently staffed and equipped, the ABT does have some concerns about the amount of time that is available to it to discharge its functions under the legislation. Of course, that is something that we should be aware of and should address, but more particularly it is something that the Government should be aware of. It should provide the Tribunal with the resources necessary for it to cope with its workload in a manner which enables it to discharge its functions adequately and fully.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, I was given certain guarantees some years ago by the Government. Those guarantees were with respect to broadcast and program standards. I raise that now in case the Department of Transport and Communications has forgotten about it. I have not. If the Government goes into an election or reneges on the agreement that was made on that occasion, certainly it will hear from me and from a lot of others. It was before the time of the Minister, so he may not know what I am talking about-but I am sure that the Department, the Tribunal, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and quite a lot of other people do. I simply make that point.

I also make that point in the context of the Broadcasting Tribunal's document TV Violence in Australia, which is order of the day No. 1 relating to Government documents. I do not want to anticipate debate on that document, but my fear is that there is a trend within the Department to suggest that there should be self-regulation. Self-regulation by whom? It would be by interest groups-that is, by the persons who are interested.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you tell them what interest groups?

—When I say interest groups, I mean groups such as television organisations. I would be inclined to start reminding the Government of what it undertook on that occasion. I have not done so for some years, but I thought it appropriate to do so now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly understand what Senator Harradine is discussing. It is perfectly appropriate for him to issue this warning about the matter to the Government at this stage, but I simply point out-I am sure that Senator Harradine would agree-that the particular amendment that is before the Committee is not directed to the question of changing standards. I certainly note Senator Harradine's observations about standards.
—I was doing it for the Department's sake more than for the Government's sake.
—I have taken that on board.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 6.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3. Clause 6, page 3, proposed subsections 89a (11), (12) and (13), lines 22 to 36, omit the subsection.

As I said in the second reading debate, my primary concern with clause 6 is that, if a situation is serious enough to warrant an inquiry in the first place, I think it is inappropriate to deem approval for the transaction simply because six months has elapsed. Indeed, it may be more appropriate to deem rejection rather than approval where an inquiry is incomplete after a prescribed period. If this Bill is passed, and I am sure that it will be, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will be required to inquire only into issues of significance. What is a matter of significance is always a matter for debate. I believe that issues such as licence transfers have very significant repercussions for the industry as a whole, and simply to turn around and say that, because six months has elapsed, a transfer should be approved is not, I believe, sufficient.

I recognise that the option is there for the Tribunal to extend the period of the inquiry where it feels that this is appropriate, but if because of some extenuating circumstance the Tribunal neglects to extend the inquiry, the inquiry will be closed and the licence transfer will be approved by default. To avoid the so-called deemed approval of transfer inquiries, the Aus- tralian Democrats have drawn up the amendment that I have moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will oppose this amendment. It is not quite as Senator Kernot says, that a transfer will be deemed to have been approved if within six months the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has not completed its work. The proposal places what I do not think is a particularly onerous requirement on the Tribunal to deal with the matters before it expeditiously. The only other requirement that it places on the Tribunal, and I think it is a very reasonable one, is that, if it has not completed its work during that time, it is required to publish written reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to what Senator Kernot said about a situation in which the Tribunal neglects to do that or forgets to do it--

TALK.START.PARA: —The ADJR can compel it.

—That is true, but considering how simple that procedure is and how it would flow from the matter not being dealt with in six months, I would find it very surprising if such a circumstance did arise. But there are avenues available through the administrative decisions judicial review procedure to take that into account. Frankly, without getting into that matter, I do not think the requirement on the Tribunal to deal with the issues before it in terms of maintaining the public respect that is required for its credibility and to provide the degree of certainty and stability in the industry that the industry is looking for is an unreasonable requirement. I think the parties would be entitled to get a written explanation if the Tribunal failed in that respect.
-I ask the Minister: if this written explanation is given, what will happen to the licence in the meantime?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation is that the licence will continue while the matter continues to be reviewed, providing the Tribunal carries out what it is obliged to do under the Act and gives a written reason as to why the inquiry is taking more time.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. Clause 6, pages 3 and 4, proposed subsections 89a (14) and (15), line 37 (page 3) to line 13 (page 4), omit the subsections.

Senator Kernot's amendment dealt with subclauses (11), (12) and (13). Mine deals with subclauses (14) and (15). Suffice it to say that the Opposition takes the view that the Government ought to adhere to the advice proffered it by the Department of Transport and Communications, that the Tribunal ought to be in a position to decide whether these affiliation agreements or network agreements provide sufficient flexibility, whereas the insertion of these subsections means that there will simply be no choice in the matter. That will put a number of things at risk in the event that the networking agreement requires the regional stations to take programs direct in the metropolitan area. It may well mean a dearth, if not the death, of localism. We have that particular concern, so we seek to omit those two proposed subsections.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —All of the Opposition's amendments 1 to 4 are, as Senator Alston has said, directed in effect to one end, and that is to addressing the question of networking. There has been some debate on that matter not just in the Committee but in the second reading debate today. Amendments 1 to 4 are intended to remove the networking exemptions from the Bill. As the Government has indicated, it will be opposing them. That exemption was included because the News case in the Solicitor-General's opinion indicates that the current networking arrangements whereby affiliate services take the majority of their programs from a network may give the network the control of the affiliate and therefore place the network in breach of the ownership and control requirements of the Act and allow the network to participate in the benefit of the licence without the approval of the Tribunal, contrary to the Act. That is the purpose of the Opposition's amendments, as Senator Alston has explained. They are all directed to that end.

SPEECH.PARA: The sum effect of all that-one either agrees with it or one does not-is that these amendments, if carried, would have the very profound effect of precluding effective networking arrangements from Australian television. Not only would that negate agreements freely entered into and, I would argue, of benefit to both broadcasters and the viewing public, but also it would effectively destroy the level of service offered the public. I am sure that Senator Alston, even in moving these amendments, would not agree with Senator Crichton-Browne that it would be satisfactory to have local television broadcasters having sufficient budgets in terms of the advertising revenue available to them only to broadcast home movies.

If it did not go that far, it would certainly lead to a severe diminution in the standard of the programs that are broadcast. The cost of negotiating program rights on a station by station basis would be prohibitive, and without the guarantee of program and national advertising sales to affiliates-I simply have to reflect on the effect it would have in my own area of Australia-no licensee on its own could afford to commission the quality Australian and overseas programs we have come to expect. By and large, by international comparisons, we have high quality broadcasting in Australia.

No advertiser would be able to make satisfactory arrangements for national advertising, and regional viewers could expect to see the policy of equalisation, which is bringing them the benefits of the same level of service enjoyed by their city cousins, and I must say one only--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mean bankruptcy?

—As I informed Senator Alston earlier in the debate, I think it is highly arguable on analysis that that has any impact on the real reason for the very high flying that took place in that industry to come to earth with a thud. There is no question at all in remote Australia as to what the viewers think of the benefits of equalisation. They support it--
—That would mean five prosperous channels.

—Indeed, what Senator Alston has said is the reality of the situation, and he would be perfectly correct. The effect of these amendments-again, whether one agrees or disagrees with them-if they are carried, would be to destroy those arrangements. It would bring a very radical change in effectively eliminating those arrangements, as the amendments-Senator Alston has been quite forthright about it-would simply go to removing the current networking provisions in Australian television and, for that reason, the Government will be opposing the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will also be opposing this amendment. I indicated earlier that it was on a vote, I understand, of the Australian Labor Party and the National Party of Australia that this policy of aggregation went through; the Democrats did not vote for it. However, now that it is in place, we are very reluctant to take the destructive action that would eventuate from this amendment to dismantle something which has already seen investments of millions of dollars by the television industry. So the Democrats will be opposing this amendment.

` ``loan agreement'', in relation to a company, means an agreement under which:
(a) money is lent or advanced to the company; or
(b) money is deposited with the company; or
(c) a debt or liability (whether or not financial) of the company arises;
whether or not:
(d) the money, debt or liability is secured; or

These are straightforward amendments. Subsection 89e (1) of the Act contains a definition of the term `control' for the purposes of part IIIba of the Act. The definition provides in paragraph (c) that, when used in relation to a company, `control' has the meaning given by section 89k. Clause 11 (a) of the Bill amends paragraph (c) of the definition to give `control' the meaning in new section 89kb as well. This amendment will make paragraph (c) of the definition of `control' subject to new section 89kb as a consequence of the insertion of new section 89kb by amendment No. 9.

Amendment No. 6 inserts a new definition of `loan agreement' in subsection 89e (1) as a consequence of new section 89kb being inserted by amendment No. 9. The definition is intended to include the types of financing agreements which are commonly used in financial transactions.
