(c) a corporation whose sole or principal business is the making of loans to other persons, being a corporation:
(i) that is registered as a financial institution under the Financial Corporations Act 1974; or
(ii) in respect of which a declaration under subsection (5) is in force; or
(iii) in respect of which an application for such a declaration has been made but not finally disposed of;
``controller'', in relation to an authorised lender, means a person in a position to exercise control of the lender;
``media company'' means:
(a) a company that holds a commercial licence; or
(b) a company that publishes a newspaper; or
(c) a company that is in a position to exercise control of a company referred to in paragraph (a) or (b).
`(2) Subject to subsections (3) and (4), where an authorised lender has a loan agreement with a media company, then, for the purposes of this Part:
(a) the agreement; and
(b) any arrangement, mortgage or other transaction associated with the agreement; and
(c) any rights or powers of the lender under the agreement or such a transaction; and
(d) the exercise of any of those rights or powers;
are to be disregarded in determining whether, or to what extent, the lender or any controller of the lender is in a position to exercise control of:
(e) the company; or
(f) the acts and operations of the company; or
(g) the votes, of which the company is in a position to exercise control, in another company.
`(3) Where:
(a) the media company holds, or is in a position to exercise control of a company that holds, a commercial licence; and
(b) the authorised lender or a controller of the lender:
(i) exercises control over persons or matters in such a way as to prevent the licensee complying with a condition of the licence; or
(ii) controls the selection or provision of the programs to be broadcast pursuant to the licence;

then subsection (2) does not apply in determining whether, or to what extent, the lender or that person is in a position to exercise control of the media company or of a matter referred to in paragraph (2) (f) or (g).
`(4) Where:
(a) the media company publishes, or is in a position to exercise control of a company that publishes, a newspaper; and
(b) the authorised lender or a controller of the lender controls the selection or provision of the material to be published in the newspaper;

then subsection (2) does not apply in determining whether, or to what extent, the lender or the person is in a position to exercise control of the media company or of a matter referred to in paragraph (2) (f) or (g).

`(5) The Tribunal may, in writing, declare a corporation (whether formed inside or outside Australia) whose sole or principal business is the making of loans to other persons to be an authorised lender for the purposes of this section.'.''.
(10) Clause 17, page 8, at the end of the clause add the following subclause:

``(2) During the 3 months beginning on the commencement of this section, a corporation whose sole or principal business is the making of loans to other persons is an authorised lender for the purposes of section 89KB and 92M of the Principal Act as amended by this Act.''.

Amendment No. 7 simply makes a drafting change to clause 17. Amendment No. 8 clarifies the impact of the joint control, by confining its operation to situations where persons act together to be in a position to exercise actual control rather than deemed control; that is, `control' as defined by section 89 of the Act.

Amendment No. 9 inserts a new section into section 89 under clause 17. The new section would exempt the loan agreements of authorised lenders from being taken into account in determining to what extent the authorised lender or a person in a position to control that lender is in a position to exercise control of a media company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After proposed subparagraph 89kb (3) (b) (ii), insert the following new word and subparagraph: ``or
(iii) exercises direction or restraint over any substantial issue relating to the conduct of operations under the licence;''.

This is to amend Government amendment No. 9. The Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 2), as the Minister has said, will abolish the registered lenders scheme. In practice, this scheme was not terribly effective and there was a need to review the process. As such, the Australian Democrats are not staunchly opposed to its abolition. However, we do believe that it is essential that we retain some form of scrutiny over lenders to commercial licensees. The new legislation proposes a broader definition of `control' and the banks have expressed a concern that this definition will, through normal loan covenants, deem them to be in control of broadcast stations. Because the banks have lent to a number of media outlets, they may then be in breach of a number of ownership and control limitations. The Minister has just quoted from the explanatory memorandum, ending with this section:
. . . to what extent the authorised lender or a person in a position to control that lender is in a position to exercise control of a media company.
These exemptions will apply as long as the banks do not attempt to-and again I quote:
(1) exercise control over persons or matters in such a way as to prevent the licensee complying with the condition of the licence; or
(2) control the selection or provision of programs to be broadcast pursuant to the licence.

The purpose of these two qualifying conditions is to ensure that, while the banks are exempted from the ownership and control provisions, they do not in fact attempt to exercise control over broadcast stations. One needs only a cursory glance at the state of television in this country at present to see the need for these sorts of limitations. I note that a number of media commentators seem to be of the opinion that the banks are already effectively controlling two of our major networks. So we need to consider the Government amendment in this case very carefully, because the basis of tribunal scrutiny of the industry is very much determined by the new definition of `control' that this Bill will be implementing. It is absolutely crucial.

To exempt any party from this definition of control will be to allow it to act basically independent of the Broadcasting Act and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. In recognition of this very fact, the Government has included in its amendments the two qualifying conditions for the exemption that I have mentioned earlier. If we are to place authorised lenders outside the scope of control, I believe we need to be very careful that we do not allow them free rein over our broadcast stations. In case honourable senators think this is being a little paranoid, they need only look at what is happening with the Ten network.

Government amendments to section 92m of the principal Act, which we will look at later, will provide the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal with the power to issue directions at any time to a person, including a registered lender, who is in a position of control of a commercial licence in order to protect a licence. Previously the Tribunal could take this course of action only when an inquiry was in progress. Fortunately, in the Ten network case, an inquiry was being conducted which allowed the Tribunal much closer oversight of the changes at Ten than it otherwise would have had.

The Democrats welcome the new powers under section 92m and also the two qualifying restrictions on the activities of the banks. We believe, however, that these restrictions do not go far enough in ensuring the autonomy of broadcast stations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the thrust of the Democrats' argument in this matter. The Government believes that the principal role of the Broadcasting Act is simply to protect the service to the public, not to protect the peripheral business arrangements of licensees that do not relate to programming or to the ability of licensees to meet their licence conditions. If lenders go beyond that, they will be subject, properly, to the scrutiny of the Tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: To the extent that the proposed amendment goes beyond the Government's own proposals, and this does seem uncertain, it can only intrude-and I think would intrude-into the normal business arrangements between licensees and their lenders. The Government sees no role in those arrangements where they do not affect programming or compliance by licensees of their licence conditions. On that basis the Government will be opposing this amendment because, firstly, we believe it is superfluous and, secondly, we believe that its effect will be very uncertain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: -I believe my amendment will in no way impede the normal commercial practices that go on between the banks and the licensee companies. It will, however, clearly draw the line between these normal practices and those situations where the banks may seek to exert some control over the licensee. I have no doubt that banks are very closely scrutinising the operations of the stations that they have lent to. Given the financial status of the two networks, the banks would be crazy not to be doing this.

SPEECH.PARA: I am happy for the banks to conduct these sorts of analyses, but I am not happy with them interfering with the day-to-day running of the stations. Where there are huge losses there will need to be some fairly significant changes made to the operation of broadcast stations and some rationalisation is inevitable. I am not opposed to this if, in the long run, it will help our broadcasting industry get back on its feet.

I believe, however, that the Tribunal needs to have some oversight of this process in order to ensure that the public interest-I, too, am concerned about the public interest-is protected. While the industry is in such a vulnerable financial position, we must provide some protection to it and to the viewing public. I believe that the amendment I have proposed will do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, the difficulty the Government has with this amendment is that it gets to the question of what is a direction or restraint. Lending institutions commonly incorporate in their lending agreements clauses which sensibly and without question restrain the person getting the loan from dissipating the assets which are purchased with that loan without the prior consent of the lender. I do not think there is much question that there would be uncertainty as to the effect it would have in what I believe would have to be interpreted by a court as a restraint. It would make it absolutely impossible, if that sensible provision were removed or made inoperable by these amendments, for institutions to lend money to television licensees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: -Amendment Nos 6, 7 and 8 standing in my name deal with the whole issue of prior approval, or prior notification, which is another crucial issue, I believe, in the broadcasting debate. Rather than seeking to strengthen the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's hand with respect to the transaction approval process, the clauses of this Bill will, I believe, actually weaken the Tribunal by removing the obligation for parties to transactions to give the Tribunal prior notification of those transactions.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats believe that not only is this prior notification essential to the efficient operation of our broadcasting regulator but also that this power should be extended to require prior Australian Broadcasting Tribunal approval of ownership changes. Senator Alston will probably say we are trying to turn the clock back again. Of course, it was the infamous Murdoch amendments of 1981 which removed the prior approval requirement.

In its report The Role and Functions of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal of November 1988, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure said it believed:
The present system of approvals after the event does not provide the Tribunal with the capacity to supervise changes in ownership and control effectively.

The Committee also noted that, without prior approval, ownership changes have become a case of trying to unscramble eggs for the Tribunal. An example of this was radio station 3DB which changed hands five times in seven months in 1987, with the final change taking place before the Tribunal had completed its report on the first transaction. Another example clearly highlighting the Tribunal's powerlessness was the situation where the original purchase of the Nine network by Bond Media had not been approved before the Bond group had sold the network. As such, no inquiry needs to be held into Mr Kerry Packer's purchase-or should I say repurchase-of the Nine network. Perhaps of greater concern is the fact that the Tribunal was powerless to oversee any of the restructuring that occurred in radio and television back in 1986-87. We are now, I believe, seeing the shake-out of that restructuring.

Once a share transaction has occurred, if the Tribunal decides not to approve the transaction its only option to date has been to order divestiture-which is rarely acting in the public interest. The Tribunal's post-hoc approval process for ownership changes means that there may be significant managerial, staff or programming changes or other changes in the operation of the licence before the Tribunal has made a determination. A report by the Department of Transport and Communications Broadcasting Review Group in July 1989 entitled A Review of Broadcasting Regulation Discussion Paper stated:

By the time a decision could be made by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in relation to a transaction that had already occurred, structural or other changes to the company in respect of which the shares were acquired could make it difficult and possibly disruptive to effect a divestiture.

An example of this occurred when Broadcom (Australia) Pty Ltd first bought the 10 Network and there were major changes in staffing and operations before the Tribunal had held an inquiry. More recently, Kerry Packer's return to Channel 9 and the subsequent sackings that occurred clearly demonstrated the significant changes that can take place very rapidly under the direction of a new owner.

Under the current system new owners may be in breach of cross-media ownership limits, audience reach restrictions or other ownership and control provisions. Not only does the system allow this but it also allows a new owner to maintain control for a substantial length of time before attracting Tribunal sanctions. The infamous Skase incident, where stations were purchased in excess of the 60 per cent audience reach limit with a certain arrogant confidence that the legislation would be changed before Mr Skase would have to divest, was a blatant disregard of this Act. On a recent Four Corners program the Acting Chairman of the Broadcasting Tribunal, Mr Peter Westerway, stated that he believed the Tribunal's public interest powers should be reinstated.

The Department of Transport and Communications report to which I referred earlier concluded that `a limited prior approval requirement directed at significant ownership changes may now be appropriate under the Act'. It may come as a surprise to some people that broadcasting regulators in overseas countries have this prior approval power. This morning we were talking about foreign ownership requirements in other countries and indeed the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) used these overseas examples which I had used as support for why 20 per cent was a reasonable figure. The Federal Communications Commission in the United States has prior approval power, as does the Canadian Radio Television and Telecommunications Commission. As a consequence of having this power these countries have not experienced the sorts of problems that we have in Australia.

The Australian Democrats believe that in the public interest the Broadcasting Tribunal needs to be empowered to issue or withhold approval of share transactions that affect the ownership or control of licenses prior to those transactions taking place. The integrity of the licensing process must be ensured and, as such, the prior approval system for major changes in ownership or control of licences needs to be reintroduced. We believe that the prior approval process should be imposed only on those transactions involving real issues of control-that is, any purchases of 15 per cent of shares or more or any purchases which confer significantly greater control.

We believe the Tribunal should be provided with the discretion to conduct inquiries into lesser purchases where it believes that this is warranted. Importantly, the Tribunal needs to be adequately funded to ensure that these inquiries can be performed expeditiously. Prior to the 1981 amendments the delays involved in conducting inquiries-which have been referred to already this evening-often frustrated proposed transactions because of rapid share trading and allowed other companies time to interfere with the transactions. We would need to ensure that normal commercial practices were not seriously disrupted by the reintroduction of the prior approval process. The experience of the United States and Canada shows us that the prior approval system is indeed workable. I believe it should be reinstated in this country as soon as possible.

The Democrats' initial intention was to draft our own amendments to install a prior approval process. However, it would have necessitated a virtual rewrite of the Bill and, as it had little prospect of passing the Senate and would have consumed a huge amount of the Senate budget, we did not proceed with this. I would, however, urge the Government to take my comments and those of many in the industry on board and to look to reintroducing the prior approval system in the major review of legislation which is currently under way. Clause 20 (e) will remove the prior notification requirement. For the Tribunal to at least be given the chance to function efficiently, it must be provided with all possible information. Without this information the Tribunal's already formidable task becomes much more difficult.

It seems incredible to me that on this very day, when we are hearing so much about print media, we should be seeking to water down the powers of the regulatory body in the broadcasting media. The new powers given to the Tribunal under proposed new subsection 92m will assist, but the Tribunal needs to have access to information as soon as that information is available. We therefore oppose the removal of prior notification.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will oppose these amendments. The difficulty we have in accepting them is that the amendments with respect to these particular clauses relating to radio licensing and the subsequent amendments that the Australian Democrats will move with respect to television would simply remove all of the basic efficiencies that the Government is proposing to introduce. Of course, the Democrats have canvassed their view on this matter earlier but, as I have said, the Government believes that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal should be concerned with matters of substance and not with what can be irrelevant transactions on both sides of the argument-that is, where the interest is known to be minuscule or, on the other side of the argument, where the interest or control is known to be absolute. There is very little point served by the Tribunal examining an increase in a person's interests if the person is already clearly in control of the licensee. What point is served by the Tribunal examining interests too small to be of any real influence, or, as I have said before, examining interests that are known to be in control simply because they are required to go through that process and waste a great deal of resources in so doing?

SPEECH.PARA: The Tribunal will be informed of interests in licensees and will be able to inquire into them if it thinks fit. But it should not be required to waste its resources on formal exercises. Having said that, as I have also made clear, it should then be accountable for its actions. The Government therefore wishes, I think reasonably, to see the Tribunal either complete ownership or control inquiries within six months or give written reasons why it cannot. For this reason the Government opposes the amendments, but it also opposes them because they will have the effect of validating the current situation where persons holding excess interests can demand and expect-and no doubt get-repeated extensions of time in which to dispose of those interests. Under the amendments only one such extension would be possible, which again I think is reasonable.

The Bill will ensure that the Tribunal can concentrate its resources on matters of substance. In those circumstances, it is reasonable for the Tribunal to deal with those matters quickly and for persons with excess interests to be expected to comply with the requirements of the Act within a reasonable period. The reason why we will be opposing these amendments and also the amendments to clauses 27 and 28 is that if they are agreed to they will fundamentally destroy all of the efficiencies the Government is looking for with this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: -I ask the Minister: what is the status of consideration of reintroduction of prior approval in the review of broadcasting legislation currently under way? Is it totally discounted at this stage?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: -This Government amendment will allow the Tribunal to step in at any time and issue directions to a person in a position to control a broadcast licence in order to protect the licence. This, too, is a vital amendment. As I said when speaking to Government amendment No. 9, the Australian Democrats welcome these new powers. In the past, the Tribunal has been empowered to issue these directions only in situations where a transaction inquiry is taking place.

SPEECH.PARA: Back in September we had an example where the Tribunal was able to give directions to the 10 Network's bankers only because there was a transaction inquiry being undertaken. It was this case which clearly highlighted one of the deficiencies in the powers of the Tribunal. I have highlighted a number of cases earlier in this debate. We welcome the Government's moves to rectify this deficiency and we hope the experience with Network 10 has been a lesson for the Government and that it takes this on board in this long awaited fundamental review of broadcasting.

It is clear, I believe, that whatever body we are to have to regulate this industry that the powers provided to it must be sufficient to enable it to protect the public interest in all cases. I believe that this particular amendment will ensure this protection and it has the support of the Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

SPEECH.PARA: 5. After clause 29, page 27, insert the following clause:
Review of decisions
``29a. Section 119a of the Principal Act is amended by inserting after paragraph (1) (g) the following paragraph:
`(1) (gaaa) a direction by the Tribunal under subsection 92m (1aa);'.''.

The amendment to section 92m, which provides very far reaching powers to give directions to protect licensees, clearly has to be exercised with caution. We think this amendment should certainly be the subject of review where necessary by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. On its face, it provides quite open-ended and draconian powers, which may or may not be exercised properly, which may or may not be reasonable in the circumstances, but which could have very significant secondary effects on a whole range of potential players, be they bankers, creditors or accountants.

We all know that one can have unintended consequences in this area, as we saw recently with the bid by Asahi for shares in Elders IXL Ltd, which Senator Collins and I discussed in this chamber. One could have a situation which was never contemplated where, by dint of a series of interlocking transactions, one could have an ability to control a licence-something that never occurred to one in the first place when one simply bought shares in a quiet little manufacturing company that was subsequently discovered to have shares in a media organisation.

Looking at the way in which the ability to influence or be in a position to exercise control is defined in section 89ja, taking it at its highest point, a person could exercise control merely by virtue of being in a position in any manner to indirectly exercise restraint over any substantial issue affecting the management or affairs of a company. That is nebulous in the extreme. It is very unpredictable and may well give rise to a determination by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal that was not contemplated by a range of parties, and certainly those whose interests may be affected, but not properly taken into account at the time.

We therefore take the view that, just as section 119A prescribes a long list of circumstances in which the power of review is available to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT), particularly where one has a power as sweeping as this to give directions affecting a whole range of third parties, one ought, in fairness and in terms of justice, to be entitled to have that direction by the Tribunal reviewed by the AAT where necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: -I do not think this is a particularly helpful amendment. I understand what Senator Alston is trying to achieve, but the effect of this amendment would be to delay an appeal for, say, three months after the event-and it is an important event which would necessitate an appeal. Within those three months, there is the possibility that asset stripping will take place. As I understand it, avenues for appeal would still be available under the Federal Court and under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. So I do not think that this particular amendment is either helpful or necessary.

—I simply respond to that by saying that it seems an extraordinary proposition that one can acknowledge the virtues of an appeal through the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act mechanism, which would make it a one-off in that sense, and yet section 119, which prescribes a whole list of situations in which one can appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT), Senator Kernot says should not be used because one has other rights. All those other situations attract those similar rights and yet the scheme of the Broadcasting Act is to allow the AAT to build up expertise to review these sorts of decisions. The decisions will not be made lightly. Unless one has a basis for doing it, one will not get to first base. I do not understand why Senator Kernot wishes to have this sort of situation treated differently when it has probably more far-reaching consequences in terms of the width of discretion than almost any other power of the Tribunal.

-I think there is a vital distinction between protective appeals and the rights of that protection and the mechanisms ensuring suitability which are covered under the section that Senator Alston quotes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

The Government did carefully consider whether to allow for Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) review under this particular section. But because the application of this particular section in practice would be in an emergency situation where the Tribunal did have to act very quickly, the Government, having given considerable attention to whether AAT review should be allowed for the reason Senator Kernot has already stated, decided not to.

That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1990. I indicate at the outset that the Opposition is supporting this legislation. We regret that the Bill must be looked at in the context of the Government's appalling corporate reform mess which has occurred in the last three years. I think it can be fairly said that the Government has handled the subject matter with little tact. In many ways it has contributed to the negative response it has received in recent years from the States. It has given little confidence to practitioners in the field, and it took little notice of the constitutional advice it had before it.

SPEECH.PARA: The result has been an enormous waste of money and time, and the Government has done little credit to itself. Regrettably, we still see only half the package. As I understand it, the formal agreement upon which the scheme is based is still to be signed. The regulations which are critical to the application of this law are still to be seen. We have before us an amazing timetable. This is, as I said, at the end of some three years. The Government must have this legislation passed and assented to within the next few days. It must make the regulations, and anyone who knows anything about this area will realise that they will be highly complex. It must have the regulations printed and must then distribute the regulations-all of this in time for a start-up date on 1 January.

This can be seen as nothing more than an appalling indictment of the Government's legislative capacities. It is a total shambles. In the House of Representatives one hour was allowed for debate of this important package. No amendments were allowed. Members were in fact given only a few days notice of the details of the legislation. Why is the Government not now being reasonable and allowing adequate time for consideration? The reason is that it has before it a third commencement date. The first two dates have already passed-1 January 1990 and 1 July 1990, and now it has set for itself 1 January 1991.

The Government would obviously be humiliated if it were unable to meet its third deadline. It would be simply too embarrassing to again delay the package. That is even though such respected bodies as the Law Institute of Victoria are saying publicly that there should be a delay. Why? It is because practitioners obviously are not going to be able to give good advice. The law has not been passed and we are only a few days before the start-up date. Those who have to work to the law, the consumers in the corporate field, clearly will not understand their obligations. No-one could describe that as good law making.

The Law Council of Australia has detailed concerns. It has also had the difficulty of having had the proposed legislation for so short a period of time. Nevertheless, it has sought to meet its responsibility to its members and to the public-it has a public responsibility in this important area which it accepts-by giving advice to the Parliament and to those who are interested. That advice came to us on Monday of this week.

We believe that, at the very least, the concerns of the Law Council should be put before a committee of this Parliament for some more detailed examination. I am pleased that it has now been agreed that the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs will examine those concerns at a meeting tomorrow night. I should stress that these are not concerns on matters of principle, but on matters of detail. I thank the Australian Democrats for their support. I regret to say that I do not think the Government would have been of a mind to give that extra consideration. At least we as a chamber will have done the minimum which was required although, bearing in mind the complexity, the novelty of the federalism solution that is incorporated in this package and the importance of the issues involved, it is still not really a satisfactory examination by the Parliament.

The Government should have learnt the lesson by now of not doing the job properly because it was warned time and time again that the last package was running a major risk of failing to meet the constitutional requirements as they related to the power to legislate for incorporation.

I take a minute or two of the Senate's time to remind the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) and the Government of my presentation, and the presentation of others as well, to the reference in October 1988 of the previous package to a joint committee, when I attempted to draw together all of the pieces of constitutional advice that were before the Senate. I asked the Government seriously to consider the danger of legislating when so many eminent practitioners were advising it that its legislation would fall.

If we look back through the history of the Commonwealth, we see that on a number of occasions it was believed that the Commonwealth's power was inadequate. In fact, there were referendums to change the Commonwealth's power in this area. In 1911, 1913, 1919, 1926-even back in those years-the short cut that the Government was seeking to take was considered to be inadequate. In 1929, the Royal Commission on the Constitution recommended that the Constitution be amended to confer power on the Commonwealth in legislative form in this area. In 1959, the Joint Committee on Constitutional Review recommended that the Constitution be amended to grant this power. The Government's advisory committee to the Constitutional Commission in 1987-the advisory committee on trade and national economic management-recommended constitutional reform to overcome doubts that existed as to the constitutional competence of the Commonwealth to support legislation of this type.

As the Government will be aware, that advice was given only a few months after the conflicting advice of Sir Maurice Byers to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which looked at this matter in 1987. In fact, the Attorney-General's Department, in a submission to the Senate Committee, made it clear that it had doubts as to the constitutional validity of the Commonwealth in this area. It said that there was still room for doubt in these areas.

Then, of course, the Government had before it a joint memorandum of the Solicitors-General of each of the States and the Northern Territory, produced on 9 March 1988, which unanimously questioned the Commonwealth's legal competence in this area. They said that there was at least a reasonable prospect that the High Court of Australia would conclude that the incorporation power of the Commonwealth did not extend to the matters. Advice from the Law Institute of Victoria which was given in August 1988 which the Government had before it was to a similar effect.

There were numerous other advisers-advisers from Mallesons Stephen Jaques, and advisers from the Law Council of Australia which put out its advice on 31 August 1988. It believed it would be irresponsible for the Commonwealth to legislate on the basis of its existing constitutional powers. It said that the Commonwealth should not legislate unless and until the Constitution had been appropriately amended. Despite all of that good advice the Government pressed on and it suffered the consequences when the High Court, on an action brought by the States, found against it. So all of that effort, all of the money that had been spent, the resources of practitioners, and the traumatic debates with the States, had been in effect wasted and the Government had to go back to square one again.

If we had more time, which we have not, I could go through so many other presentations before the Senate during those debates in which the Government was warned of the path it was entering upon. It did not accept the advice. There is no doubt that constitutional reform would be a more ideal way to go, or, as the Law Council has suggested in its advice which I mentioned that it gave to the Senate on Monday of this week, a referral of powers would be a better option than the path the Government has now gone down.

That leads me to discuss briefly what the Government has in fact adopted and what it is seeking to do by this legislation. In many ways it is really a refinement of the former cooperative scheme. A ministerial council remains which will have a consultative role in respect of all legislative proposals and a deliberative role in relation to company law statutes. So in some ways it is still not a national scheme in the sense that it seems the Commonwealth must take initiatives to the ministerial council. Presumably if other than incorporation matters are involved there will again be a need for reciprocal State legislation. The Minister might clarify that point. If that is so, we run the danger that the cooperative scheme ran into after a few years; that is, if the States-under different governments and different attitudes-do not respond with identical reciprocal legislation, it seems to me we are back to the position of inconsistency and lack of certainty.

Company law matters will be particularly important because of the constitutional matter that I raised. One wonders whether this Parliament is still going to achieve the proper parliamentary accountability that has been demanded for so long. It still seems that in many ways this ministerial council intervenes. As I said, we may not end up with the certainty that is required. It is difficult, despite what the Minister says in the second reading speech, to see a single clearly defined line of ministerial responsibility. It is true that there will be one regulatory body, one enforcement body. We on this side of the chamber believe that that is a step in the right direction.

I should say in passing that the State corporate affairs commissions (CACs) actually were not doing a bad job in relation to the enforcement aspects. I know many able practitioners-accountants and from the law-who have worked in the enforcement areas of CACs, particularly in my State of South Australia, and did a good job for many years, but the CACs have received little credit in this package. Certainly, the scheme will provide a national registration and that, we believe, is good.

We have been saying for a long time that because of the nature of business, apart from the very small types of business which some see as being more akin to a partnership form, there is a need for a more national approach and, in some ways, a more international approach. There should be a national registration. Those who trade with Australia should be able to look upon our corporate structures in national terms. That is why we accept that this measure, at least to that extent, is a step in the right direction.

What we have criticised in the past is not that direction but the fact that the Government sought to take it without accepting the requirement for cooperation: cooperation of the States; cooperation of those who practise in the field within the States; and cooperation of the business sector that has to exist under this regulatory regime. For some years the Government fought against the need for that cooperation and ultimately it lost. Even now it seems that it was not prepared to speak to the Opposition parties in Western Australia, and it has lost the opportunity-at least for the time being-of embracing all States within the package. I think that is a matter of regret.

The design of the scheme is for cooperative constitutional legislation and for uniform law and administration by one agency. As I said, we believe that is heading down the right path and we would therefore be prepared to give it support. There is no doubt that in the impossible timetable that the Government has set-because of the shambles it has got itself into in this area over the last three years-there will be shortcomings and flaws in this legislation. Despite our efforts tomorrow night, it will be a responsibility that the Government will have to accept.

I conclude by raising a few other matters. I wonder what has happened to the close corporations aspect, which was seen as so valuable only some months ago but seems to have been dropped off the list in this legislative package. Also, what does the Government propose in relation to small companies that clearly are not of a national context and do not require the same level of regulatory intervention? We on this side of the chamber would certainly be interested in hearing what it intends to do in that regard.

I refute in many ways something that also appears in the Minister's second reading speech-that is, blaming the level of corporate misbehaviour which has occurred in this country in recent years on the shortcomings in the previous legislative scheme. By and large, that is not a fair criticism. It would be much more reasonable for the Government to accept that it is not a question of the shortcomings. I acknowledge that there are still shortcomings in the law, and I intend to mention them in a minute, but in many ways the failure to properly regulate reflected the refusal of the Commonwealth to apply reasonable resources to the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) in its enforcement role.

As a result of that refusal, the NCSC went down this path of seeking to find business solutions to legal problems, to find ways of reaching agreement-some might say doing deals. I have to say that it was a path that I always found uncomfortable. I have mentioned on a number of occasions in this chamber that I regard it as unsatisfactory, but the NCSC was given little choice as a result of being starved of resources. More resources are now being put into enforcement and the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) might be given the credit, but in many ways it is unfair to seek to judge what its future performance will be with much greater funding compared with the past performance of the NCSC.

As I mentioned a moment ago, there are still many areas needing reform. The Government has concentrated over the last three years on its structural reform, to some extent avoiding the qualitative reform that has been necessary, at the very least, to keep up with the major changes in business practice, new technology, the internationalisation of business, and so forth. I notice that the Government tonight even acknowledges areas of shortcoming in relation to loans to directors, insider trading and many other areas. One might say that more effort should have gone into those areas of legislative reform in recent years if the Government was to meet its responsibility.

I also voice the disappointment expressed by the Law Council of Australia that the Government now seems to have departed from its previous practice, which actually commenced before it took office, of providing exposure drafts which gave practitioners a chance to properly examine intended legislation and to produce better quality work as a result. As I said, that has been criticised in this instance by the Law Council. I also think it is a disappointing move in the wrong direction.

In the short time available tonight I simply sum up by saying that the final trend-if this is to be the final trend, although it in turn will have to stand the assessment of the courts and, as I said, it is a novel approach-is one which we nevertheless are prepared to support. We regret that the Government has not accepted the sensitivity of federalism in recent years, that an enormous amount of energy and resources have been lost through the Government's incompetence in this area, and that the uncertainty and failure to legislate properly and meet its responsibilities has also contributed to the poor standing to which some of the corporate world has fallen in recent years. I trust that the Government in its final year or two of office has now learnt that lesson and that it might now get on to some of the other areas of critically important qualitative reform which I outlined a moment ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened to Senator Hill's speech, as I always do. If one understands his speech as Senator Hill no doubt meant it to be understood, one could only agree with much of it.

SPEECH.PARA: I understood Senator Hill to be saying that the thrust of this legislation on corporations, what it aims to achieve and the means it will use in that regard are to be approved, indeed praised, although Senator Hill is less than happy with the method by which the legislation has got to this stage in the Senate. As I understand it, he was criticising the failure of the Government over the years to seek cooperation among the various groups that he says it should have. Indeed, he mentioned the States, the Law Council of Australia and the Law Institute of Victoria. I cannot but agree with him that proper consultation with those bodies and with all the groups with an interest in this legislation should have been carried out. His area of difference with the Government is with its process of consultation and certainly not with the substantive matters with which this legislation deals and the way in which it deals with that legislation.

There has been a great deal of discussion leading to the present legislation. Over the years the matter has been discussed by some very eminent figures. I will take a short time to go through the names of the people who, through this Parliament, contributed mightily to the debate leading to the legislation before us tonight. In that context I should mention, firstly, the report of the Select Committee on Securities and Exchange-Australian Securities Markets and their Regulation-which was presented in this chamber in July 1974. The Chairman of the Committee which prepared that report was Senator Peter Rae. The other people on that Committee also deserve mention and honourable senators will see their eminence: Senator Durack, Senator Georges, Senator Lawrie, Senator Sim, Senator Wheeldon and Senator Wriedt. A former member of the Committee was Senator Cormack.

In the time available to me I also mention the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs-The Role of Parliament in relation to the National Companies Scheme-which was presented to the Senate in April 1987. The Chairman of that Committee when it presented the report was the present Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Nick Bolkus. Prior to that, the inquiry by the Committee had commenced under the chairmanship of Senator Michael Tate, who is presenting this Bill tonight. The Deputy Chairman of that Committee was also of some eminence, being Senator Robert Hill who, although he insisted tonight that there should have been more consultation by the Government with various bodies, certainly had given considerable consideration to these reports. The Government had available to it, not only in this report but also in other reports, the considerable learning of Senator Hill. No doubt he discussed these issues with the various bodies he mentioned tonight. Senator Alston was also on that Committee, as were Senator Puplick and Senator Margaret Reynolds.

A report was presented in the House of Representatives by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs under the chairmanship of Mr Alan Griffiths, who is now the Minister for Resources, with Mr Smith as his Deputy Chairman. The Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation also brought down a report. That Committee was chaired by Mr Ronald Edwards; Senator Jim Short was the Deputy Chairman and the Committee's members included Senator Alston, Senator Macklin from the Australian Democrats, Senator McMullan, Mr Warwick Smith and Mr Duncan Kerr. That Committee went deeply into this legislation and heard witnesses from many sources, including the various sources Senator Hill mentioned tonight.

In November 1989 the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs presented a report on company directors' duties to this chamber. Again it had the privilege of having serve on it Senator Alston, Senator Hill, Senator Pat Giles-who, as everyone would agree, has a fine legal mind which is too often underestimated, although she says she is not legally qualified-Senator Janet Powell, now leader of the Australian Democrats in this chamber, Senator Schacht, and Senator John Stone from Queensland.

I read through the list of people who prepared those reports to illustrate that, although consultation is another matter the Government should undertake, especially in an area like this, there is a limit to the amount of consultation to be undertaken, particularly when the corporate sector is being dealt with, that sector being the one that has the most to do with the economic life of this country.

As Senator Hill said, there is a desperate need to have the framework by which the corporate sector operates in proper order. He agreed to that, although he said, as I understand him, that more consideration should be given to the way that framework is set up. Of course, that is a matter of judgment on his part. In my view, this legislation has been delayed for too long. Given the need, as I have already said, to set up a proper structure within which the economic life of this country must run, it is important to bring this legislation on track as soon as possible.

Far from being critical of the Attorney-General, Mr Duffy for having brought this matter on as rapidly as he has done, I think it is a great credit to him that he has been able to get this legislation before the House and passed, we hope, before Christmas so that it can come into operation by 1 January. I think that Mr Duffy deserves great praise for having guided the legislation to this point. I think he has shown himself to be a great Attorney-General in being able to do so.

He has not been able to do it without the cooperation of two States-Victoria and New South Wales. Mr Kennan in Victoria has been a great advocate of the national scheme and has been of crucial importance in getting this legislation through. Two other people need to be mentioned: Mr Greiner, the Premier of New South Wales, has shown foresight and a generosity, which at times is not present in Premiers of various States, in seeing that this legislation goes through; Mr Dowd, his Attorney-General, deserves considerable praise, which I give him.

Senator Hill says, `It may be that situations arise which would require amendment to this legislation'. That is no reason to stop its passage now. All legislation, particularly legislation as complex as this, does call for amendments from time to time. The very Act is a result of years of amendment, refurbishment and rethinking. No doubt, after this, history will be repeated. As things change, new provisions have to be brought in.

I turn now to some other matters that Senator Hill properly raised. He spoke of the need for proper regulation of corporations and of the lack of regulation during the 1980s. In that context, he spoke of the corporate misbehaviour that we all know of. Companies are central to our business life and, no doubt, dishonesty does occur in business, but it is extrinsic to it; that is, it is outside the normal, proper operations of business.

Insider trading, misuse of shareholders' funds, fraudulent statements in prospectuses, and illegal transfer of funds from one company to another all occur in a corporate sector, but are not intrinsic to its operation whereas production is. It is an essential mark of the business world that it be productive. If it is not, an essential dimension of its nature and purpose is denied. I want to deal quickly with that matter now.

Ugly betrayals of trust, gross misuse of boardroom powers and profligate expenditure of company funds have been rightly condemned in recent times. Laws have been made to meet these evils and are welcomed by the corporate sector as well as by the community generally. No person of decent instincts wants sharp, questionable or criminal practices to be tolerated, whether in the administration of companies or otherwise.

Although these practices seem to have pervaded the business world in the last decade they do not reflect its essential role, which is to carry out Australia's trade and industry. Some important issues arise from that. Parliament and the courts properly punish delinquent conduct in the corporate sector. They are expected to do likewise wherever it appears. But how far should they intervene when the conduct, although not immoral, prejudices the success of a company's operations? Should officers who carry out a task with a lack of care and diligence be punished as criminals?

Section 229 (2) of the Companies Act 1981 and section 232 (4) of the Corporations Act 1989 provide that they should. I consider that to be harsh legislation, but it does show an understanding of the substantive character of corporate activities. Companies are instruments for carrying out trade and industry in an efficient and productive manner. If an officer diminishes their ability to do so, even though not in a criminal way, he strikes at their very essence.

By the proper running of companies I mean simply that the people within them should avoid committing criminal acts and show a proper dedication to the task to which they have been appointed, that is, as I said before, to carry out the trade and industry of the country. If they do that, they perform a proper function. In the end, that can be done only if there is a greater growth in the ethics with which people who are in control of companies go about their task.

I conclude on this point: in that context, I think much praise should be given to Mr Henry Bosch, who is presently trying to ensure that ethical conduct becomes the norm of company activities. As Senator Hill suggested, and I repeat, Henry Bosch was one of the few people who in the 1980s warned of the impending turmoil into which the corporate sector has now come. Like the prophets of old, he saw the problem early in its gestation and struggled rather lonehandedly to do something about it. I think this is an appropriate time to note that and give him much praise.

The issue before the corporate sector in the 1990s seems to me to be not so much whether there will be the gross conduct of the past with conduct like insider trading but whether companies have the ability to conduct Australia's industry and financial life in a proper way for us to recover economically. We should be looking towards achieving that goal. I conclude by saying that this legislation lays a very solid and sound foundation for the corporate sector to do just that.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being almost 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill raises the question in a very real sense as to whether we are one nation or a conglomeration of States each rowing its own boat. I believe it is a very significant step forward in our progress towards one nation. It is as yet, as has been mentioned before, imperfect, and it is for that reason that the Australian Democrats agreed to refer it to a committee, which will meet tomorrow. We wish to go a step further and seek Government assurance that the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) advisory committee will carefully monitor the performance of this legislation and recommend to Parliament subsequent amendments that should be instituted.

SPEECH.PARA: It was mentioned by one of the earlier speakers-I believe it was Senator Hill-that the corporate misbehaviour was in part due to the old unsatisfactory legislation. That may certainly have been the case, but only to a small degree. We should not forget that corporate misbehaviour, irresponsible lending, the fraudulent behaviour of directors and all the other practices we are aware of were made possible by wholesale deregulation instituted by this Government and supported by the Opposition. In that situation, we should have been aware that we would need more rather than less regulation. Here I wish to extend my compliments to Mr Henry Bosch who, with very few and scarce resources, did a tremendous job over the years in attempting to keep some order and obedience to the law in the corporate sector.

As we now move to the conclusion of the development of this extremely important piece of legislation, it may be worth recalling its now quite extensive history and the part that various participants have played in it. Since the Government's announcement in 1987 that it would proceed to the national scheme to replace the existing cooperative scheme, the proposed national scheme has been thoroughly debated and examined. This detailed scrutiny and examination has been rarely matched in recent times, and to that extent I cannot agree with Senator Hill's complaint that consultation has been inadequate.

The Federal Parliament, pleasingly, has played an extremely significant role in advancing debate on the issue. The need for a national scheme to replace the cooperative scheme was acknowledged as early as 1974 by the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange, the Rae committee. That Committee concluded that it was vital that the national character of the corporate activities being regulated be recognised.

Ever since the report of the Rae committee, the business environment and Australian securities and financial markets have changed rapidly and dramatically, but the mechanisms for dealing with them have scarcely changed at all. The problems associated with this situation were acknowledged yet again in 1987 by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, of which Senator Hill was a member. In its report The Role of the Parliament in relation to the National Companies Scheme the Committee concluded that the cooperative scheme had served the needs of the 1970s but had failed to meet the needs of business as we head into the next century. Increasingly, the cooperative scheme had become a creakingly inadequate mechanism, illequipped to adapt to the new business environment. The Committee report further recommended that the Federal Parliament develop and assume responsibility for the national companies and securities scheme. The report, then, had a considerable influence on the legislation which finally emerged.

This new approach-a single system of law for corporate legislation in Australia, an approach which, incidentally, in the Committee's recommendations was unanimous-was supported in principle by the Australian Democrats from the very beginning. First, the position adopted in the 1987 report and the need for a scheme looking into the future and our position rested on two further matters, both of them of major significance. One is parliamentary and ministerial accountability and the other is the attitude of the business community to the regulatory mechanisms.

In relation to parliamentary and ministerial accountability, it is obvious that there were serious problems with the old scheme. Every time, for example, an amendment was seen as necessary, the almost impossible task of getting the Commonwealth and all the States to agree put everybody off. On numerous occasions we were forced to pass deficient pieces of legislation, very often identified by the Parliament's own Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills because of this problem. In fact, Parliament was effectively denied the possibility of exercising proper responsibility in this important area. At the level of ministerial accountability, no single Minister had responsibility for the old scheme and therefore, in effect, nobody was in charge.

Having made our position clear in principle, the Democrats were keen to ensure that the process of developing this legislation was as constructive as possible and that the final version of the legislation was as good as possible. In line with that approach, when the first enormous version of the legislation came before this chamber the Australian Democrats moved to refer it to a joint select committee for examination of its complex detail. On this matter tribute should be paid to the then Attorney-General, the Hon. Lionel Bowen, for his cooperation at the time.

What we were hoping the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation would do-and in fact it did it-was to take evidence over six months from Australians, business organisations, business generally, lawyers and other groups that were interested in this area right around the country. It was a quite extensive process of consultation. The Committee took an innovative approach to the investigation, one which could well be used in future. A representative from the Attorney-General's Department, the National Companies and Securities Commission and the Australian Stock Exchange went with the Committee and provided it with invaluable expertise and information on a day-to-day basis.

Also as a result of the Committee reference, a very large number of people and businesses throughout Australia became aware of the import of the package and were willing to come forward with valu- able information and contributions. When the Committee's final report came out, the productive nature of the process was quite apparent, I believe, and the value of the whole exercise in relation to the largest group of Bills ever to be introduced in the Federal Parliament cannot be overestimated. A range of immediate amendments was agreed to and the quality of the whole package was significantly improved as a result.

Apart from other aspects, evidence before the Committee substantiated the view that most businesses throughout Australia also saw the need for a national scheme. They could see how imperative it was for the good of Australia's business community and Australia's future. The broadly constructive nature of the debate at that time was somewhat sullied by variants of spurious States rights arguments put forward in defiance of the clear national good that would be served by a national scheme. Furthermore, the Opposition parties wasted some time in wanting to debate the constitutionality of certain aspects of the package. As the Democrats noted at the time, this was essentially an exercise in futility.

The proper body to rule on constitutionality is the High Court of Australia. In due course it did so, and the consequences of its ruling are addressed in the legislation we have before us tonight. In that case, the High Court decided that section 51 (xx) of the Constitution did not give it proper power to legislate with respect to the incorporation of trading and financial corporations but that that did not detract from its plenary power to legislate on the governance and activities of such bodies after the formal act of incorporation had been concluded. That High Court ruling did nothing to diminish the conviction of the Australian Democrats that corporate regulation must be proceeded with on a national basis, and we were pleased to see that the Government's resolve remained as well. The Government's negotiations with the States and the Northern Territory led to agreement on future corporate regulation in Australia. The matters agreed in the heads of agreement are translated into the scheme to which the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill gives effect. The heads of agreement and the Bill take into account the decision of the High Court and the need to avoid any future constitutional uncertainty.

As this somewhat agonising and long overdue process was drawing to a conclusion, it is almost unbelievable that a segment of the Opposition parties has moved to partially cripple the scheme and completely unbelievable that the Federal leadership of the Liberal Party has failed to stop this happening.

With an astonishing capacity for political irresponsibility, the Western Australian Liberal Opposition has rejected the necessary mirroring legislation in that State's upper House. Presumably motivated by some obscure concept of States rights, it has probably done more damage to business in Western Australia than even some of that State's now disgraced corporate high fliers. Companies operating in Western Australia will have to experience the cost and confusion of complying with two systems of corporate law and administration. To quote the Chairman of the ASC, Mr Tony Hartnell, they will be `foreign companies' when they operate outside Western Australia. Even companies not domiciled in Western Australia but which conduct some operations or activities in Western Australia will face the extra cost and inconvenience of differing rules of compliance. The Western Australian Liberals obviously do not care about higher compliance costs, legal anomalies and potential litigation, increased legal costs and inevitable confusion and inconvenience.

Even more astounding than the gross irresponsibility of the Western Australian Liberals is the weakness of the Federal parliamentary Liberal leadership. Faced with this outrageous action on the part of his Western Australian branch, the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, has tried to have it both ways. He has publicly disagreed with its decision, but has done nothing to either prevent it or reverse it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you suggest he do?

—He could lead, for a start. This example of so-called leadership is hardly convincing, particularly as Dr Hewson and his Federal colleagues have mouthed support for both the national scheme and the urgency of its implementation on 1 January 1991. That brings me back to the crucial issue. The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) has outlined the `federalising' technique which will be used to implement the new national scheme, and there is no need to repeat it here. The important point here is the implementation and the fast approaching 1 January starting date.

SPEECH.PARA: Even with the exhaustive amount of work already done, with legislation of this size and complexity, there are bound to be some unintended consequences and inadequacies in the transitional arrangements. Indeed, this week we in the chamber will be grappling with some last minute concerns that have been raised by the Law Council of Australia and Coles Myer Ltd. However, the ASC has said that it will deal sympathetically with anyone caught out by inadequacies in the transitional arrangements and will exercise its discretionary powers to exempt them from any unintended breaches of the new legislation. Monitoring arrangements are in place and the Parliament may need to make clarifying amendments in the future on the basis, I trust, of the recommendations from the advisory committee of the ASC which is to be charged with that duty.

However, to countenance now any further delay would be unconscionable. Domestic investor confidence, Australia's international reputation and the ability of our business community to function effectively and efficiently have all been badly shaken by the corporate excesses of the 1980s. This Parliament now has the opportunity to pass a national regime which offers the possibility of a sound and properly regulated framework for corporate activity in this country.

At this point, I wish to advert to my private member's Bill, the Financial Corporations (Prudential Standards) Amendment Bill, introduced some weeks ago, which seeks to create a similar national scheme to regulate building societies and credit unions. It is time that we consider non-bank institutions as part of our financial system, and that the Commonwealth Government and the Reserve Bank of Australia take responsibility for those institutions that are stated in their charters.

Given the corporate experience of the 1980s, it is important that the passage of this legislation is implemented as quickly as possible. It is no exaggeration to describe this legislation as historic, and all those who see Australia as a single nation, with a need to secure its future economic well-being, will support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —As our Leader in the Senate, Senator Robert Hill, has said, the Opposition will be supporting the progress of the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill through the Senate, although many of the comments I am about to make could possibly raise some doubt as to the level of support I give to the package. I open by responding to some of the outrageous remarks made by Senator Spindler. I think it was Senator Walsh, from the opposite side of the chamber, who during the last election referred to the Australian Democrats as being the fairies at the bottom of the garden. Some weeks ago I suggested that the fairies were no longer at the bottom of the garden; they had actually come into the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is absolutely outrageous that Senator Spindler should suggest that in this new corporations package a national scheme is now required because of the corporate excesses of the late 1980s and because of some failures of the cooperative scheme. In the whole of his address to the Senate tonight, he blamed the Opposition parties in Western Australia for upsetting this new national scheme. Senator Spindler even blamed Dr John Hewson, the Federal Leader of the Opposition, for not going over to Western Australia and telling them what to do. The Liberal Party of Australia does have a Federal system and the Federal Leader does not tell the members of a State upper House what they should do.

I think the worst aspect of what Senator Spindler tried to have the Senate believe tonight is that he did not criticise this Government at all during the whole of his address about the undermining of the cooperative scheme and the lack of resources for the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC). The only negative political comments he made in his entire address were directed to the Opposition and, indeed, to the Leader of the Opposition, Dr John Hewson. It shows that Senator Spindler is, indeed, quite out of touch with what has happened in corporations law reform over the last few years. I suggest that all he did tonight was attempt to read a speech probably written for him by former Senator Michael Macklin, who was indeed very much involved in the process of developing this new national scheme and deserves some credit for his role therein. Senator Spindler's contribution is far less evident.

Of course, the legislation has arrived in this chamber tonight after a tortuous process. As Senator Spindler correctly said, the legislation is the product of a deal that was done in Alice Springs nearly six months ago. At that time a heads of agreement and legislative program were put down, and we were told that the legislation would actually appear in September. So the legislation is quite late. As I suggested during the Appropriations debate, it may be that the delay in drafting that legislation was a matter of design as opposed to just bad luck or delays caused by the complexity of the matter, because it is fair to say that the parliaments around Australia-each State parliament, the Territory parliaments and, indeed, this Federal Parliament-have not had enough time to look at what is a very complex matter.

This is one of the most complex pieces of legislation ever introduced into this Parliament. The new unofficial consolidation of the Corporations Act 1989 and the current amendment legislation form quite a weighty document, which acts as a good bookend on anyone's bookshelf. As Senator Hill said earlier, the amendment Bill deserves a lot more scrutiny by the Senate. I am quite sure the Australian Democrats would support me in that assertion.

The need for reform was quite clear some years ago. The cooperative scheme did have some failings but the process of reform that has been entered into in the intervening years has, I would suggest to the Senate, created a degree of uncertainty and a degree of lack of knowledge of the law. It is a reform process that has led to the situation where we are now in December 1990 looking forward to a 1 January start-up date for the new scheme, and where the peak professional bodies have very little idea of how the Bill or any of the new legislation is going to work. The Attorney-General's Department and the Australian Securities Commission, the bodies responsible for the legislation, have very little idea of how or if it is going to work or if the constitutional underpinnings of the legislative package are going to work.

The position that the Liberal and National Party Legislative councillors in Western Australia have taken is going to make the process slightly more difficult in that State. I suppose that was an unforeseen position; however, this Government was warned of such possibilities on many occasions. The opposition of the Western Australian Liberal Party to this whole national scheme has been well documented, is well known and should have been taken into account by people who had some idea of administration and who could have made some contingency plans for it. The legislation that we have before us tonight, in concert with the Corporations Act 1989, does centralise more power and control into the hands of very few bureaucrats and a couple of politicians in Canberra. It will be a system that will be far less in tune with the local business community, and the business and corporate sector influence in the whole corporate regulatory process will be significantly reduced.

We may ask ourselves why it is bad not to have business and corporate sector influence on the corporate regulatory pro- cess reduced. There is no better person to quote in relation to this matter than Henry Bosch, the former head of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC). Mr Bosch, in his recently published book The Workings of a Watchdog, in his reference to the five part-time members of the NCSC, says:

They were all senior businessmen with wide experience and great strength and independence of mind. They all had wide personal contacts and considerable influence in important parts of the business community. The long experience of the chairman and deputy chairman in various parts of the private sector provided knowledge and confidence. The practice of maintaining frequent and detailed contact with business and professional organisations and the individual firms that were affected by our policies deepened our knowledge and strengthened our business relationships and our resolve. The fact that we were constantly dealing with scores of practical situations arising from investigations and applications from the private sector ensured that our judgments were based on up-to-date information.

It is fair to say that as we now have a scheme controlled by a much smaller bureaucracy in Canberra, contact with the business community is going to be somewhat reduced. One of the proposals that I would like the Government to consider, perhaps in the committee stage of this Bill tomorrow or whenever it may be, is that we have a regional advisory committee network set up as well as the national advisory committee, on which there are some business representatives from each State.

If we are to believe the Government's rhetoric about trying to make the regional offices responsive to the local needs of the business community, the regional directors would be quite advantaged by having a small advisory group in each State and a formalised network. I know that that would be one thing that the Western Australian business community and the Western Australian Liberal Party, if it matters, would be sure to support. The regional directors in each of the States could have a formal mechanism for consultation with local business groups. Perhaps the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) can answer that suggestion when he responds.

The genesis of this scheme is not something that has just arisen in the 1980s; the desire to centralise control over corporations has been a part of the Australian Labor Party's centralist doctrine since the early 1970s. In 1974, the introduction of the Lionel Murphy corporations and securities industry legislation was the first parliamentary representation of the Labor Party's centralist doctrine in relation to this area of policy. That initiative by the then Senator Murphy was cut short by the events of 11 November 1975. After that the Fraser Government introduced the scheme that we now have, the cooperative scheme.

This was not to dissuade the centralists in the Labor Party. In August 1979 the now retired Attorney-General, Lionel Bowen, introduced a private member's Bill, which was fundamentally the Murphy package, in the House of Representatives, again trying to centralise control over corporations and securities. The former Attorney-General did not have much success in 1979. As has been said a number of times here tonight, the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in April 1987 made representations that a national scheme be entered into. I think it is fair to say that at that time the Federal Government made a political commitment to ensure that the cooperative scheme was not enhanced, reformed or allowed to succeed. Mr Bosch's book refers to a letter from a senior Treasury officer in late 1987, saying that the Commonwealth will not entertain any more reform of the cooperative scheme `while there is to be no further legislative amendment in the context of the Co-operative Scheme'.

There was a determined conspiracy-I suppose that is a strong word, but it is the most descriptive word I can use-to ensure the cooperative scheme was not a success after 1987. The resourcing level of the NCSC after that date was something of a national scandal. Its annual budget was something in the order of $22m. As Mr Bosch says quite descriptively, that was less than the subsidy provided to the Australian Capital Territory bus service.

This is the sort of money that this Government committed to the national corporate watchdog, and we wonder why the members of the Senate and the Government can contend that there was a need for reform because the old scheme had failed. I put it to the Senate that the scheme failed because the Government wanted it to fail, and it has got its way. The later history of it is that the 1989 legislation appeared. As Senator Spindler, Senator Hill and others have referred to tonight, that failed on constitutional grounds, despite the best advice of that eminent centralist lawyer, Sir Maurice Byers, that it would stand up.

As I said earlier, a deal was done in June which saw the States agree to enter into a new arrangement to form this new national scheme. Part of that deal was to ensure that the New South Wales Government would see the chairman based in Sydney, with something like 8,000 square metres of office space, and all the attendant bureaucrats and employees of the Australian Securities Commission being settled in Sydney. For the people of New South Wales that was probably a good thing, because one of the problems that my constituents have is that it is a long way from Western Australia if one has problems or if one wants to have some influence on the course of corporate law reform or corporate law in any sense whatsoever.
