In Sydney, I guess people such as the Premier of New South Wales, Nick Greiner, have a little trouble understanding some of our opposition to this centralisation process. For people such as the good Premier and the good people of New South Wales, it will not really be a problem to go to the head office of the Australian Securities Commission because it will be located in their capital city. So the process of handing over State control to the Commonwealth does not have the very worrying effects that it has for people who live in Western Australia, so many thousands of kilometres away from the centre of political and corporate power in Australia.

The process I have just described has had, of course, some consequences that are less than desirable. It has, indeed, destroyed morale within the NCSC. It has destroyed the careers of many people in the NCSC and the corporate affairs commissions around the States. I think it is a disgrace that job offers were not made many months ago by the Australian Securities Commission to the staff of the corporate affairs commissions.

We were given an assurance by Senator Tate that job offers would be made towards the end of the first week in December, only some 20 days from the establishment of the Australian Securities Commission. These people have been living in some form of career limbo since the announcement of the deal back in June.

I do not think any of us, in contemplating our futures, would like to have no idea for a period of a week or two, let alone six months, of when an offer was going to come or what our remuneration package or career structure would be. But these poor people in the corporate affairs offices around Australia have been subjected to this. Is it any wonder to any of us here that industrial disputes are taking place in most of the corporate affairs offices around Australia as I talk tonight?

There are many other problems that I have referred to earlier in relation to the setting up of the Australian Securities Commission. I do not intend going over these matters tonight. However, they are, of course, relevant in Western Australia. During the debate on the Appropriations the ASCOT principle-the Australian Securities Commission on time principle-was enunciated. It has now become quite clear to anyone who has anything to do with this legislative package, be it in the Parliament or be it out in the business community where it really matters, that ASCOT is not going to win its first race, that the odds are off, that ASCOT will not be achieved and that the Australian Securities Commission will not be on time.

We have all come to the realisation that the Attorney-General, Mr Duffy, and the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission, Mr Hartnell, are determined that at all cost they will start up the Australian Securities Commission on 1 January. It does not matter if Western Australia is in it. It does not really matter if the Commission does not have its offices set up. It does not matter if it does not have its computers or trained staff. The Commission has to get it up because it is politically imperative.

It does not really matter about the service levels to the business community. It does not matter if the legal community and the professional community have not had time to look at the regulations. It does not matter if they have not had time to go down and buy the new Bills and the unofficial consolidation from the Government bookshop because the legislation will pass this place only a few days before the Australian Securities Commission is meant to be set up. It just does not matter to these people because their concern is the political imperative to get 1 January up and running and worry about all of the problems afterwards. Anyone who denies that is denying what is clear to the whole of the business community in Australia.

I think it behoves me to relate my view of the position of the Western Australian Liberal Party. I think this matter deserves airing in the national Parliament. I believe it has been misrepresented by a number of people for their own political ends. We have witnessed a campaign, partly in the Senate, in which Senator Michael Beahan has asked Senator Tate some questions in relation to the position in Western Australia. I put it to honourable senators opposite that some of the answers have actually inflamed the situation. They have, for their own political ends, actually distorted the situation that will occur after 1 January. I guess that is part of the game we play.

The great thing about what the Western Australian Liberal Party and the National Party have done in Western Australia is that it does cover up the maladministration of the set-up of the Australian Securities Commission. It gives Tony Hartnell, the Attorney-General, Mr Duffy, and all of the people associated with the ASCOT principle a very convenient veil to hide behind. We all know that the Australian Securities Commission cannot operate properly in Western Australia until at least March or April next year and that the sensible thing to do would be to delay the start-up date to probably 1 July, the beginning of the new financial year. But that did not matter. So I guess the Western Australian Liberals have given Mr Hartnell and his friends an excuse to hide their lack of administrative skills behind and I guess, to that extent, they have helped the Government.

The great problem in relation to the Western Australian situation is that very few people had any idea of the scheme that was proposed. They did not know the constitutional underpinning of the legislative package. The business community in Western Australia and the Western Australian opposition group in particular, headed by Laurie Shervington, had very little, if any, consultation in relation to this matter.

Today, Senator Tate, in answer to a question asked by Senator Beahan, again as part of their political program to try to rile the Opposition in Western Australia, tabled what he called the heads of agreement, as if it were some great new Magna Carta or document that provided service guarantees to the business community of Western Australia. I thought, `I am glad to see that Senator Tate is finally really concerned about the interests of the poor battling business people in Western Australia and not his own political ends for once'. I flicked through the document and was disgusted to find that it was just really the document that came out of the Alice Springs meeting. If Senator Beahan reads through it he will see that it has nothing to do with service levels in the States. It is really just a document that tries to create a transitional arrangement. It is for the bureaucrats, not the business people.

Senator Beahan's question in the Senate this afternoon implied that it was some guarantee of service levels to the people of Western Australia. Of course, the honourable senator knows about the deal that was done by the Western Australian Government. His colleague Joe Berinson, the Attorney-General in Western Australia, signed that heads of agreement with a condition precedent that there would be some guarantees of staffing levels, service levels and various other things. This was, as I said, a condition precedent to the Western Australian Government getting involved in this dirty deal. Those guarantees have never been given.

The letter that the head of the Western Australian Opposition group, Laurie Shervington, sent to Mr Hartnell on 6 June was replied to in part. But most of the serious issues that he raised, which concern the business community in Western Australia, were not replied to even though he did receive some acknowledgment of his letter from an officer of the Australian Securities Commission.

We are yet to sight the formal agreement. We have not been told when that formal agreement will be available. Of course, the problem that the Legislative Councillors had in Western Australia was that they really had no time to consider this complex legislation. So they did what they had to and said, `Look, we have not had proper time to consider this. In principle, we are opposed to this centralisation. We have not been consulted about it so we are opposing it'.

I have been around this place for something over six months now. As the Minister knows, I have been bitterly opposed to this centralisation. But I have come to realise that once the deal was done, as soon as Nick Greiner decided to be part of the deal and the other States agreed, the whole thing was probably a reality and what Western Australia did probably did not matter. So I have been working very hard for the last months to try to get some guarantees of service for the Western Australian business community.

My view is that the Western Australian Liberal Party position will create some problems for the business community but they are problems that could be easily overcome if this Government were cooperative and took a conciliatory approach to achieving its goal of national legislation.

Tony Hartnell, the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission, went across to Western Australia last Monday to discuss this issue with the Liberal Party. My reports from that meeting were that he took a very conciliatory approach. It surprised me that he did so. I have some letters and some correspondence between Mr Hartnell and Mr Derrick Tomlinson, the Liberal Party Legislative Councillor, who is the shadow Minister handling this legislation, which show that Mr Hartnell made it quite clear to those people that although he did not support their position, he was prepared to compromise on some points and agree to some of the compromise proposals that those Legislative Councillors in Western Australia proposed.

Of course, what happened? His compromise, his conciliatory approach to the Liberals and his clear message that he would be prepared to work through the problem and try to get it going in consultation with the upper House people, lasted only a few hours. When he got back to the eastern States he did a 180 degree turn because his conciliatory approach with the upper House people in Western Australia did not fit into this Government's political program, which was to crash through or crash.

We had a barrage of statements by the new Minister, the Attorney-General, and by the Chairman, Mr Hartnell, saying, `We'll leave Western Australia out on a limb, we'll let them wither on the vine and we'll just go ahead without them'. They even said they would not set up an office in Perth, which has proved to me to be a distortion of the truth because work on building the office at 66 St Georges Terrace is going ahead full speed today. So it is clearly a bluff.

My call to this Government is that the Western Australian Liberal Party does have the genuine concerns of the business community at heart; it does have genuine concerns about centralising power. It will assist the Australian Securities Commission in achieving a national scheme, but it will require cooperation, compromise and conciliation. It will not occur by people banging their fists on the table and saying, `You can all go and jump'. The Government will not achieve its stated objective by these means. I doubt that the Government's objective is to get it up and running in Western Australia. The Government's objective is to score political points at a time when Australia needs some hard heads to sort out some of these problems.

My prognosis for the establishment of the Australian Securities Commission is shared by Chanticleer on the back page of the Australian Financial Review of 28 November 1990. Alan Kohler was the correspondent. He basically said that people in business and corporate lawyers should get out of town, take a holiday in January. I do not share Senator Spindler's view that this is the last we will see of this legislation. I think we will be back here all of next year and the year after with amendment after amendment to get this scheme really working.

One commitment I give to this Government is that I will be here to make sure that it is amended properly, that we certainly commit far more time to this whole area of public policy, and that the interests of the Western Australian business community are far better protected than they have been to date.
In his article, Alan Kohler refers to a number of issues which he thinks will cause immediate problems. The first one is the matter of rights issues and capital raisings. He stated:

Here is the nastiest: any rights issue or other capital raising or share issue that comes under the new capital raising provisions of the Act, and which is still open to the public on January 1, must have a prospectus. In other words, there is no `grandfathering' for any issues that were announced or started before that date.
So he is saying that if a person is thinking about making an issue, make sure it is closed on 31 December or get another prospectus. The other matter of uncertainty which he raised was as follows:
There is a broader source of uncertainty in the method of getting around the Constitution, which is to `federalise' State law.
He referred to Bob Austin, who said:
The new law will apply as State law, but the Bill tries to treat it as Commonwealth law as far as possible. This will create legal problems, uncertainty and legal challenges.
We must never allow corporate law to be made this way again. The process demonstrates what a low ebb has been reached in corporate and securities law reform.

I commit myself to ensuring that law reform in the future is not carried out like this. I conclude by saying that part of the political barrage that the Western Australian business community has had to put up with in the last week was a threat by Tony Hartnell and the Attorney-General that Western Australian companies will be treated as foreigners. I have read section 102 of the Act on which Tony Hartnell relies. I believe he is scaremongering in a political way. I do not believe Western Australian businesses will be treated in this way. I think the Minister should look into the claims made by Tony Hartnell in relation to the effect of those clauses and reassure the Western Australian business community about the real legal position that they are in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1990. I wish to raise a matter of concern to the Australian Capital Territory Government, not so much because of anything contained in the legislation, but because the ACT is excluded. The reason it is excluded is that section 23(1) (h) of the Australian Capital Territory Self-Government Act 1988 precludes the ACT Government from making laws with respect to companies, close corporations, foreign companies, the acquisition of shares in bodies corporate, and the regulation of the securities industry and the futures industry-one of a number of exclusions to the general grant of power for functions of a State-type nature.

SPEECH.PARA: As a consequence of this exclusion, the ACT Attorney-General, Mr Collaery, is the only State or Territory Attorney-General who does not have full membership of the Ministerial Council on Companies and Securities, a body which I think all would agree has an important consultative role for legislative amendments in this area of corporate law and a deliberative role for law reform. It should be noted that the Northern Territory Attorney-General, following the grant of self-government to the Northern Territory, was granted full membership of the Ministerial Council on Companies and Securities.

This raises two issues. The first is the question of the purpose of the Commonwealth in denying the ACT Government the right to pass laws relating to these matters. I ask whether it is intended to change this or leave it as it is. I do not recall at the time of the legislation being passed any explanation being given for this decision. In view of the recent Special Premiers Conference, where it was suggested that there should be discussions between States, Territories and the Federal Government as to powers and responsibilities, I would like to know whether this will be included as a matter for discussion in the near future. I would appreciate clarification from the Government concerning the reason why the ACT perhaps was excluded in 1988 and still remains excluded. I would also like comment from the Government about whether it believes this should continue. If so, why? If not, when is it likely to change?

The second issue is whether, notwithstanding the ACT's lack of power to legislate on the matters I have referred to, there are other good reasons for the inclusion of the ACT as a party to the heads of agreement and as a full member of the Ministerial Council. The heads of agreement which were concluded in Alice Springs on 29 June-which have been referred to previously in this debate, and which are included in this legislation-exclude the ACT because of its lack of legislative power with respect to companies and securities.

The Attorney-General for the ACT has written to all of the State Attorneys-General and to the Federal Attorney-General, putting a case for the inclusion of the ACT in the Ministerial Council, in the belief that the arguments that he has put forward are of substance. I ask the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate): will the Federal Government look at the reasons given by the ACT Attorney-General? I would hope that a response to this may be given tomorrow night when the Committee meets to discuss this legislation.

In doing so, I would also ask the Minister to consider giving a response in writing because I understand there are delays with the production of the Senate Hansard for committee reports, so that the response of the Government can be considered before the debate on this matter is concluded.

Rather than taking the time of the Senate tonight in going through in detail the matters raised by the ACT Attorney, I intend to seek leave to incorporate a copy of his letter. He deals with all the issues that are of significance, particularly the question of revenue to the ACT. Mr Deputy President, you may have heard me speak previously in debates about the way I feel regarding the Commonwealth's attitude to the ACT on the transitional funding arrangements. This is not quite the same issue, but we are sensitive about ACT funding matters. The Attorney raises the question of stamp duty, the overlap with local laws, the role of the courts and criminal offences under this legislation, and the matter of certainty in the ACT of the legislative process.

I seek leave to incorporate the letter, which is addressed to the Attorney-General of South Australia, although copies were to be sent to all State Attorneys, the Northern Territory Attorney and the Federal Attorney. I hope the Government will respond to this in the committee stage of this debate.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Australian Capital Territory
1 Constitution Ave
Canberra ACT 2601
Deputy Chief Minister
The Hon. C. J. Sumner,
MLC Attorney-General
12th Floor
S.G.I.C. Building
Victoria Square
ADELAIDE SA 5000
Dear Mr Sumner,
NATIONAL LEGISLATIVE SCHEME: CORPORATIONS LAW

I am writing to ask if you will support the inclusion of the Australian Capital Territory as a full member in the proposed new national scheme on companies and securities. I have read with interest the Second Reading Speech by the Commonwealth Attorney-General, Hon. Michael Duffy, on the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 and there is much to commend the proposed legislative scheme.

I trust you appreciate, however, that I am trying to be constructive when I say that there is, in my opinion, one major deficiency in the scheme and that is the exclusion of the A.C.T. Government as a party to the Heads of Agreement and as full member of the redefined Ministerial Council on Companies and Securities (MINCO).
There is, I submit, a strong case for the inclusion of the Australian Capital Territory as a full member within the proposed new scheme. I ask you to consider the following

* MINCO: with its redefined role MINCO will not have power to direct the Australian Securities Commission (ASC); MINCO will have a consultative role for legislative amendments and a deliberative role for law reform; there is no legal nor logical reason to exclude the A.C.T. from full membership of MINCO.

* HEADS OF AGREEMENT: the Heads of Agreement concluded in Alice Springs on 29 June 1990, excludes the A.C.T. because the A.C.T. Legislative Assembly is precluded from making laws with respect to companies and securities by paragraph 23(1) (h) of the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988; nevertheless, there are aspects of the national scheme which could have, at least, recognised the emergence of the A.C.T. as a political entity; the need to supplement the Agreement to settle the ``federalising'' of the courts and criminal offences offers an opportunity for the A.C.T. to be invited as a signatory to this national scheme.

* ONE NATION: a national scheme should be truly national and allow for the recognition of all jurisdictions; our laws should evolve along with the growth of the nation and include newly-emerged political entities.

* REVENUE: the A.C.T. estimates that the excess of revenue over expenditure on a per annum basis for corporate affairs functions in the A.C.T. runs to some $2.5 million; technically, the revenue issue in the context of the A.C.T. is complex as it also involves consideration of the Commonwealth's general revenue grant to the A.C.T., and the broader issue of A.C.T. involvement in corporate affairs; nevertheless, if the A.C.T. was placed on the same footing as the States and the Northern Territory in the matter of compensation for loss of a corporate affairs function, then it could have expected $1.88 million per annum (i.e. allowing a 25% reduction for the increased funding for the ASC); this notional $1.88 million is, of course, additional to the amounts already agreed under the Heads of Agreement, to compensate the States and the Northern Territory.

* STAMP DUTY: there is a concern that jurisdictions may diverge on stamp duty issues and the A.C.T. needs to protect its own revenue base in this area; while the Commonwealth law is neutral on stamp duty issues it is a subject area which directly affects the A.C.T.

* OVERLAP WITH LOCAL LAWS: regulation of building societies, co-operatives and associations brings with it the need to have some nexus with the financial, securities and corporate sectors (e.g. the recent conversion of one of our building societies into a company for amalgamation into a bank); also there is a move for such regulation to mirror the more sophisticated approach used in the companies and securities area; there is no reason to exclude the A.C.T. from the benefit of intelligence and information sharing which can be available through the national scheme for companies and securities.

* COURTS: CORPORATE CRIMINAL OFFENCES: the ``federalising'' of the courts, and the prosecution of offences under the new Commonwealth Corporations Law will see the involvement of the A.C.T. Supreme Court and the A.C.T.'s enforcement and detention services; the A.C.T. should have a direct say in the use of such services by the Commonwealth; the A.C.T. Supreme Court will, of course, also be a venue for civil actions under the proposed new national law.

* LOCAL LEGISLATIVE CERTAINTY: paragraph 23(1) (h) in the A.C.T. Self-Government legislation becomes redundant once the new Corporations Law is enacted, yet, unless paragraph 23(1) (h) is repealed or amended it will continue to prevent the A.C.T. from making necessary local laws which touch upon company matters (e.g. the recent example of the building society conversion); the A.C.T. laws in question will deal only with Territory matters and will not intrude into the national scheme.

The residents of the Australian Capital Territory, at present, have no say within their own jurisdiction as to the form and content of this important legislation. The law will be enacted by the Commonwealth in the Federal Parliament. Local Federal Members will have a vote, of course, but only in the context of a Commonwealth law. Unlike the residents of the States and the Northern Territory, A.C.T. residents have no voice through their local Minister. I submit that it is important that all Australians should have the same level of access irrespective of whether they can be excluded by the narrow application of a technicality of constitutional law.

On behalf of the residents of the Australian Capital Territory, I ask you to give favourable and urgent consideration to the inclusion of the Australian Capital Territory in this important national scheme. A.C.T. residents are shareholders, investors and taxpayers as well as being, in some cases, active participants in the direction and management of companies.
I am writing in similar terms to the Ministers in the other States and the Northern Territory. I have also written to the Commonwealth Attorney-General.
Yours sincerely,
Bernard Collaery
Attorney-General
27 November 1990

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to thank those honourable senators who have contributed to the debate and indicated that the chamber will indeed support in principle the passage of this very significant legislation. What it does with its passage is bring back to this Parliament political responsibility for the shaping of the companies and securities law which will be in place to regulate those extremely important areas of our economy and of our social and national life Australia-wide.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important to say to Senator Campbell that I welcome the fact that he has said that he will take up the challenge of contributing to the formulation of legislation to do with companies and securities, as Senator Barney Cooney will, as Senator Spindler will, and as I know Senator Robert Hill will when his duties permit. This chamber, by virtue of what we will be doing over the next few hours and days, will take political responsibility for the formation and passage of this important legislation in a way which has not been true in the years of the cooperative scheme.

This was the fundamental flaw and democratic weakness of that scheme. Senator Spindler touched on it to some extent but not perhaps as extensively as he might have. He spoke of the difficulty of putting together and composing the legislation which was put out by the Ministerial Council on Companies and Securities. That is one aspect of it, but the other aspect is that it was passed too easily. It was very difficult to put together but it was passed too easily because there was an automatic obligation on the various parliaments around Australia to actually pass that legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —When you were chairing the constitutional committee, your biggest disappointment was that the legislation was a fait accompli when it got this far.

—That is exactly the point I am making. I am glad Senator Crichton-Browne has got a substantial part of the speech I know he would have liked to have made into the Hansard on this occasion by way of interjection because he is backing up exactly my point that we now have the grave responsibility of taking the actual composition of the legislation to deal with companies and securities very seriously.
—How is the capacity of the Senate to make amendments to this legislation different now from what it was in the past?

—I will come to that because there was some misunderstanding. But before doing so let me say in relation to Senator Campbell's constructive contribution that he misunderstands some of the history of the financial support and allocation of resources to the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC). That was the case when it came to the Commonwealth's participation in that scheme. I know Senator Hill would verify at Estimates committees that when the Ministerial Council made a commitment to provide further resources for the National Companies and Securities Commission, the Federal Government immediately appropriated the funds. But that was not always the case in the States. In fact, the States, as we know, used the companies area as something of a revenue raiser and siphoned off the moneys and put them into other areas of their administration through their Consolidated Revenue, rather than using the moneys generated in order to regulate that area.

SPEECH.PARA: When new fee structures were put forward by the Ministerial Council, once again the Federal Government did its part very speedily; I think one or two other States did but others did not. In so far as the NCSC lost support around Australian jurisdictions, the Federal Government could not be held responsible in that regard.

We are faced with a peculiar constitutional arrangement following the decision of the High Court of Australia by agreement between all governments and it has this particular impact, which I might just emphasise: that the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill converts the Corporations Act 1989 into a law under section 122 of the Constitution for the Government of the Australian Capital Territory to be known as the Corporations Law of the Capital Territory.

The corporations law will then be applied by State and Northern Territory application of laws Acts as the corporations laws of each of those jurisdictions. In this way a single national corporations law will be enacted throughout Australia. It is important because it helps answer one of the queries and misgivings that Senator Hill quite legitimately raised, which was this: what if State parliaments do not take up and immediately pass mirror legislation and one gets a discordance, fragmentation, lack of consistency, and lack of uniformity Australia-wide?

With an application of laws-type provision in all of the State and the Northern Territory parliaments, we will have a situation where, as this Parliament passes amendments to the corporations law, those amendments will be taken up automatically in the laws of the various jurisdictions concerned. In that way the corporations law will form a uniform text of the new national law applying in all jurisdictions. So what one has is an application of laws-type situation.

Senator Hill also mentioned the question of the Ministerial Council and the role it will play. Once again, Senator Hill was somewhat worried whether that might lead to a situation where perhaps people had a veto, or some jurisdictions had a veto, which could be exercised in a disruptive and fragmenting way. Senator Hill will know that the Ministerial Council will have a consultative role in respect of all legislative proposals and a deliberative role in relation to the reform of what can be broadly described as company law matters. Takeovers, securities, public fundraising and futures will be pre-eminent matters for the Commonwealth, subject to the general consultative role of the Ministerial Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about an amendment that is moved in this chamber that has not gone through the Ministerial Council? Aren't we in the same position as we have been in the past? You will want to take an amendment back to the Ministerial Council before it is passed here.

—Where we are dealing with company law and those amendments to the company law are moved in the Commonwealth Parliament, the undertaking given is that the Commonwealth will use its best endeavours to ensure adequate consultation with the Ministerial Council on those amendments. That is the undertaking that is given.
—So that means we can amend the Bill in this place?
—We can in the corporations law where they are company law matters as I have described. In relation to other matters there is a deliberative vote process within the Ministerial Council.
—What happens then?

—I will deal with that at the committee stage tomorrow night. I think it might be easier to get a flow chart of how we deal with amendments in regard to various areas. The point I am trying to make is that we were in a situation, which the honourable senator would acknowledge because he was on the Senate committee that dealt with this particular problem, where there was a complete lack of political democratic responsibility for the shape of corporations and securities laws. There was no particular parliament that took ultimate responsibility. There was no ministerial line of responsibility which could lead to a particular elected representative of the people being held accountable. I think that that is extremely important.
—There is a collective responsibility.

—The collective responsibility led to the difficulties in the composition of the legislation which have already been referred to and to the passage through the various parliaments, without proper scrutiny, of the amendments that were put forward from time to time. So that was not a satisfactory democratic situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I also take up the point made by Senator Campbell about the way in which the Western Australian phenomenon has emerged in recent months and weeks and, of course, in a very acute form, in the last couple of days. I want to emphasise that in my answer today I was trying to say that, despite some rhetoric that accompanies statements emanating from Western Australia, which has that secessionist tinge and speaks of sovereignty in States' rights issues, I believe that the Liberal Party and the National Party in the upper House were motivated by a very real concern to look after the interests of the business community in Western Australia.

I believe that the pressure that came from Western Australia, not only from those interests but also from the Attorney-General, Mr Joe Berinson, led to the inclusion in the heads of agreement, which I tabled at Question Time, of clause 3 and the clauses following, which may be described and have been described in colloquial parlance as the Western Australian clauses. I am sorry that the honourable senator did not get a chance to read the document as fully as he might have because of his other senatorial duties. On page 2, under `ASC Regional Administration', clause 3.3 states:
The ASC will, through these regional offices and business centres, maintain a level of service not less than current levels of service provided by Corporate Affairs Commissions in each State.
The honourable senator might say that that is rhetoric.
Clause 3.4 goes on:

The ASC will put in place performance indicators to ensure the maintenance of those levels of service and report twice yearly to each State Minister on the performance of the ASC in the State against those indicators.
Clause 3.5 says:
The ASC will also, to the fullest extent practicable and efficient, delegate the exercise of powers to Regional Commissioners.

Of course, we know that there will be a role for the Regional Liaison Committee. I believe this Committee, as the honourable senator indicated, will have an extremely important role to play. I know that there is a willingness to try to make that system work. It depends on the appointment of a Regional Commissioner who, of course, will be the linchpin person, but there is no cap on the numbers of persons on the Regional Liaison Committee. It can comprise any number of people whose presence on such a liaison committee would be of assistance in ensuring that the interflow of information between the local business community and the ASC does take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell me where the performance indicators are and where the delegated powers are. Where are the guarantees?

—The guarantees are included in this heads of agreement. This is an agreement made under great pressure-I acknowledge it, and it is a fact-from the various Attorneys-General around the various jurisdictions of Australia. I believe that we can accept in relation to those particular undertakings which have been given and which form the political foundation for the legislation we are debating that those particular ingredients of clause 3 will be realised soon. I am very confident that, unless they do, this whole endeavour will collapse. I do not believe that that is at all a prospect. I believe that those particular performance indicators that the honourable senator speaks of are going to play a very important role, because not only will the business community be concerned to see that they are properly formulated and adhered to through their membership of the Regional Liaison Committee, but, of course, State Ministers have a right to go to the Ministerial Council and complain about the lack of measuring up to the performance indicators and require a response from the Commonwealth within one month.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a most unusual situation, but there it is. It is put in, probably because of the suspicions which the honourable senator is voicing so eloquently on behalf of Western Australians. But it is in there and there is a requirement for a Federal Government response within one month. I believe that indicates that at the political level of State Ministers and at the liaison level, dealing with the business community, there is more than enough scope for the sorts of consultations which are important and which the honourable senator has indicated are going to be an absolutely vital key to the success of the ASC operation out of the eastern seaboard capitals.

As a Tasmanian, I am not particularly captive to the Sydney and Melbourne centres of power in relation to companies and securities. In fact, I spent three years in Western Australia as a youngster when my father managed Charlie Carters Pty Ltd.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great company, too, I might say.

—I thank Senator Crichton-Browne. It certainly was in those three short years that my father was the manager. I believe that I have some understanding of the sort of sentiment which underlies the concerns which the honourable senator has expressed in moderate terms, but forcefully, during the course of the debate and at various Question Times over the last several days.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Campbell raised one substantive matter. That was the question of the Act imposing the requirement for a prospectus to be required when a company is making a rights issue. It was said that this will cause difficulties for companies which have a rights issue on offer before 1 January which remains open after 1 January. I was exercised by this myself last night and so I sought some advice on it. It has been pointed out to me that the requirement that a prospectus be lodged or registered for a rights issue is not a new proposal. This amendment to the law was contained in the Corporations Act when first introduced in May 1988. The Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation reviewed, in particular, the fundraising provisions of the Act, but that in itself would not answer the honourable senator's particular problem. The next paragraph does.

The Australian Securities Commission has power under section 1084 of the corporations law to give an exemption from compliance with the prospectus provisions in an appropriate case. Whether such an exemption should be available in a particular case such as this is a matter obviously within the discretion of the Australian Securities Commission, but there is a capacity-not a formal grandfathering clause in a blanket sense of a categorisation of particular prospectuses lodged for a rights issue-within the Australian Securities Commission to deal with the matter which the honourable senator raised.

I know that honourable senators wish this debate to be brought to a speedy conclusion. I believe that I have covered most of the major matters of principle that have been raised. I have given an undertaking to Senator Reid that I will answer in the committee stage tomorrow some of the matters which she raised, apart from the general underlying policy issues, which of course have been determined in relation to the self-government of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) by higher authorities than myself or the Attorney. Those include the major political questions as to what power should be vested in the ACT Government. However, the more particular questions that the Attorney-General, Mr Bernard Collaery, has raised about revenue and so on can and will be answered in the Committee tomorrow night.

I believe that this is a remarkable piece of legislation. It has a peculiar constitutional genesis which has led to some great innovation both in the way in which legislation can now be made, which has an Australia-wide effect, and, of course, in the various ways in which civil and criminal jurisdiction is vested in the State courts and the Federal Court and how the investigation, prosecution and sentencing of those who offend against the provisions of this law can be undertaken by the Commonwealth.

It is, I believe, a matter of some pride that the political representatives of the Australian people have been able to come to this particular arrangement. It has survived the scrutiny of the most learned counsel throughout Australia, including the very intense scrutiny of the various Solicitors-General at various times in the composition and drafting of this legislative scheme. I believe it forms a firm and secure foundation, since the High Court of Australia decision, for the sort of regulation of companies and securities which this country so desperately requires.

I believe that this legislation is required to restore confidence domestically within Australia as to the operations of the marketplace in relation to companies and securities matters. Our international reputation has also been gravely damaged. I believe that with the passage of this legislation-and I still hope for the accession to this particular national scheme by the Western Australian upper House-we will have Australia-wide such a legal and administrative structure in place that confidence, internationally as well as domestically, can be revived in a way which will allow our companies and securities markets to operate efficiently and fairly in the interests of the creation of wealth and the well-being of all the citizens and residents of the Commonwealth of Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Senator Hill) agreed to:
That this Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for consideration and report by 13 December 1990.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to discuss a matter raised in this place on 12 November by Senator McLean. I have advised Senator McLean that I would be doing so. The honourable senator has made no secret of the fact that he is pursuing a hit list of banks he accuses of malpractice and corrupt practice. He has promised to provide the national bank inquiry with what he calls a `wheelbarrow' of material.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that I have listened to Senator McLean in adjournment speeches for quite some time now. I have been a little apprehensive about the names he has dropped under parliamentary privilege. In the adjournment speech to which I refer, he was not content to allow that inquiry to assess the matters brought to his attention, but he proceeded, I believe, to convene a kangaroo court to act as judge and jury to destroy the reputation of a particular banking official. I believe that Senator McLean acted solely in reliance on complaints made to him by certain individuals. I am informed that he made no attempt whatsoever to contact the person he planned to defame in order to investigate the truth of the allegations or to give that person an opportunity to present his side of the story.

Senator McLean launched into a sustained attack on the character of the former National Australia Bank manager in Toowoomba, a Mr Colin Cannon. I personally feel free to name Mr Cannon because his name has already been maligned through the media. Senator McLean did this by recklessly scattering allegations of malpractice and corrupt practice, fraud, conspiracy, deliberate deceit, greed and financial thuggery. His attacks, couched as they were in such extreme and uncompromising language, gained extensive coverage in the local newspaper and on Toowoomba television.

Senator McLean may or may not be aware that there was a large feature article in the Toowoomba Chronicle headed `Senate told of bank's fraud, deceit and greed'. In fact, Senator McLean is quoted throughout that article. One can only speculate about how the local media obtained such complete details of the matters aired in the Senate. I would have to say that one would not expect the adjournment debates in the Senate to be closely monitored by the Toowoomba Chronicle.

I also point out that as a result of that adjournment speech Mr Cannon was featured with still pictures of himself in the lead story on Star Television news. Again, the same remarks were repeated in that lead story on the television station. When Senator McLean throws names around like this, I wonder whether he recognises the damage that can be done. Senators can imagine the grievous, possibly irreparable, damage done to a person's reputation by this type of publicity. The distress caused not to Mr Cannon in particular, but to his wife and children and the harm to his future career can scarcely be calculated.

People may ask, `How can we believe in this man's integrity when a member of the Senate would say such things about him in the Commonwealth Parliament?'. It is obvious that Senator McLean relied on the complaints of two individuals who claim to have suffered loss as a result of the bank's actions. This chamber is not in a position to adjudicate in commercial disputes. I shall not detain the Senate by recounting all the details of the dealings between the bank and the customer. They are well documented, and particularly well documented in the two court hearings that were held on this matter.

However, although Senator McLean dismissed the fact that the complaints did not succeed as a technicality, it is a matter of record that his informants had failed twice in court action designed to establish their claim. Unlike him, I shall not embarrass these particular people-they have admittedly suffered financial loss for whatever reason-by naming them in the Commonwealth Parliament.

There were two court cases. In the initial court case, judgment was handed down on 29 September 1988 and is available for public scrutiny. The appeal case before three judges of the Federal Court of Australia, held on 21 April 1989, also failed. It disturbs me that Senator McLean was willing to use this chamber under the protection of privilege to make allegations against an individual without apparently being in possession of all the facts in relation to the matter; indeed, without even giving the target of his attack an opportunity to state his side of the case.

Had Senator McLean made even a perfunctory effort to investigate the complaint brought to him, he may have discovered what the courts have said about the credibility of his informants-informants whose complaints the Senator seems to have accepted without question. Senator McLean chose to table 33 documents following his speech, but in this bulk of paper he neglected to include the two court judgments which record that many of the assertions and allegations he made were not accepted by the Federal Court.

It is instructive to look at the relevant litigation, which alleged that Mr Cannon engaged in misleading and deceptive conduct in relation to certain property transactions. In the Federal Court the case turned upon the credibility of witnesses. It is significant to note that the trial judge, Mr Justice Neaves, made firm findings of credit and generally accepted Mr Cannon's evidence and did not accept the evidence of the complainants. Of one of the complainants, His Honour said that he `formed such an adverse view of her as a witness that I have completely disregarded what she said except where it is confirmed by other credible evidence'.

Further, the judge chose to believe Mr Cannon's evidence that two crucial alleged meetings referred to by Senator McLean had not taken place as claimed by the complainant. His Honour found that, even assuming that alternate unsatisfactory evidence was reliable, it was insufficient to establish the allegations against Mr Cannon. On appeal the applicants tried to amend their claim, but permission was refused not only because it would have led to unfairness at that late stage but also because it would not have led to any different result. That is what was found by the three judges.

Mr President, to my deep regret, I can only conclude that Senator McLean has abused the privilege enjoyed by honourable senators-something that was alluded to last night by Senator Aulich and, in fact, I understand picked up by Senator McLean himself. In the process Senator McLean has undoubtedly damaged his own credibility, calling into question the reliability of all the other adjournment debate bank malpractice exposes to which he has treated us.
Last night, as I mentioned, we were lectured by Senator Aulich on this matter. He advised us to recognise:

. . . that parliamentary privilege exists for a very specific purpose; namely, as a protection for parliamentarians who must raise contentious issues that are demonstrably in the public interest. It exists for their protection against defamation and for no other purpose. If it is to be used for personal attacks on people, either through implication or innuendo, and if attacks without substance against individuals who are not in this chamber are to be the order of the day, then the question of parliamentary privilege will be queried all around this country.

It was rather a coincidence that the next speaker was Senator McLean, who announced that he intended yet again to use parliamentary privilege for another of his anti-bank crusades, although he acknowledged the extreme seriousness that is associated with the use of parliamentary privilege. I believe that Senator McLean's actions belie the fact that he has any notion about the seriousness of relying on parliamentary privilege to attack defenceless individuals.

When Mr Cannon phoned me to discuss this matter he was in a state of great distress. Two court cases had been held on the matter and he had been found innocent in both. He said to me that he did not care much about himself, that he was happy to accept the cut and thrust of life, but that his wife and daughters were distraught. It had even got to the stage, for a man who had been married some 15 or 20 years, where his own wife was saying, `If you are innocent, how come you cannot protest your innocence against these claims made in the Federal Parliament?'. He phoned me and asked me what he could do about it.

I went to some lengths to look into the matter before I got up in this place to debate it. I believe that a decent and responsible citizen has had his character damaged by reckless and unfounded statements made in this place. I think that if Senator McLean has any sense of honour and principle-and since coming into this place I have believed that he has had honour and principle-he should offer a full apology to the person he has wronged. He should also contact the newspapers and the media who quite improperly reported what he said in this place. It will not repair the damage he has done, but it may go some way to restoring the self-esteem of a decent man and his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make a few comments in response to what Senator Parer has said before I move on to what I intend to say in the adjournment debate this evening. By all means, I acknowledge the seriousness of the use of parliamentary privilege and that what I have said will impact upon the lives of those about whom I have spoken. I have spoken with literally hundreds of people in the last two years about the matters which I have brought into this chamber. Their lives have also been impacted upon, their lives destroyed and, in many cases, their marriages and health destroyed. They were distressed when they came to me and many of them are still distressed. I have borne the consequences of bringing these cases before the Senate.
—What about the court judgments, though?

—I have seen, read and discussed the court judgments. I have had hundreds of hours of discussion with the people whose cases I have brought to the attention of this chamber. I have not brought them in here lightly, and I am not placing them before the parliamentary inquiry lightly. At long last, a colleague has taken the allegations seriously, has taken the material that I brought into the Senate for the deliberation of senators and has responded to the process that for two years I have challenged my colleagues to undertake. I am prepared and knew that I would have to live with the consequences of my action. I understand that I will have to live with the consequences of taking the matters before a parliamentary inquiry.
—Why have you been so selective?

—I have been very selective in what I have put before the Senate. I have said that I have in excess of 400 cases. I have chosen to put some of those cases before the Senate. I made the judgment on the evidence that was brought to me by constituents, and I responded as a senator. I am now prepared, as I say, to live with the consequences of that decision.

SPEECH.PARA: I now proceed to the issue of what I consider to be bank malpractice and corrupt practices-but not this particular matter. Honourable senators will be relieved to hear that I will be brief. They will recall that during the adjournment debates of 13 and 14 September 1990, and then again last night, I disclosed what has been referred to as the Rigg case. I have demonstrated that in 1984 the Commonwealth Bank of Australia marketed a finance package to small business proprietors offering a bills discount facility with foreign currency loan options. I demonstrated that the bills drawn down by the bank were a sham, calculated to extract from the borrower-in this case the Riggs-the interest that would otherwise be paid to an independent dealer on the open money market, together with the bank's usual fees and margins, together with compounded overdraft interest thereon, in addition to foreign exchange losses incurred by the borrower pursuant to a contractual pretence.

The finance package was offered to Mr and Mrs Rigg and their company, Tony Rigg Welding and Manufacturing Pty Ltd. The bank provided to the Riggs the bill discount facility and the Riggs business was crippled. Such a finance package was also offered to Mr and Mrs Rahme-whose case I will now briefly describe-and their company, David Securities Pty Ltd. The bank provided the Rahmes with the foreign currency loan, as a result of which the Rahmes business was crippled.

I am citing only two cases-and I will place them before the bank inquiry-out of what is estimated to have been 1,400 such cases in Australia at that time. It is this process about which Dr Henry Stalder a few weeks ago made a quite unsolicited comment when I was sitting with Swiss bankers in Zurich. He said-and I paraphrase it-that the senior bank officers who manipulated Australian business people and farmers into Swiss foreign bank loans between 1984 and 1986 are little more than criminals and should be in gaol. He said that he would come to Australia to testify to that effect.

By a loan agreement dated 17 December 1984-and at the end of my speech I will seek leave to table the document supporting what I am saying here tonight-David Securities, as the borrower, entered into a purported foreign currency loan with the Commonwealth Bank of Australia of Suite 2204, 50 Raffles Place, Singapore, as the bank. I contend that the agreement was a sham-a contractual pretence entered into by the bank to induce the borrower to accept a foreign exchange risk that did not exist. In other words, the system that the bank was using was to extract profit at the expense of customers under this particular mechanism.

I contend that if the loan had been a genuine foreign currency loan the bank would have complied with the laws of Singapore and Australia and would religiously have observed and performed the terms of agreement to ensure its enforceability against the borrower. The bank did not do that. By entering into an agreement the bank traded out of a permanent establishment in Singapore. That would have required the bank to be registered in Singapore as a corporation. It appears from the face of the agreement that the bank was not registered in Singapore as a corporation. Further the bank would have been obliged to hold a banker's licence and to lodge a tax return disclosing interest and foreign exchange profits paid by the borrower. I am aware that the Singaporean Government is undertaking an investigation into the activities of the bank in Singapore and may shortly call evidence from representatives of the borrower. I will endeavour to keep the Senate informed of these developments.

Clause 2 (a) of the agreement requires the borrower to give written notice to the bank-that is, in Singapore-requesting draw-downs. The bank did not seek or receive any such notices. Clause 5 (a) (i) requires the bank to give notice to the borrower in Singapore of any agreements to make an advance in Swiss francs. No such notices were ever given. Clause 2 requires the bank to make available all advances in Singapore. No advances were made available in Singapore. The advances were made available by the Commonwealth Bank of Australia in Sydney. I cite a letter from Mr K. T. Robinson to the borrower, dated 7 January 1985, and I will seek leave to table that at the end of my statement.

Clause 2 (d) of the agreement requires the borrower to give written notice to the bank in Singapore requesting renewals of roll-overs of the loan. The bank did not seek or receive any such notices. The roll-over notices from the borrower were addressed to the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Dee Why. I cite as an example a notice received on 21 June 1985, which was accepted by the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Dee Why. I cite also a letter from Mr G. R. Porter to the borrower, dated 2 October 1985. Moreover the bank did not seek or receive any applications from the borrower for extensions to the loan. The applications for renewal from the borrower were addressed to the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Dee Why. I refer to an application dated 18 December 1986, which was accepted by the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Dee Why, and a further undated letter on the same subject.

Clause 7 (a) (i) of the agreement in conjunction with a letter from Mr Robinson required interest payments in Swiss francs to be paid to the bank in Singapore. The borrower did not make any such payments to the bank at all, nor did the bank request or demand any such payments. In fact, payments of interest and withholding tax were remitted by the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Dee Why, to the CBA, Sydney. I cite the memorandum from Mr Robinson to the Dee Why branch, dated 28 June 1985.

Clause 7 (a) (i) further provides that payments by the borrower in United States dollars were to be paid to an account designated by the bank in New York City. After the loan was changed from Swiss francs to United States dollars, the bank did not designate a New York account. The borrower did not make any payments to the bank in New York at all, nor did the bank request or demand any such payments. In fact, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Sydney, purported to place the loan in default, to remain designated in United States dollars, but did not even mention the New York requirement. I cite a letter from Mr G. Pearce to the borrower dated 29 October 1987. Moreover the Commonwealth Bank, Sydney, issued a cross-claim against the borrower and against Mr and Mrs Rahme as guarantors-and I will table that cross-claim-in its own name and on its own behalf, not claiming the United States dollars as payable to the Singapore branch nor to a New York City branch.

Clause 8 (b) of the agreement provides that the borrower shall pay all interest payments to the bank in Singapore without deduction of any tax. This means that the borrower is obliged to pay withholding tax on the interest payments to the Australian Taxation Office. We know that funds representing withholding tax were remitted from the Commonwealth Bank, Dee Why, to the Commonwealth Bank, Sydney. I will table evidence of that. Honourable senators will also know that several hundred million dollars collected by the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and other major banks as withholding tax were not paid to the Australian Taxation Office and were not refunded to the borrowers. That is what happened in this case and the borrower is taking the issue to the High Court of Australia.

Why did the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Sydney, not pay the withholding tax on behalf of the borrower to the Australian Taxation Office? If the foreign currency loan was legitimate and interest payments were made by the Commonwealth Bank, Sydney, on behalf of the borrower to the bank in Singapore, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Sydney, was obliged by law to pay the withholding tax to the Australian Taxation Office. Failure to do so would be a fraud against the Australian Government. If the foreign currency loan was a sham, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Sydney, was not obliged by law to pay the withholding tax to the Australian Taxation Office. If that be the case, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Sydney, has defrauded the borrower in respect of charging foreign exchange `losses' to the borrower and misappropriating the withholding tax. I believe the Commonwealth Bank of Australia should not be allowed to get away with such delinquent and illegal conduct.

The issue of whether the foreign currency loan in this case was legitimate can only be resolved by establishing whether there was a nexus between the Swiss francs remitted by the bank in Singapore to the Commonwealth Bank in Sydney and the Australian dollar equivalent credited to the account of the borrower or its nominee. That can only be done by undertaking an audit trail of the funds.

The issue I have raised here is a matter of national importance and could lay bare the greatest banking scandal in Australia's history. In my view this issue comes within paragraph (d) (i), `Product innovation', of the terms of reference of the inquiry to be conducted by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. I propose to make a submission to that Committee relating to this specific case in conjunction with the Rigg matter and call for the audit to be undertaken.

The Commonwealth Bank is proceeding against David Securities Pty Ltd and Mr and Mrs Rahme by way of notices pursuant to section 57 (2) (b) of the New South Wales Real Property Act. I will table those notices. I believe I have produced sufficient evidence to demonstrate that the loan agreement is a sham. It means that the loan agreement is probably unenforceable and the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Sydney, never had standing to sue on it. I call upon the directors of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia to withhold any action on the notices until the issues I have raised are resolved by the parliamentary inquiry. I seek leave to table the documents to which I have referred in my speech.
Leave granted.
Wednesday, 12 December 1990

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to speak tonight, but I listened with a lot of sadness to Senator Parer's discussion of the case to which he referred and as he detailed how Senator McLean had maligned and defamed that man and the consequences that brought.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened with some interest to Senator Aulich's speech last night and I thought that was quite interesting too, although it was a bit one-sided. He spoke of Mr Tuckey and proceeded to malign him after saying that people should not be maligned in Parliament. I am pleased Senator Aulich is here tonight because no doubt he will get up to follow me.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have got to be joking.

—I would have thought that Senator Aulich would want to do so unless he was being hypocritical, because it was easy for him to attack Mr Tuckey when the House is not sitting and he is unable to respond to what Senator Aulich said. When you spoke last night you were followed by Senator McLean, who acknowledged everything that you said, and then proceeded to malign people again.
—Order! I ask Senator Macdonald to make his remarks through the Chair and not directly to Senator Aulich.

—I am sorry, Mr President. I shall do that. Last night Senator Aulich spoke very well in principle on the subject of maligning people but he had no sooner finished than Senator McLean, after acknowledging Senator Aulich was right and saying how proper his speech was, proceeded to malign someone else.

SPEECH.PARA: I would hope that Senator Aulich, in fairness, would get up tonight and make the same speech that he gave last night about Senator McLean. One wonders if there is something going on between the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party whereby they do not accuse and chastise each other.

Tonight's exhibition by Senator McLean has been absolutely disgraceful. Senator Parer has quite rightly pointed out how this person was maligned and defamed and the enormous problems, hurt and trauma that this has caused him and his family. He described this very clearly, rationally and calmly, and I congratulate him for bringing this matter to the Senate. He very calmly suggested that Senator McLean might do the decent thing, acknowledge that what he said was wrong, apologise, and undertake to contact all those press outlets that he apparently ran to so quickly with his release last time.

Senator Parer suggested that Senator McLean might have the decency to issue press releases to try in some way to repair the damage he has done. What did Senator McLean do? He did absolutely nothing except acknowledge that he knew the court cases that Senator Parer referred to but did not bother to tell us. He has the indecency now not even to acknowledge it. It is an absolutely disgraceful act, one that I think should be referred to some sort of privileges committee of the Parliament, or whatever else.

Senator McLean has been tabling a lot of documents. We usually give him permission to do so, but we wonder whether we should do that in the future when it seems that Senator McLean only tables documents that suit his cause and enable him to defame people. Any documents, such as the judgment which Senator Parer referred to, that show that what Senator McLean is talking about is nonsense, do not seem to be tabled. Maybe we and the Government should very seriously consider whether we will allow the tabling of these wheelbarrow loads of documents to continue.

When I first came to the Senate, I wondered what Senator McLean was on about. I spoke to one of my more senior colleagues who, in fact, that night, warned Senator McLean, because he had not shown us the documents to be tabled beforehand, that he should not set himself up as judge, jury, prosecutor and executioner. Senator McLean now very blandly says that he will wear whatever odium comes to him, but he still continues to be prosecutor, judge and executioner. I think this is a disgraceful misuse of this Parliament.

If Senator McLean has any understanding of the issues of British justice, he will realise that he cannot go around accusing people, being judge and jury, and determining the issue after hearing only one side of any argument. He should have been around for long enough to know that whenever there is one side of an argument, there is always another side. That is what is so unfortunate in what Senator McLean has done.

Such cases all sound terrible. If there have been malpractices, the courts of the land are there to deal with them. In fact, in the case that Senator Parer mentioned, the courts of the land did deal with them and came to an entirely different conclusion, in the proper legal way of British justice, which seems to refute, in just one instance that we know of, the sort of evidence that Senator McLean has allegedly been bringing before us.

Mr President, it is very late, but I was moved to raise that point. Having heard Senator Aulich last night, I was astounded that Senator McLean got up and did exactly the same thing. Tonight the mischief that has been caused has been shown very clearly by Senator Parer, yet Senator McLean does not even have the decency to apologise publicly to that man and to undertake certain actions.

I ask Senator McLean now if he has the decency to apologise to that man and to issue, in an apologetic form, the sort of wide ranging press releases that he issued in accusing him. I think that would not cause too much hurt, but it would go some way towards re-establishing the dignity of this place and of members of parliament generally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to keep the Senate for more than a couple of minutes. I believe that what has been occurring over the last few weeks in this Senate degrades the Senate by abusing the privilege that honourable senators have in this place. Senator McLean has given the Senate hearsay evidence of what has occurred-in his belief or his informant's belief-in a small country town, without giving the person he is accusing any opportunity of response. Indeed, even when a court case has been held and the court has decided on the person's innocence, we have not been told that the court case was even held. We were told only one side-the hearsay evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Evidently, Senator McLean finds it very easy to stand up here and say that he is well aware of what he is doing and that he is willing to wear it. I wonder whether he really understands that he is not the only one having to wear what he has been saying in this place. Mr Cannon and his family also have to wear what he has been saying in this place.

Has he any idea of what living in a small town is like? I do. I used to live in a small town. I can assure Senator McLean that he cannot undo the damage he has done to this gentleman because a small town does not work that way. Even if he stood here and apologised in the Senate, he may do some good but he will never remove the mud that he has thrown. I think that anyone who comes into this place besmirching a man's reputation without ever approaching that man and asking for his point of view on the hearsay evidence lacks all credibility. Anyone who has any responsibility at all should not do this.

I would like to join with my colleagues in asking Senator McLean whether he would be willing to apologise. He should forget about what he is thinking. He must know that what he has brought into this place is just hearsay evidence. He should at least follow up what he has told the Toowoomba Chronicle, make sure that that is corrected and, at least in that sense, respond to Mr Cannon in this instance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want briefly to comment on this matter, which is a serious matter-
—Not you, too!
—Despite the smears of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans), who is at the table, a very serious matter has been raised by Senator Parer this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that Senator McLean made his comment on the same day that the Senate was subjected to 10 to 15 minutes of complaints from Senator McLean because he felt that some people in this chamber had reflected on his character. If we inspect the Hansard of the day, we will find that Senator McLean was greatly concerned about what he judged to be reflections made upon him.

What shocked me particularly about this debate this evening-and I come late to this issue-was the appalling defence that Senator McLean put up to the comments made by Senator Parer. Senator McLean made no attempt to answer the comments that Senator Parer had made. As Senator Walters said, he was prepared purely to wear them.

I would urge Senator McLean to think very carefully about what he has done and to think very carefully not only about how he has damaged the people concerned in this small country town but also about how he has damaged the standing of this Senate by his behaviour. I think all of us are very concerned to ensure that the standard of behaviour in this chamber is raised. It is certainly a view that Mr Hawke has put forward and a view that Dr Hewson has put forward. It is certainly a view that Senator Powell and her colleagues put from time to time. I ask Senator McLean to rise this evening and, if he cannot effectively respond to the issues which have been raised by Senator Parer, to do the manly thing and the decent thing and apologise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The documents I have tabled, now essentially in relation to in excess of 80 cases, have been the sworn statements of constituents. When I started this process I was told by Mr Allan Cullen, for instance, of the Australian Bankers Association that I should challenge the sworn statements of every constituent that walked through my door.
—Answer the comments of Senator Parer.

—Listen, I am making my statement, not a statement that Senator Kemp wants. He asked me to respond and I will respond. He may or may not be satisfied with my response. I begin with the assumption that, when constituents come to me and plead with me to table in the Senate their sworn affidavits, and when they plead with me to establish a special Senate inquiry to investigate the credibility of their sworn statements or the statements that I make to this Parliament, it is not unreasonable to assume that they are telling me the truth and that they are not liars. That is the beginning of the judicial process that has been referred to here this evening.
—Why didn't you mention the court case?

—If Senator Walters had cared to read the sworn affidavits that I had tabled, she would have seen reference to the trials. She has not read the document herself. Opposition senators have chosen to come in here and run the counter case, and I admire them for that. I have been pleading with people to do that. Why have I been tabling the documents for them to read? But they have not read them. Month after month, case after case, the sworn affidavits have not been read.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Parer has admitted here tonight that a senior colleague denied me leave actually to table documents that supported allegations I was making. The first time I attempted to use privilege in this place, in my name-me using privilege, not people's sworn affidavits-I was denied the right to table the documents that supported the process that I was going through. It was a senior lawyer that was denying me the right to table those documents.

Opposition senators have selectively read some of the Hansards. They have decided to come in here and at long last respond to the process that I have been asking them to respond to. I have twice called for a Senate inquiry based upon the documents I was tabling, and twice they have got up and refused that inquiry. I have stood in front of this nation and said, `If I lack credibility, prove it. Prove it by having a Senate inquiry; prove that McLean is barking up the wrong tree; prove that by coming in here with sworn affidavits of constituents I am abusing my privilege'. What say I move the motion again tomorrow for a Senate inquiry?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the issue.

—It is the issue. It will provide the Opposition and the whole Senate with the opportunity of taking all of the material that has been tabled. The applications for evidence to be placed before a parliamentary inquiry close on Friday. I have gone around this country pleading with Australians to put evidence before the inquiry into banking practices and the opportunity closes on Friday. How many of the people on the Opposition benches have gone out and told their constituents to take that opportunity? How many of them have done it?
—We believe in the law of the land, the courts.
—Listen, the law of the land is not always right.
—Order! There are too many interjections. Senator McLean, address the Chair and not the interjectors.

—I am sorry, Mr President. I just do not happen to believe that the law of the land is always right. There have been some outstanding cases when the judicial process has let down justice and has not delivered justice. I am not going to apologise for what I have done. I take no pride in the fact that what I have done has impacted sadly upon families. It has impacted upon my own family, with death threats and a marriage break-up. I understand the implications. Opposition senators should not sit there and preach to me about the fact that I am doing serious things. I foreshadow to the Senate now that I will move again the same motion that I have twice moved, for a Senate inquiry into banking practice in this country. That will be the Opposition's opportunity to shoot down my credibility. That will be its opportunity to destroy my reputation.
—You have done it yourself.
—I will do it again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak very briefly. I have always held Senator McLean in high regard in my short time here. The allegations that have been made tonight are essentially that Senator McLean has made comments upon a person's character based upon documents that were tabled selectively. Parliamentary privilege exists so that parliamentarians can make allegations in the public good. Sometimes that entails making an allegation which is mistaken; that is, an allegation which is made in good faith but is based upon a mistake. That is why we have parliamentary privilege. I think there is a difference between an allegation based on a mistake and an allegation based on the selectivity of documents that have been tabled. I do not intend to act as a judge, a prosecutor or a jury in the case of Senator McLean; I just raise this as a distinction between the two bases upon which this sort of allegation can be raised. If it is the case that Senator McLean has based an allegation upon selectively tabled documents, I will be very disturbed. I hope that my faith in Senator McLean has not been misplaced.

SPEECH.PARA: I think there is also a distinction to be made when one queries a court case because we are here as crusaders, I believe, for the public good. Sometimes that means that we in this Senate must question things and fight for causes. But we always have to be very careful when we start to query the results of court cases because I believe there is another distinction that must be made as well-that is, to distinguish between alleging guilt or innocence after a case has been heard by a court. I believe that it is fair and permissible for a member of the Senate to allege that a court may have found wrongly and that a man or a woman was in fact innocent when he or she was found guilty.

But I do not believe it is appropriate for any member of parliament to raise a question of somebody's guilt, of somebody's negligence or of malfeasance after a court has acquitted him of that charge. That is not our role and that is not what parliamentary privilege should be used for.
