I only cite the oft repeated phrase of Blackstone who said that it is better that 10 guilty men go free than that one innocent man be condemned. I think this is something that we must always bear in mind when we use our privilege in this case and question court cases.

As I said, I do not intend to condemn Senator McLean. I have always held him in the highest regard. I would only suggest that in the cold light of day tomorrow, perhaps when Senator McLean has had the opportunity to review the matter and when he is perhaps feeling less personally involved, as a result of some of the statements that have been made by honourable senators this evening, he may wish to change the comments he has made. He may wish to make another statement. If Senator McLean were to do that, I would welcome that statement wholeheartedly. It would restore my faith in him and I think it would do much to restore my faith in the manner in which we in this Senate use our parliamentary privilege.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President--
—Oh!

—I am sorry to disappoint the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I do not need to assure him as he can see for himself that I do not fit into the category of the seven dwarfs-as he referred to members on this side of the chamber inasmuch as they were getting up and following each other. It is one of the rare occasions that my demeanour is an advantage.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to speak very briefly on this matter. Senator McLean sought from this chamber, not that long ago, leave to make some brief remarks and he did so on the basis that he wanted to make a response. I think the fair understanding from that was that he was going to respond to the substantive remarks that had been made. Instead, what we were subjected to was a short lecture of vitriol. It was probably some insight into Senator McLean when he is near the end of his tether.

We in this chamber were not treated to any response to the remarks made by Senator Parer at all-the basis, of course, on which the leave was given. What we were treated to, if one can summarise it and paraphrase it, was Senator McLean saying to this chamber, `Don't you challenge me to answer to you here in this chamber for what I have said; don't you challenge me here to answer for the omissions I have made. But you do what I want you to do. You have this particular Senate inquiry that I want you to have, and then you can have your chance at me.'-I notice that Senator Bell has come in to support Senator McLean and, heaven knows, he needs a bit of support on this matter- `You do what I want to do and have this Senate inquiry, and through that you'll be able to show whether I'm right or wrong'.

The point is that Senator McLean has made certain remarks, certain omissions, and Senator Parer has come in and put some further light on the story. Some people are, I think, entitled to draw the conclusion that the truth has been told by Senator McLean, but not the whole truth. Of course the reason one says, `Tell the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth' is that, if one does not tell the truth and the whole truth, one can mislead. So leave was granted to Senator McLean to clear this matter up, to tell us where Senator Parer was wrong. Leave was granted for that to be done and it was not done. In fact, there was pretty much silence as to the matters that Senator Parer had raised.

Now, the Australian Democrats are going to come here into this chamber tomorrow on a completely different matter and they are going to argue that silence is acquiescence, it is consent and it is agreement. They are going to say in relation to another matter altogether that if one does not open one's mouth and point out where someone else is wrong, one is agreeing with him. That is the line that we are going to hear trotted out tomorrow in relation to a piece of retrospective legislation. So I wonder why they are not doing it tonight. Can we assume from Senator McLean's silence with respect to the allegations made by Senator Parer that he acquiesces to them? Can we assume by his huffing and puffing and simply bypassing what Senator Parer has raised that he does in fact agree?

I conclude at this point, Mr President, simply by saying that I think it is very regrettable where a senator comes in and does what Senator McLean has done, is challenged by another with an alternative or an additional set of facts, seeks leave to make a response to that and does not take up that opportunity. Senator Kemp invited Senator McLean to do the right and decent thing and to apologise. He has failed to do it. I think that is regrettable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, far be it from anyone on the Government side to seek to intervene in a war of destructive rhetoric between the Opposition and the Australian Democrats, but there are some serious issues that have been raised tonight. It is always a serious matter when someone under cover of privilege raises allegations about guilt or innocence of offences or impropriety of a high order. I do not believe there is anything prima facie wrong about doing so, provided the person makes those allegations or suggestions in good faith and backs them up with something in the nature of substantial or at least prima facie evidence. Without wishing to go into the canvassing of the merits of the situation, I think that point ought to be acknowledged.

SPEECH.PARA: Equally, anyone bringing forward matters of this kind in the Senate has to be conscious, as a number of honourable senators have said, of the very great potential damage that allegations of that kind can do to people's reputations, and it is for that reason that the conventions and the procedures of this place are couched in such a way as to ensure, hopefully, that allegations are not made under cover of privilege, unless there is a strong basis or believed basis for doing so-and I think that is the way we ought to look at it. I just cannot forbear from one further comment--

TALK.START.PARA: —It has to be more than hearsay evidence when a court case has been held.

—The comment I am obliged to make in these circumstances is that, for all the enthusiasm we have heard on the Opposition side tonight about accepting due process in the courts, I cannot help but recall innumerable cases in the past, and some running presently, when there has been an utter unwillingness on the part of the Opposition as a whole or particular Opposition senators to accept the principle of innocence until guilt or impropriety is established by court or by royal commission, as the case may be, and all sorts of allegations are constantly being made against carefully targeted people.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators opposite do not need me to remind them now at this hour of some of the occasions in the past when witch-hunts of this kind have been maintained. They do not need me to remind them of one of the witch-hunts that is presently being set in train by some of their number at the moment in relation to matters presently or potentially the subject of royal commissions or conceivably, ultimately, court hearings. The principle of innocence being presumed until guilt is established is not one that has been honoured in the observance, for all the unctuous lakes of crocodile tears that we see on so many occasions and that we have seen again being filled up tonight.

So, having said that, Mr President, I think it should be acknowledged nonetheless-I repeat again-that there are important issues involved whenever serious allegations are raised under cover of privilege. It is not competent for this chamber tonight to evaluate the merits of these allegations. It is not competent for me to make any judgment about the good faith or otherwise with which those allegations have been made or answered. I just make the point on behalf of the Government, which is a not very interested spectator of this particular combat at the moment, that it is incumbent on both sides to this debate to think very carefully before embarking further on a course which may be damaging to the reputations either way of particular individuals-and I hope we can leave the debate there for tonight, although no doubt that is not the last we are going to hear of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with a great deal of patience and tolerance to this debate from its inception. I would not have spoken but for the outrageous behaviour of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans). To classify what has gone on tonight as some sort of squabble between the Australian Democrats and the Opposition is to either have a total lack of understanding of what the debate was about or to be utterly, completely and totally irresponsible.

SPEECH.PARA: The fundamental issue that those on this side of the chamber have been seeking to establish and defend is the fact that the Parliament has a reputation as an institution. It is the institution of the Parliament that is under assault when these sorts of attacks are made on innocent, or presumably innocent, individuals in the community who have no recourse to defend themselves. It is quite different when leading political figures in the country are under attack. They are fair game. All of us in this chamber are fair game for criticism and for attack, to have our motives assailed and debased and all the rest of it.

What my colleagues have been doing tonight is defending the institution of the Parliament. I understand from what the Minister has said that he does not have the first comprehension of what a parliament is about.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 12.42 a.m. (Wednesday)

The following answer to a question was circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 14 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the total number of passengers travelling through the international terminal at Adelaide airport in the latest 12-month period.
(2) How does the total in (1) above compare with the total for the corresponding period in 1988-89.
(3) What was the major country of origin of passengers arriving at Adelaide airport on international flights.
(4) How many passengers travelled non-stop in each direction between Adelaide and New Zealand in the latest 12-month period.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) According to provisional data reported to the Department by international airlines flying to and from Adelaide, 168,259 passengers arrived and departed Adelaide international airport in the 12 months ending June 1990. This data excludes transit passengers.

(2) From the same source of data, 138,433 passengers arrived and departed Adelaide international airport in the 12 months ending June 1989. This data excludes transit passengers. The number of passengers for the 12 months ending June 1990 represents an increase of approximately 21.6 per cent compared with the number of passengers for the 12 months ending June 1989.

(3) The Department is unable to readily provide data on the major country of origin of passengers by arrival on international flights. However, using data by total movement (ie arrivals and departures), the major country of origin of passengers on flights to and from Adelaide for the 12 months ending June 1990 was the United Kingdom (representing approximately 33.3 per cent of visitor arrivals and departures).

(4) Provisional data reported to the Department by international airlines flying to and from Adelaide shows that there were 5,077 passengers travelling non-stop from Adelaide to New Zealand in the 12 months ending June 1990, with 4,608 passengers travelling non-stop from New Zealand to Adelaide during the same period. These numbers actually represent passengers carried from December 1989 to June 1990 as there were no non-stop flights between Adelaide and New Zealand (and vice versa) for the period July to November 1989.
